PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House records its sincere regret at the death on 6 October 1981 of President Mohamed Anwar El Sadat, and expresses to the people of the Arab Republic of Egypt profound regret and tenders its deep sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

I advise the House that the Commonwealth Heads of Government in Melbourne jointly extended their deep sympathy to Madam Sadat and to the Government and people of Egypt and expressed their horror at the act of outrage which took President Sadat's life. The Governor-General has also expressed his deep sadness and distress over the manner and fact of President Sadat's death. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) represented Australia at the funeral.

Anwar Sadat was one of the architects of the movement which shaped modern Egypt and which brought it to its present level of social and economic development. On becoming President of Egypt in 1970, he led his country both as an outstanding patriot and as a man of vision in relations between nations. It reflected his great personal courage and initiative that he worked so hard to lay the groundwork for a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East. To embark on this process involved an acceptance of substantial risk, both domestic and international. His capacity to devote his energies single mindedly while bringing his nation with him was itself a tribute to his greatness.

In 1977, after 30 years of continual warfare in the Middle East, President Sadat made his historic and courageous visit to Jerusalem to address the Knesset and thus open the path to negotiation in the quest for peace. Then, in 1979, the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty was signed. I said at the time that the world hoped that work on a comprehensive Middle East settlement would proceed in the aftermath of that treaty. President Sadat sought peace to resolve the problems built up through mistrust and fear. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1978 jointly with the Prime Minister of Israel.

While the peace with Israel and the stability which has ensued is perhaps President Sadat's greatest monument, his other achievements are no less significant. He realised that the basic security of Egypt and the Middle East lay in distancing the region from wider global power struggles, and to this end he sought to diminish the impact of the Soviet Union by restricting its influence within Egypt and the area as a whole. His pursuit of constructive and realistic domestic and foreign policies brought both to himself and to Egypt a reputation for moderation, balance and constraint in the non-aligned movement. His death is a great loss for Egypt, the Middle East and the world, not least because of the senseless and brutal violence which brought it about.

To have lost a world leader of President Sadat's stature is tragic. Not everyone, as we know, agreed with what the President was doing, although everyone must surely respect him for his courage and his objectives of peace and stability, and certainly no benefits will follow from what has taken place. We can only hope and trust that President Sadat's achievements will be sustained and that his vision of a lasting and comprehensive peace settlement can be realised as a fitting tribute and memorial to him. We all mourn his death. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a sombre occasion. The world mourns the late Anwar Sadat. He was brutally assassinated last week at Cairo, capital of Egypt for which, as President, the late Anwar Sadat had toiled courageously and with determination. By any measure the late President Anwar Sadat must be credited as an historically significant leader of his country. I totally condemn his assassination, whatever its motivation. On behalf of the Australian Labor Party I extend my deepest sympathy to his widow and his children at this time of bitter grief.

SPEECH.PARA: Anwar Sadat was born on 25 December 1918 in the village of Mit Abul Kam on the Nile delta. He was the son of a poor military clerk and a Sudanese woman. As early as 1939 he joined a group dedicated to the liberation of Egypt from British occupation and from a corrupt regime which dominated the Egyptian Government. After the war he held a variety of jobs-truck driver, newspaper reporter and canal digger, until he rejoined the army in 1950. He took part in the 1952 revolution against the monarchy and was a relatively obscure figure in Egyptian politics until he inherited the presidency upon President Nasser's death in 1970. He was considered at that time as a purely interim figure. President Sadat, however, proved all the predictions false. Over the next 10 years he showed himself above all to be a man totally unafraid to pursue the course he felt was best for Egypt.

More than anything else President Sadat was a man who took enormous risks. He turned out the Russian advisers who totally dominated the Egyptian economy and military machine. He undertook the 1973 war against Israel and, in doing that, against all the odds. Whatever the military analysts may say was the true outcome of the conflict, he and his people saw it as the restoration of their national pride which had been destroyed in 1967. He increasingly turned towards the West and in the mid-1970s adopted an open-door economic policy towards foreign investment. The greatest risk he took, however, was in his attitudes to the Arab-Israeli conflict which had brought his country to war four times in some 30 years. It was he who initiated the opening to Israel. It was he who journeyed to Jerusalem in November 1977. It was he who was the driving force in achieving the Camp David Accords in 1978-79. He did so despite the vilification of his neighbouring Arab countries and pursued unremittingly the course which he saw as the one best for his people despite all opposition, both within and outside his own country.

The great tragedy for Egypt is the intractable economic problems that confront it. Its population growth has been a serious problem, stretching available resources too thinly. In 1980 its economic growth was calculated as around 10 per cent but there was an inflation rate of about 50 per cent and per capita income was about $370. Imports of wheat supplied two-thirds of Egypt's needs and petroleum reserves were running down.

Within this environment, constricted by all of the difficulties of a large and growing population and minimal opportunity for the generation of savings to allow investment to develop, growth to be promoted, and living standards to be improved, there were, obviously, serious bottlenecks obstructing effective income redistribution. These clearly led to expressions of discontent as they inevitably will. There were political and religious tensions to be contended with as well as the strand of Pan-Arabism which is influential in certain parts of the military, the intelligentsia and the middle class. These were very difficult ingredients to handle.

Indeed, they represented a fissionable association. On balance one concludes that the control of the potential of these various forces for explosive ignition in the wake of the cruel slaughter of Anwar Sadat is an indication of how successfully he had been striving to balance and contain them.

I said earlier that he was a man of great courage. It is now known that he was aware that his life was in danger. But with the true courage of a soldier he still persisted in discharging his official duties, knowing full well that he was exposing himself to the risk of violent death whenever he did so.

Perhaps I can briefly anecdotically recall from personal experience Anwar Sadat's charm, lively interest and intellectual awareness. A little over 12 months ago he generously spared more than an hour of his time at Alexandria to talk with me in detail of the problems with which he had to contend within his very difficult region, of the economic challenges confronting his country, of his determination to try to improve the lot of the ordinary people of his nation. It was not a matter of a man being carried forward by a grand and impractical vision of a better society. He acknowledged the enormous economic constraints that bore down so depressingly on his country. But he was confident in his belief that with all of those limitations there was still room for a better result to be achieved for the ordinary Egyptian people, and within this context it was his belief that peace in his region was an absolutely essential ingredient to all that. War wasted too many resources, human and material, and destroyed too many opportunities for creative endeavour within his country. In the final result it will be said that he was a warrior for peace, and it is to be hoped that the commendable objectives which he laid before himself will be pursued by his successors with diligence, intelligence and conviction. His passing is mourned throughout the world and indeed throughout this country and within this Parliament, and the sadness is shared by all members of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the National Country Party and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the members of that party, I endorse the motion that has been moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden).

SPEECH.PARA: The late Mohamed Anwar Sadat was born on Christmas Day, 25 December 1918. He was one of 13 children of Mohamed Sadat, a civilian clerk in a military hospital. His birthplace was a small town-a cluster of mud-brick buildings-in provincial Egypt north of Cairo. He rose from that to the highest position in the land.

He moved to Cairo with his family when his father was transferred there in 1925. There he lived in a small house on the outskirts of the capital not far from the palace of the Egyptian kings. Indeed, he often boasted that as a child he stole apricots from the royal orchard. From his youth he was a nationalist who had a burning desire to play an important part in his nation's development. He saw the best way of doing this as a military officer, and he graduated from the Royal Military College in 1938. He spent most of the years of World War II as a prisoner of the British. Twice he escaped from prison. On the first occasion he went straight to the palace of King Farouk, signed the visitors' book with a plea for independence, and returned to prison in a taxi cab. On the second, he lived as a fugitive and worked as a labourer. He was close to the late Colonel Nasser, a former military college classmate, and he had the task of taking over the Cairo radio in 1952 to announce Nasser's coup. He showed his religious nature by waiting 20 minutes for the completion of the daily reading from the Koran before he made the announcement. He held several important posts under President Nasser but his real stature was never fully appreciated. He was the only vice-president when Nasser died. He was sworn into office as President on 19 October 1970.

The late President Sadat was thought to be only an interim leader, but he survived several coups and soon began to leave his mark on Egypt. One of his first achievements was a new Egyptian constitution in which he sought to blend the best of the traditional Islamic values with Western concepts of human rights and parliamentary responsibility. He led his country to war-the Yom Kippur or Ramadan war in 1973. It was through the experience of that war that Sadat became a peacemaker, and that, of course, is how he will be long remembered. He wanted peace and he showed that he was prepared to take risks to get it. It is not without significance that the peacemaker died at a military rally. The high point in his career was probably his decision to go to Jerusalem nearly four years ago when he was received by the people, the Knesset and the Government of Israel in a way that will be remembered, as Prime Minister Begin has said, as one of the great events of our time. Equally significantly, he returned to Egypt from Jerusalem fearing that he might be met by hostile crowds, but he was greeted by his own people who demonstrated that they were exhausted by 30 years of war and sought peace in the way that he did. President Sadat's death has taken from the world one of the great statesmen of our time. The scope of his greatness is marked by the fact that nearly everyone now wonders what impact his death will have upon his country, his region and the rest of the world. We can hope that the words of his successor, President Mubarak, will prove meaningful:

Although we have lost the leader, we find consolation because our people, throughout the country are standing in sadness and pain to declare that we are following his path, the road of peace in full conviction that it is the way of right, justice and freedom . . . We say to the late leader that we will stand as one solid front behind all the banners he had raised.

The late Anwar Sadat often said that his most valuable hours were not spent in the councils of state, but walking along the Nile contemplating the great questions of his time. He was clearly a man of his people and a man of his time. To Madam Sadat and the people of Egypt, on behalf of the National Country Party, I join in extending our deepest sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As spokesman for the Opposition in matters relating to foreign affairs I want to support the remarks of my leader in extending to President Sadat's family our deep and sincere sympathy in their loss. The late President Sadat will have a place in the modern history of the Middle East as a leader whose greatest campaign was for peace between his country and Israel. He will be remembered as a patriot who fought for the true independence of his country from the colonial rule of the British. He was a man of true intregrity and his assassination leaves the world a poorer and more dangerous place. That he was a man of great courage is undeniable. He demonstrated this shortly after his accession to power by moving to assert his country's independence and integrity in the face of great pressure from one of the super-powers. That he was a man of vision as well as of courage was demonstrated by his historic journey to Jerusalem in 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question that he desperately wanted to bring peace to his region. He understood, perhaps better than any other leader in that region, that accommodation and sacrifice were necessary to achieve that end. Unfortunately, his vision and courage were not always matched in equal measure. The greatest tribute to President Sadat, the most appropriate memorial to his memory, would be the achievement of a comprehensive and durable settlement in the Middle East that would allow his people, for whom he made the ultimate sacrifice, to live in peace. For them to live in peace means that all other people who live in that region need peace as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to cover ground already adequately covered by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). My views on President Sadat are known. I regarded him as one of the great men of this century. He is the only Arab leader who had the foresight and understanding to acknowledge the realities of Middle Eastern politics and the courage to do something about them. He paid for that with his life.

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1977, when he made the historic speech to the Egyptian Parliament offering to Israel the hand of peace of the largest and most powerful Arab country in the region, he knew the risks he was taking. He knew that there were forces in the Middle East which would stop at nothing to prevent peace coming about. It is not yet clear who was responsible for his assassination but it is clear from the reaction of some of the fanatics in the region that there were many who would willingly have done such a foul deed if the opportunity had been available to them.

What I want to do today is refute the obscenity reiterated both in Australia and abroad in the Middle East that Anwar Sadat was somehow a traitor to the Arab cause. He can be accused of being a traitor only by those who see the only solution to the conflict in the Middle East as the obliteration of the state of Israel. During the past few days we have seen in the Australian Press statements, editorials and articles from leading journalists, academics and politicians that have argued that President Sadat paid the price for Prime Minister Begin's intransigence and belligerence and that had Israel been prepared to negotiate with the more moderate elements in the Arab world, particularly the Palestine Liberation Organisation, the problem of the Middle East could have been resolved.

Let those people who reiterate these absurdities remember quite clearly what President Sadat said from the beginning of his peace initiatives and what was repeated by him in his speech to the Knesset and in dozens of speeches, letters and statements from then until his death last week.
I want to quote from that speech. He said:

The cause of the Palestinian people and their legitimate rights are no longer ignored or denied by anybody. It is a reality which the international community . . . has supported and recognised. The Palestinian Question is the heart and crux of the conflict, and as long as this issue remains unsolved the conflict can only continue to aggravate and to reach new dimensions. In all faith I tell you that peace cannot be achieved without the Palestinians. It would be a grave error with unpredictable consequences to ignore (their cause)-

One may not necessarily agree with all the sentiments expressed in those words of Anwar Sadat but I defy anyone in this House to state that these are the words of a man who has sold out the Arab cause, that these are the views of a man who is guilty of treachery to the Palestinian people. President Sadat went on to suggest a peace agreement based on the following principles:

First: Termination of Israel's occupation of the Arab territories occupied in 1967. Second: Achievement of the basic rights of the Palestinian people particularly their right to self-determination including the right to establish their own state. Third: The right of every state in the area to live in peace within secure borders guaranteed by mutually agreed procedures that would ensure the proper security of the international borders in addition to appropriate international guarantees. Fourth: All the states of the area should be committed to conduct their relations with one another in accordance with the aims and principles of the United Nations Charter particularly not to resort to the use of force and to resolve any differences among themselves through peaceful means. Fifth: Termination of the present state of belligerency in the area.

It is a mind-boggling exercise in intellectual gymnastics and self-delusion to assert that these statements made by President Sadat and repeated ad infinitum over the past four years are those of a person intent on deserting the Arab cause and the Palestinians. I ask everyone in this House to study these principles carefully and to tell me what more he could have demanded of the Israelis short of asking for total abolition of the state of Israel. We are told that Israel should deal with the more moderate factions in the Arab world. If these demands made by President Sadat were insufficient to satisfy the moderates what would have satisfied them? The honest people among us can only come up with the conclusion that President Sadat's crime was not that he did not demand enough of Israel but that he committed the unforgiveable-he accepted Israel's right to exist. That was his crime. That is why there has been dancing in the streets of Libya, Syria, Iraq and amongst the PLO in Lebanon.

President Sadat recognised that Egypt alone could not achieve all the principles enunciated in his speech to the Knesset and re-stated repeatedly. Egypt had the right to negotiate for only that territory that was previously Egyptian-the Sinai. This he did with such success that in April next year, if the peace process continues under President-elect Mubarak, all of the Sinai occupied by Israel in 1967 will be returned to Egyptian sovereignty. The West Bank, Gaza, the Golan and East Jerusalem had never been Egyptian territory and the Camp David Accords and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty envisaged that other Arab countries-Syria, Jordan, The Lebanon-and the Palestinians would be involved in a step by step process in resolving these problems. No one in his right mind would ever believe that after 30 years of war and a century of bitterness and hatred these matters could be resolved in a few weeks or a few months. The legacy of distrust will take time to dissolve but this process will not even start until other Arab nations follow President Sadat and indicate to Israel their willingness to recognise her right to exist.

Having just returned from Israel and Egypt, I am convinced that given the same encouragement, the same recognition and an end to a state of war between Israel and its Arab neighbours, peace will occur. Prime Minister Begin, the Israeli Cabinet and the people of Israel will surprise the world with what they will be prepared to concede for permanent peace. But Israel will not-President Sadat was the only Arab leader to recognise this fact-withdraw from territory or settlements that will make it easier for those Arab nations that wish to destroy Israel. The world will mourn the passing of one of the great men of this century. We can only hope and pray that there are other men of stature in the Middle East who will have the courage and the compassion to follow the magnificent example he set. If they do not, then the Middle East may well become the starting point for the greatest conflagration in history.

Before I conclude, I take the opportunity to say how shocked I was to learn also that John Woods, the young Australian First Secretary in Cairo, was seriously wounded in the assassination. I arrived in Cairo on Wednesday, 2 September, and was met by John Woods. He arranged my itinerary and accompanied me for the four days I was in Egypt. I could not have been more satisfied with the treatment I received and with the excellent program and briefing arranged by John Woods and the Embassy. John Woods is a first-class example of the intelligent and dedicated young diplomats who serve Australia superbly in similar outposts around the world. We are fortunate to have such men in our service. I deeply regret the constant impression given by some of our Press that diplomats have easy lives of luxury. Nothing could be further from the truth, particularly in Cairo. I can only wish John the speediest of recoveries and hope that he will soon be back with his charming wife, Gay.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Sub-Committee on the Middle East of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I want to add a few brief words of endorsement of all that has been said and particularly to respond spontaneously to what the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) has just said with regard to John Woods. So many of us in this House have seen this young man and it is such a blessing that we are not also commenting on his death today, because he was grievously wounded in the course of his duties. I speak on behalf of the Parliamentary Committee in paying tribute to him. Of course, I also pay tribute to Sadat and to his greatness as a man who brought peace and who desperately wanted support. I believe his country still wants support in the Sinai.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join other members of this House in expressing my sorrow and condolences to the Egyptian people on the death of their President, Anwar Sadat. I was fortunate enough to visit Egypt in 1974, four years after Nasser died, as a guest of the now defunct Arab Socialist Union. That was six months after the October 1973 war. We were able to observe at first hand the attempts by President Anwar Sadat to effect economic, social, welfare and industrial progress in Egypt. We were particularly impressed at that time by the efforts to industrialise, particularly the steel and textile industries. We observed the growing tendency to develop at least some progress towards an independent trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing I observed at that time was the great burden of escalating armament acquisition on the economy of a poor and struggling nation such as Egypt. However, I must say that, if economic reports that one reads are true, the economic effect of the open-door policy of Anwar Sadat has certainly not ensured that a flow-on of economic benefits has necessarily occurred to all those millions of poor peasants whom we observed struggling for subsistence along the Nile.

There is no question that Sadat was a great president of Egypt. It was Sadat who in October 1973 broke the stalemate that existed because of the then Israeli occupation of the Bar-Lev line on the eastern side of the Suez Canal. He disproved for all time the myth of Israeli invincibility which led to the movements in the peace front that have occurred since. Then there was in 1977 his historic visit to the Knesset which, of course, led to the Camp David agreements. Although the Camp David agreements brought peace settlements to both Egypt and Israel, some people tend to overlook that they were supposed to lead to a broader and lasting peace settlement involving at least Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank of the Jordan River and, then, the establishment of a Palestinian state. The point about all this is that, although there had been this substantial progress on the Egypt-Israeli front, there had not really been any progress with regard to the broader and long term issue of the provision of a homeland for the Palestinian people. I suggest that it was this deficiency in the Camp David Accords that eventually led to the destruction of Anwar Sadat, horrific and reprehensible as it was.

I conclude by observing that unless the attitude of the present Begin Government of Israel changes-we have seen at least 40 settlements established, and the annexation of some 30 per cent of Arab land, on the West Bank-great problems indeed will be experienced before the Camp David Accords are brought to a successful conclusion.

The problem for Anwar Sadat, which eventually led to his death, was that the more successful he became in the south, the more intransigence resulted from Israeli towards Syria, the Palestinians and in attacks on Lebanon in the north; thus the less chance there was of achieving a lasting and meaningful settlement in the north. That must be taken into account if the so-called Camp David Accords are ever to have any hope of producing not just an Egyptian-Israeli settlement but a broader settlement that will bring hope to the 2,500,000 people who happen to be Palestinians but are not allowed to return to their own homeland.

I join in mourning the President of Egypt, Anwar Sadat, and suggest that shocking, deplorable, reprehensible and unnecessary as his death last week was, it illustrates the inescapable conclusion that there will be no lasting peace in this troubled area of the world unless the rights of the Palestinian people are recognised and they receive justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion of condolence moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the death of Mohamed Anwar El Sadat. In the written history of mankind few human beings have ever drawn the sword and yet been prepared to sheath it short of defeat or victory on the field of battle. The fact that Anwar Sadat was one of the very few people who did that has undoubtedly guaranteed his place in history. However, what is important to remember is that this man, who grew to become an administrator, a soldier and later a great statesman, did not always believe that the road to peace in the Middle East rested on negotiation. In fact, it is worth noting that in 1970, prior to becoming President, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Don't ask me to make diplomatic relations with them.
He was referring to Israel-
Never. Never. Leave it to the coming generations to decide that, not me.

Yet, a few years later this man, appreciating the realities facing his nation, realising that the economic development, physical security and prosperity of his people could not be achieved through war, and knowing that the military establishment which was an important basis of his administration had received some satisfaction from its relative successes in the Yom Kippur war, believed that the time had come when steps could be taken towards initiating negotiations with Israel for a settlement in the Middle East. Incidentally, he was the first and only Arab statesman since 1948 to look seriously at negotiation as a way of solving the interminable problems of his nation and of the Middle East in general. He has now passed away, in tragic circumstances, and the future of the Middle East, which inevitably will involve the rest of mankind to some degree, requires quite clearly that countries such as Australia must continue to give to his successor at least the same degree of support as was given to Sadat to achieve a lasting settlement, because we do stand for peace; we do not support the concept of war as the best means for solving issues between nations.

For that reason, I think it appropriate that President Sadat's own words should be a fitting epitaph to what he stood for. In Washington, in 1979, at the signing of the peace accords with Israel, he said:
In all the steps I took I was not performing a personal mission. I was merely expressing the will of a nation. I am proud of my people and of belonging to them.
Today a new dawn is emerging out of the darkness of the past.
Let us work together until the day comes when they beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks.
I believe the Middle East will have peace one day, but it will be achieved only if there are more men like President Sadat. We indeed must mourn his passing.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE PATRICK JOHN KENNELLY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on 12 October of the Honourable Patrick John Kennelly, a senator for Victoria from 1953 to 1971 and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from 1956 to 1967; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service; and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

Pat Kennelly had a lifetime association with the Labor movement. Before entering the Commonwealth Parliament he served for 14 years in the Victorian Legislative Council as member for Melbourne West, eventually becoming leader of his party in that chamber. From 1945 to 1947 he was the Commissioner of Public Works and Minister in charge of Electrical Undertakings in the Labor Government. In 1945 he became the Federal Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, a position that he retained for eight years. In 1953 he was elected to the Senate.

During his 18 years as a senator he served on several parliamentary committees, including the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications and the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. He was also a Temporary Chairman of Committees from 1968. Senator Kennelly was Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from 1956 to 1967. Pat Kennelly served his nation, his State, the Senate, and the Labor movement with great distinction. He was unstinting in his support for his Labor ideals and a vigorous defender of his party's policies. Mr Speaker, when I entered Parliament in 1955 Pat Kennelly had, as you will recall, already won wide respect for his political skills, both within this Parliament and within the State of Victoria-indeed, the entire Labor movement.

Whilst Pat Kennelly served in the Senate and I in the House of Representatives, I remember him as embodying many of the qualities of the old time Labor movement which had won much respect throughout Australia. He will be remembered as one of the most influential, dedicated and colourful figures in the history of the Labor Party. He was, at the same time, a very significant figure in his own particular area of Melbourne, which he looked after and safeguarded with great zeal and with great energy over many long years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, I express the party's sadness at the death of Senator Pat Kennelly and extend its deep sympathies to his surviving family. Pat Kennelly was a notable personality and influence in the Labor movement for over half a century. He was, at various times, State Secretary of the party, a Minister in the Victorian Parliament, and Federal Secretary of the party while Ben Chifley was Prime Minister. He was elected to the Senate in 1953 and retired from politics in 1971. To recite his official positions is to give only the barest hint of the role he played in our party, often at the centre of action and equally as often behind the scenes, but always with effect. For Pat Kennelly, the Labor Party was his life. He became very close to the late John Cain senior, the former Labor Premier in Victoria. Nothing would have given the late Pat Kennelly greater pleasure in his last days than to know that the son of the man he admired so much was soon to follow in his father's footsteps.

SPEECH.PARA: As Federal Secretary of the party he had an especially happy and successful relationship with Ben Chifley, whom he rightly saw as one of the greatest men Australia has produced. The confidence Chifley had in him was a major factor in the harmonious and effective relationship between the extra-parliamentary party and the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party which existed at that time. Pat Kennelly was, however, his own man and a tough, hard fighter. He fought communist influence during the 1930s and 1940s. He would have no part of the industrial movement, however, and was a major actor in the great split in the party in the 1950s. The split was a tragedy for Kennelly, for the party and for Australia and, with the benefit of hindsight in times when passions have cooled, it is a shame that it ever had to occur.

Kennelly, a devout Catholic who never hid his faith under a bushel, bore with courage the bitter attacks on him from those who shared his faith. His personal courage was undeniable. He bore those outrageous slings and arrows of vilification with great fortitude, as with equal stoicism and inspiration he worked for the restoration of the fortunes of the Labor Party. He is remembered as the ultimate numbers man and as a king maker in the party. Certainly he was pugnacious and direct but he saw those traits as fundamentally in the interests of the party to which he had devoted a lifetime of service. We regret his passing. I restate that we extend our deepest sympathies to his surviving family members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of members of the National Country Party and in the absence of our leader, I support the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and extend our deepest personal sympathy to Mrs Kennelly and her two children. Pat Kennelly was certainly a remarkable parliamentarian. He served his country for a very long period of more than 32 years in two parliaments. In the uncompromising world of Labor politics, he won and held a number of senior party positions. It was not just in the Parliament however, that he achieved distinction. All of us remember the work he did with respect to Albert Park in Melbourne and his service as Chairman of the Albert Park Trust for more than 30 years. I believe it was he rather than anyone else who was responsible for the draining of the swamp that is now the Albert Park Lake. He was also a trustee of the Melbourne Cricket Ground, and for many years he campaigned against increased admission fees there.

SPEECH.PARA: Pat Kennelly's first parliamentary position was as a member of the Legislative Council for Melbourne West in the Victorian upper House. He was the Minister for Public Works in the Cain Government from 1945 to 1947. In the Australian Labor Party split of the early 1950s he lost his preselection but, less than a year later, in 1953, he won third place on the Victorian Senate ticket, beginning 18 years as a senator for Victoria. His whole life was devoted to the business of ALP politics. He will be remembered as an effective and tough debater who overcame his personal affliction, a stammer, in order to achieve considerable respect and admiration from all those who worked with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The death of Pat Kennelly ends an era of Australian politics and ends an era of Australian Labor Party politics. He was, essentially, the product of a radical Irish Catholic tradition which has played such an important part in the history of the Labor movement and in the development of Australian politics. The organisational and parliamentary positions that he held in the Labor Party, both in Victoria and federally, have already been placed on record. They need no elaboration from me. Many people have contemplated spending their life in politics, but few would have been prepared to enter politics as Pat Kennelly had to, with a physical handicap, a stammer, which he eventually turned into the ultimate political weapon. The stories of Pat Kennelly's use of his stammer and its effectiveness will live long in the memories of those who were the beneficiaries of it, and those who were at its receiving end. Many saw him wield it with a rich venom on many occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect he has to be the ultimate author of that well known statement which I believe is upheld in all political institutions and party rooms. He would say, as I recall him saying to me when I was a very young man in the Labor Party: 'Brother, you can have the arguments; give me the numbers any time'. Knowing Pat, having worked with him for many years and having loved him, I think he would want me to tell that story because he was never ashamed of it. He not only believed in that principle but also worked by it for all his political life.

Pat Kennelly had a number of loves. His family was clearly his first love. I do not know that I can enumerate the others. His religion was a major factor in his life. His involvement with his party, the Richmond Football Club and the Albert Park Trust were other aspects of his creativity. One only had to travel in the vicinity of Albert Park on a hot summer's afternoon in Melbourne to see the Chairman of the Trust moving the hoses around. In his position as Chairman he took on the Commonwealth government, the State government and anybody else who happened to disagree with his views on the development of this important recreational area. His love for the Richmond Football Club was for him rich and rewarding. When it won it was a matter of great jubilation, and when it lost it was an occasion for the deepest and saddest Irish melancholy I have ever beheld. For those who have to live in a political situation, from time to time we seek favours, and I remember saying to newly elected secretaries of the Labor Party: 'If you ever want a favour from Pat Kennelly always ring him on the Monday after Richmond has won, never on the Monday after it has lost'.

He was a devout and ardent believer in his religious faith. Perhaps one of the great tragedies of his life was that occasion on which the Labor Party split in 1955, and he was one of those who was deeply involved in that. When the history of those events is written, as I hope it will be written, there must be a place recorded in the annals of our history as a nation for the moral strength and courage of people such as Pat Kennelly and Arthur Calwell who not only believed in their Catholic faith and were prepared to uphold it in the face of the views of a somewhat turbulent archbishop, but also were prepared quietly, and with an enduring sense of nobility, to maintain it in the face of what often were very difficult and incredible political and religious pressures. He gave his family the same fierce loyalty and love that he gave to every aspect of his life. It will be a long time before the Labor Party, and indeed this Parliament, produces another character such as Pat Kennelly. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, I think his passing really records a passing in the history of the development of this nation and the history of the development of my own party. I know he would want me to say that now he is dead some of the better stories about Pat Kennelly can really be told. He was a man who was larger than life. He loved politics, the parliamentary institution and his party. He served this Parliament, the Victorian Parliament, and everything else he undertook with a fierce devotion. The Australian people will be sadder at his passing. We all have lost a vigorous, great and individual Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pat Kennelly was not just a great character, he was a great organiser as well. One of the things not mentioned so far is the very important part he played as the Federal Secretary of the Australian Labor Party during the years of the Chifley Government. He had a very close relationship with Ben Chifley and saw him in almost a paternal role. Ben Chifley was the only person he never called 'brother'. He called everybody else 'brother', but with Ben Chifley it was always 'the big fellah'. Perhaps more than anyone else it was Pat Kennelly who, in those very turbulent years after the war, helped to keep the party organisation together until it fell apart in the 1950s at the time of the split. He was in the Victorian Legislative Council until he lost the preselection ballot for Melbourne West in 1952 in his own home territory. It is true that he had a lifelong interest in voting systems-that has been commented on before-but in that election he lost in his own area following a terrible bereavement within his own family. But in 1953, in the face of very fierce opposition from the then faction which controlled the Labor Party in Victoria, he won a State-wide Victorian ballot to gain preselection for the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Pat Kennelly was born in 1900. If we look in Who's Who and in the Parliamentary Handbook we will see that they always state 1903, but he actually was born in 1900. I think he may have had a prophetic insight that the Labor Party might impose age limitations for candidates in the future and he thought it sensible perhaps to have two or three years up his sleeve. I understand that precedent has been followed in some other cases. It is a great pity that he refused to write his memoirs or even to be interviewed for a biography. I know that the National Library of Australia wanted to interview him and it should have interviewed him, but he said 'No'. He would never put his experiences on tape or paper because, characteristically, he said that he did not want to say or record anything, even if it was published after his death, that would hurt the children of anybody he criticised.

Although he played the game pretty tough there was a very sentimental side to him. He was passionately attached to his family, as has been said before. Two children predeceased him but he was very devoted to his wife Jess and his two children, Ron and Joan. He was a great talent scout. He liked to encourage people. He was a great believer in the gospel of 'horses for courses'. In many cases the people he promoted, pushed and encouraged were people who were, temperamentally, quite unlike himself and with backgrounds quite unlike his own. He was a genuine recogniser and promoter of talent. He played a very important role, for example, in securing back in 1960 the election as Deputy Leader of the Labor Party of Gough Whitlam, a man who was very different temperamentally, but Pat Kennelly recognised his very real quality. With him an era in Australian politics ends. He was a great man, a man of his time and one whom we will always remember with great affection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Armitage Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the remarks about the late Pat Kennelly as I am one of those fortunate to have enjoyed his friendship and assistance, to which I will refer in a few moments. As has been mentioned, he was an associate of the greats in the Australian Labor Party, including Ben Chifley; Reg Downing, a former Attorney-General in New South Wales who is still living in Goulburn; Joe Cahill; John Cain; Jack Ferguson, former Federal President of the Labor Party and State President in New South Wales, unfortunately deceased; Abie McAlpine, also Federal President of the party; and W. R. Colbourne, a former General Secretary. I could go on. I thought the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) described Pat Kennelly very aptly. We always enjoyed his humor and his impediment which made him an even greater personality than he might have been.

SPEECH.PARA: I can recollect receiving assistance from him when my electorate of Chifley was established in 1968. It was to be called the electorate of Grose. I would undoubtedly have been called the fat member. There would have been no doubt about that, having an electorate of that name. I made an appeal, which failed, asking that the electorate be called Chifley. In this case-this was done perfectly correctly as it should have been-Pat Kennelly approached the Minister of the time. He said: 'There are two names in this redistribution of boundaries which I want to be preserved. One is the name of Scullin and the other is the name of Chifley'. He approached the then Minister for the Interior who is now the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and put that proposition to the Minister. As a result it was agreed that Pat would move an amendment in the Senate and that when it came back to the House of Representatives it would be accepted in the House of Representatives. That is how I became the member for Chifley and not the member for Grose. That was the sort of thing which Pat could do very effectively and utterly and completely legally without there being any question of impropriety as has been suggested in relation to some other methods which have been used in the past.

I say once again that I wish to be associated with the remarks about Pat Kennelly. Whenever he met me he would say: 'N-n-n-now, are you l-l-looking after that el-electorate of Chifley'. Pat was a very great man. I will always feel honoured to have known him and to have been friendly with him. For those reasons I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other honourable members in extending condolences to the family of Pat Kennelly. Pat took a very deep interest in my role as Federal Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in the late 1960s. I did not know him very well before that time, but he felt it incumbent upon him to give me a lot of advice in the late 1960s and early 1970s. As the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) pointed out, he had one greater love than the Labor Party and that was the Richmond Football Club. On occasions when he approached me during those years I was not quite sure whether he was going to give me a bit of advice about the Labor Party or secure the clearance of some of the best footballers from South Australia. He was really a very important person in the Labor movement. It is interesting that the State of Victoria keeps producing people like Pat Kennelly, although in the future I suspect that this will be less likely.

SPEECH.PARA: He loved to be at the height of the feuds which were going on. As one recalls, in the history of the Labor Party the late 1960s were not all that friendly a time. I think that if he were alive and active at the moment he would prefer to be a member of the Liberal Party in Victoria, sorting out its problems. After he retired from politics he continued to visit Canberra and to give us the advice which he thought was necessary. As far as I am concerned, the one outstanding feature of everything that Pat Kennelly did or said was that in any advice he ever gave me, in any decision he ever made, or in anything with which I knew he was associated, he always acted on the basis that he hoped it would do something positive to get Labor into power. I do not believe that he ever made a decision, a comment or a speech in which he felt he may have been doing something which would have extended the period for which Labor would be in opposition. In that respect he was a very positive person. It pained him greatly that the split in the Labor Party during the 1950s took so long to be settled. I am sure that he will be missed. On Thursday afternoon we will bear witness to the hundreds and hundreds of friends that Pat Kennelly has throughout Australia as a result of the outstanding contribution that he made in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period
reducing the number of street posting boxes
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Federal Government to discontinue the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) will further reduce the prospects of young Australians for employment, and place additional undue hardship on the unemployed.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government continue the CYSS program and support the voluntary Community Management Committees in their valuable work to assist the unemployed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Recognising the high youth unemployment in Australia and the overall effectiveness of the C.Y.S.S. Programme in equipping young people with skills necessary for their place in the workforce.
We strongly oppose the close of the Community Youth Support Scheme Programme and call you, the Minister, to reinstate this programme immediately.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to effect the above.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham,Mr Peacock and Mr Street.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Geelong respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.
We, the people of the Geelong Community, request that the Community Youth Support Schemes (C.Y.S.S.) throughout Australia, be restored.

We particularly ask that the Geelong and Corio C.Y.S.S Schemes be ongoing after the proposed closure date, 31st October, as they have contributed much to our community. C.Y.S.S. has provided interests, support, opportunities for service, a voice in the community and job training for its thousands of participants over the past four years in Geelong.
C.Y.S.S. is an important part of our community and we as a community, support it especially in times of high youth unemployment that seriously affects our region.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Colac and District (Vic), respectfully expressing our greatest disappointment and deepest felt concern at the announced cessation of funding to Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS).
The CYSS in Colac is a most valuable and well utilised community resource, vital in the continuing personal and social development of our unemployed youth.

Since the beginning of the Colac CYSS in 1978, 400 young unemployed have participated in the programme. Currently the programme caters for some 40 unemployed youth, many of whom cannot be catered for by any existing or proposed government or community programme.

As Australians deeply concerned for the future of unemployed youth in our community, your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse it's decision to abolish CYSS Projects, and continue to fund this invaluable community resource.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
