PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the imposition of a sales tax on printed material such as books and newspapers is contrary to the spirit of open access to information and the liberal dissemination of ideas in a free society.

We are especially concerned in a time, of general cutbacks in funds that this unjust impost will increase the cost of children's books and so seriously limit the material available to the young: its effects on already overstrained library budgets will be detrimental to the educational well-being of this country.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That your honourable House will exempt books and other printed material (e.g. newspapers) from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully ask the Government to abandon its proposed sales tax on books, magazines and journals as we are totally opposed to the idea of a tax on information, knowledge and education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5% on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Shack and Mr Viner.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the 2 1/2% sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers is a tax on knowledge, a tax on information and a tax on culture.
2. That freedom can be protected in a democratic society only if its citizens have access to information and ideas through books, magazines and newspapers.

3. That it is in early life that a tase for books and the habit of reading in the home are most easily acquired. The ability of families to provide the stimulus which books offer will be limited by the higher cost imposed by the tax.
4. That the development of the Australian publishing industry is based on a vigorous consumer demand. Such a tax can inhibit the industry and create unemployment among its workers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will reconsider the proposed tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Federal Government should provide sufficient funds for State Education Systems that will ensure the maintenance of the current high quality of Education and the continuance of educational services to all children in a happy and stress free environment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley and Mr Viner.

PETITION.TITLE: Aspect House for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally.
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to ASPECT HOUSE, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed.
3. ASPECT HOUSE is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding.

4. ASPECT HOUSE is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary suburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community.
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected.
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett and Mr Hodgman.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives asembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia being employed in the automotive products industry respectfully showeth:
1. That the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. That if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proprosals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr N. A. Brown and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross and Mr Humphreys.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a Sales Tax of 17 1/2% on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the people who have signed this petition ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howe and Dr Jenkins.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lloyd and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Aid to Polish Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that recent events in Poland are of such seriousness as to justify Australia's direct involvement in attempts to relieve tension there.
Your petitioners note that food shortages are a major cause of civil unrest.
Your petitioners further note that Australia has the capacity to make direct donations of food at short notice.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;
That the Federal Government make the Polish Government an immediate and substantial offer of food aid.
And your petitioners as in dury bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Federal Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the recent report of the World Council of Churches team which visited Australia, June 15 to July 3, 1981, emphasises the central importance of land rights to the Aboriginal people.
And noting that all attempts by white Australians to manage Aboriginal affairs for them have failed.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Federal Government will accept its responsibility and use its powers under the Constitution to override racist state legislation, particularly to provide Land Rights with freehold title, and

That in addition the Government fulfil its stated policy of self-determination and self-management for Aboriginal people, by funding all housing, health, education, legal, employment strategy and welfare matters concerning Aboriginal people directly through Aboriginal Community-based Community-controlled organisations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The students, staff and community of Preston Institute of Technology, strongly protest against your government's decision to impose a sales tax on books.

2. Books play a vital role in society, in both education and culture. As the Prime Minister himself said in a speech earlier this year, books have been a major vehicle for human communication for centuries. A tax on books is therefore a tax on communication and on knowledge.

3. In the history of Australia, no government has ever taxed or dutied books, because it has been realised that such taxes are an affront in a civilised society. The British government recognised this when it zero-rated books for value-added tax in the U.K.
4. It should be noted that Dr Harold Bell, in his Annual Budget Review to the Institute of Directors in Australia, has already deplored the application of the new sales tax to books.
5. It is the urgent wish of this community that your Government reconsiders the place of books in the Budget structure, and allows them to continue to be sales-tax exempt.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) There be no Sales Tax on books.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian Tertiary Institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students as foreshadowed in the proposals of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions announced on 30th April 1981, would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

2. the proposed tightening of eligibility criteria for T.E.A.S. will, if implemented force many students to discontinue their studies and will deter many people from undertaking tertiary study in the future.

3. the proposed loans scheme to substitute for tertiary education assistance under T.E.A.S. will, if introduced, offer no long-term relief from financial difficulties and will pressure future students into giving undue regard in selecting courses to the latters' duration and the prospects for later remuneration which these courses imply.

4. the imposition of tuition fees for second and higher degrees will, if carried through, deter many persons willing and able to undertake further study from doing so, and will therefore further reduce the postgraduate and research activities of our tertiary institutions.

5. those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the tertiary education system would be most severely affected by the proposals as outlined on 30th April 1981.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) eligibility criteria for T.E.A.S. not be further restricted but be extended; and that the level of T.E.A.S. for independent allowance be increased to 120% of the Henderson Poverty Line.
(ii) the proposed loans scheme not be introduced.
(iii) tuition fees not be introduced for any course of for any category of students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned concerned citizens respectfully showeth:

That local authorities throughout Australia are appalled at the recently announced Commonwealth Government allocation of a mere $628m for roads in 1980-81.There is extreme disappointment at both the level of total Commonwealth funding for all road categories and at the specific allocation for the local roads category.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That road funding arrangements for 1980-81 to 1982-83 reach at least a total of $2,200m over the triennium.
2. That the Commonwealth maintain an active financial interest in the funding of all categories of roads.
3. That the Commonwealth ensure that a proportion of the funds flows through the States earmarked for Local Government purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decrease in Federal Government funding for health, transfer of Commonwealth responsibility to the States, application of the 'user' pay principle to health services and encouragement of private business and profits in the health sphere will inevitably lead to a downgrading of health services and increasing health risks among people who cannot afford health insurance or private payment of doctors and hospitals.

That the cuts in Federal Government spending resulting from the recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government functions (Razor Gang) will lead to an increase in unemployment and a general deterioration in community services and living standards.
Therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. The Government continue Commonwealth funding of health services at an improved, and certainly not a lesser, level than that operating prior to September 1, 1981.
2. That recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government Functions (Razor Gang) be not proceeded with.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed New Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we believe that Australia's constitution is undemocratic and should be replaced by a democratic constitution, particularly as regards the new standard for regulation of Vitamin and Mineral Supplements.
We believe:
1. This legislation will curb our individual freedom to care for our own health according to need, environment, climate, etc.
2. These substances have proven their efficacy in maintaining health rather than destroying it and should remain freely available.
3. Why curb these substances while other noxious and toxic substances are freely available to the obvious thorough detriment of our society-e.g. commercial alcohol and tobacco.

This new constitution should be drafted at a representative directly elected people's convention following extensive public debate, and then put to a referendum of the people. The petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament, as a matter of urgency, will help to promote such public debate and will arrange for the holding of such a people's convention and referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount.
2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60 per cent.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that: The Parliament should act-
1. To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises.
2. To increase the spouse rebate from $830 to $1,342 per year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

(a) That residents of densely populated suburbs in the vicinity of the airport and residents of other suburbs in the flight path of international and domestic jets are experiencing an unreasonable degree of aircraft noise.
(b) Further, than these same residents will be subjected to prolonged bouts of such aircraft noise if a decision is taken to extend the curfew at both the domestic and international airports.
(c) That this decision has been forshadowed on two occasions as follows:

(i) In Submissions to the Public Hearing held by the Public Works Committee of this Parliament in regard to Stage One-Redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport; these submissions proposed an extension of the existing curfew when the new runway is completed (approx. 1986). This proposal received the full support of the Queensland Government.
(ii) TAA's request for an extended curfew to coincide with the introduction of the Airbus.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will refuse to extend the existing curfew and will reconsider its siting plans for the proposed new runway so as to minimise noise pollution over high density suburbs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Chile
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many people have left Chile because of political, religious and economic persecution, and that these people would face imprisonment, and political and economic harassment if forced to return.
That statements by Amnesty International and the London-based Chilean Committee for Human Rights reveal there has been no abatement of political, religious and economic persecution in Chile.

That Australia, as a signatory to the 1951 United Nations' Convention and the 1967 United Nations' Protocol on refugees, adopt and endorse the principles for refugee status espoused by the legal adviser to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Dr Guy Goodwin-Gill.

That many Chileans presently in Australia, including two refugee status applicants, Fernando Del Carmen Cerda Labarca and Pedro Jose Belmar Aguilera, clearly fall within the parameters of Dr Goodwin-Gill's definition.
We urge the government to grant refugee status to these two refugees.
And Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory, the present retrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

3. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
4. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
5. The deregulation of trading hours would force small retail companies out of business.
6. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should: Ensure that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory continue to be regulated by Ordinance as happened in the past.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the continued cutback of our local community health centre will lead to a decline in the health status of our community. We appreciate their varied services, which include baby health services, counselling, physiotherapy, community nurses, preventative services, etc.

We believe that the community health programme will cut rising health costs by supporting people in their homes. Therefore, we support the basic health care and prevention carried out by our health centre.
We request that adequate funding is provided for the continuation of and expansion of these valuable services to our community.
Your Petitioners therefore, humbly pray that your Honourable House consider this Petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government.

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1978 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Subsidy Payments for Nursing Home Residents
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The majority of Pensioners in Nursing Homes are currently not receiving any significant rebate after all fees and laundry expenses are paid. This situation does not allow for a basically acceptable quality of life and undermines the dignity of people who are unable to fend for themselves. We call upon the Federal Government to investigate the plight of these people and guarantee them at least the opportunity to financially support their own basic needs.

2. When Residents of Nursing Homes go to stay with Friends or Relatives for short periods (e.g. weekends) they are compelled to pay the Commonwealth subsidy for the period of their absence. This expense is obviously not able to be met by the majority of Nursing Home Residents or their Friends and Relatives. The result is that people who would benefit from short periods away from the Nursing Home are restricted to its confines because they are not in the position to pay for their release. This situation causes emotional trauma on festive occasions such as Christmas and Birthdays.

We feel this is a hardship that should not be borne by Nursing Home Residents and call on the Federal Government to relax its policy regarding subsidy payments for Nursing Home Residents on short leave.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Government policy on subsidy payments for Nursing Home Residents on short leave, be relaxed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programs will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is increasing Interest Rates on Home Mortgage Loans without due concern for its impact on the general community and ask that the Government reconsider its attitude to Low and Middle income earners.

Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on Home Mortgage Loans which cause Financial, Social and Psychological pressures on families.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are extremely concerned at the Government's intention to cease to fund the Institute of Early Childhood Development at Kew, Victoria should that Institute not amalgamate with some other Institute or College of Advanced Education. We feel that due to the specialised nature of Early Childhood Education the IECD should be preserved as a separate specialist campus.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will continue to provide funds for the IECD so that it may continue as a specialist teaching campus in its own right.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Highway Warning Devices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
That highway safety flares be allowed as warning devices where vehicles are in a hazardous position on a highway. Also we wish to use them for our own safety.
These road safety devices are widely used in Canada and the United States by highway patrols, and police units along with ordinary motorists in these countries.

We know if they are allowed to be used here in Australia, they will save lives especially at night. A study by Professor Merrill J. Allan Phd, OD. et al, 'the effect of flares and triangular distress signals on highway traffic' proves that highway flares are by far the most effective distress signal for a disabled vehicle. This study was from Indiana University, Department of Optometry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of citizens of Victoria showeth that the Institute of Early Childhood Development must not be amalgamated with any other Victorian College, but must remain independent and autonomous. Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives ensures that the Institute of Early Childhood Development remains independent and autonomous.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Humble Petition of the Electors of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth that because of the Sales Tax of 17 per cent imposed on Pet Foods, people will no longer be able to afford the ever increasing cost of Pet Food. This will lead to more Animals being abandoned. Many Old Age Pensioners will be deprived for their only source of companionship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned Members of the Bundaberg State High School Parents and Citizens Association respectfully showeth:

That retention of the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian Community.

That serious concern has been generated by the decision within the Schools Commission guidelines, to cut funds to the general recurrent and capital programmes by re-allocation to transition; the decision not to implement the School Improvement programme; and the divisiveness created between Government and Non-Government Schools due to increases of $43.25m to Non-Government Schools while Government Schools funds have not increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray.

That the Government will reverse these decisions-will retain the Schools Commission and Curriculum Development Centre in their original forms; retain the Schools Commission proposals including recurrent and capital funding proposals; basket of services and the Schools Improvement Programme.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of citizens of the Geelong region in the State of Victoria respectfully request the Federal Parliament not to accept the I.A.C. recommendations on the motor vehicle industry as they would, if accepted, have a disasterous economic effect on the region and would create massive unemployment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) condemns the inhumane conduct of the Indonesian forces which are illegally occupying Portuguese East Timor in defiance of a United Nations resolution;
(2) deplores the cruelty of the occupying forces as disclosed in a recent report from the Timorese Administration to the Indonesian Government in Jakarta; and

(3) calls on the Indonesian Government to acknowledge its failure to break the will and spirit of the people of East Timor, to withdraw its forces and to hand over to a United Nations force to allow the people of East Timor the right of self-determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) left Australia on 8 October to attend the funeral of the late President Sadat and to participate in trade discussions in South Korea. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) will act as Minister for Trade and Resources until Mr Anthony returns on 16 October. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) left Australia on 1 October to participate in discussions overseas. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) will act as Minister for Housing and Construction until Mr McVeigh returns on 17 October.

—My question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, concerns the balance of payments statistics for the September quarter released today, which show a dramatic deterioration with a record quarterly total deficit of $1.1 billion and a record quarterly current account deficit of $2.3 billion. I ask: In view of the fact that the Budget strategy was for a surplus on net private foreign exchange transactions to account for 45 per cent of the targeted money supply growth this year, and that so far no such surplus exists-indeed, there is a substantial deficit-does the Treasurer agree that his Budget strategy is rapidly falling apart? What action does he intend to take to rectify this situation and so ensure that the absence of money supply growth from external sources does not result in a massive credit squeeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome that question from the honourable member for Gellibrand as it gives me an opportunity of saying that I do not for a moment accept, as does the honourable member, that because of those developments on the external account the Budget strategy is in any way falling apart or in disarray. The Budget strategy was fundamentally to control inflation by the effective use, amongst other things, of firm monetary policy. The fact is that a smaller surplus of private sector foreign exchange transactions, so far from making that task more difficult, makes that task a little more easy to achieve. The effect of that situation is that it will not be necessary to place such severe limits on domestic credit creation that might have been the case if the volume of private sector exchange transactions was as great as the honourable gentleman suggests that the Budget assumed them to be.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a much larger current account deficit during the first three months of this financial year than we thought likely when the Budget was put together. The volume of private capital inflow has been about the same in the September quarter 1981 as it was in the September quarter 1980. But exports have been a lot weaker, partly due to a continuing coal strike in Queensland, the effects of a shipping dispute which has affected many of the ports around Australia, and also extremely sluggish world trade conditions. The volume of imports has continued to grow very rapidly. Because of strong domestic economic growth in Australia, as anybody with an elementary understanding of these things would know, the first thing that happens when one gets sustained economy recovery is that imports rise very sharply. That is one of the reasons why the current account deficit has been larger than we anticipated.

I repeat that these assumptions that are made when Budgets are put together are nothing more than the best calculations and predictions that can be made at the time. They are subject to great volatility and great change. The important thing to remember is that if private capital inflow turns out to be lower than one anticipates it means that other policy adjustments can be made which can still make it possible to achieve quite easily the money supply target we have in mind and thus achieve the Budget strategy, which is a reduction in inflation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon The Rt Hon Sir W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Will he confirm that there is and has long been an irreversible commitment by the Government to the view that increases of sales tax are an essential and inseparable ingredient in reducing the burden on the community of personal income taxation, both at the threshold and in each of the three taxation groups? Will he assure the House and the nation that, consistent with my pleas, the reduction of personal income tax will take place not later than 1 July 1982? Will he assure the House that the national Government will follow its own judgment and not that of the bureaucrats?
—I do not think I can do much more than repeat what the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech, which I and I think he have repeated on other occasions.
—I am referring to what you said on Friday night.

—That, as I understood it, was repeating what the Treasurer had said in his Budget Speech. That is, quite plainly the indirect tax changes announced in this last Budget enhance our capacity for income tax changes at some time in the future, providing economic circumstances are right for them.

—I refer the Prime Minister to this morning's Sydney Morning Herald article by Mr Graham Williams. Is the Prime Minister aware that this article quotes calculations by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association pointing out that a single income family with two dependent children is paying up to 81 per cent more tax in real terms than six years ago? Is the Prime Minister also aware that this same set of calculations shows that a one-income family on average weekly earnings is paying $26 a week more in tax than it would have had the 1975 tax system been retained? Is it a fact that in 1975 the Prime Minister promised to reduce the tax burden? How does that promise compare with the reality of the vastly increased tax burden for one-income families, who will also be paying an extra $4 a week in sales taxes if the proposed increases are not abandoned? When can the Australian people expect action from this Government on real tax reform rather than the promise of a tax cut every time the Prime Minister's leadership looks shaky?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a very quick look at that article and, as the honourable gentleman would expect, I am having a very careful analysis made of the many calculations contained in it. I do not have all those calculations to supply to the honourable gentleman, but when I do have them I will supply them to him and to the House. However, a couple of comments can be made. Firstly, the article makes comparisons about percentage rises in tax without looking sufficiently at the after-tax income position of people at different levels of income. Obviously if real incomes are rising, as they have been, particularly over the past 12 months or 18 months, then percentages of taxation will rise. Those sorts of straight comparisons do not really give anybody a very careful indication of just where true comparisons lie.

ANSWER.PARA: One statistic that does stick out very much on this issue is that the total amount of money taken out of the Australian community as a percentage of the gross national product by the Commonwealth Government by way of both taxation and borrowings in 1981-82, according to the Budget, will be a lower figure than the volume so taken by the Commonwealth government out of the Australian community as a percentage of GDP in terms of both taxation and borrowings in the Budget of the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr O'Keefe proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Communications-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will have to re-frame his question. I will not call on the Minister for Communications to say whether a rumour is about.

—Was the Minister for Industrial Relations aware in advance of the offer made by the Public Service Board last Friday of a $23 a week increase to tradesmen? If so, did he express disapproval of the offer to be made? Was the offer based upon the principle of comparative wage justice which this Government has previously rejected? If not, was it made on the basis of the principle of a fair comparability of rates which the Government has recently discovered? Will the Minister explain to the House the difference between these two principles? Finally, does the Minister regard the increases proposed by the Public Service Board as consistent with what it would euphemistically describe as its wages policy?

—The Public Service Board is an independent body under the provisions of the Public Service Act. Under that Act it has the responsibility of handling wage claims for employees within the Public Service. The Public Service Board made its offer on the basis of a survey and on the basis of the principle of fair comparability.
—Were you aware of the offer?
—I was kept informed of the work being done by the Board and of the offer it proposed to make in its independent capacity under the Public Service Act.
—I ask the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that Telecom Australia and Australia Post may be transferred to private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that there is an obligation on the Government to provide services which cannot reasonably be provided by the private sector. However, Telecom Australia and Australia Post are both major statutory authorities which have quite significant involvement in areas in which private enterprise is already involved. It is the objective of the Government to provide the best possible facilities, which are socially and geographically essential in both the postal and telecommunications areas. Whether this occurs as a result of a change in the overall structure of Telecom or otherwise will be largely a matter for consideration of recommendations by the committee now constituted under Mr Jim Davidson which is inquiring into Telecom. Until that report is received, of course, no major changes or decisions will be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: The consequences of the report, however, will be significantly designed not to prejudice necessary services to the Australian public. The concept that the Government will follow will certainly have in mind the greatest efficiency of resources, yet it will also marry that requirement with a concern that there should be provided to all citizens, whether they live in the remote and isolated areas of Australia or in the more rapidly growing centres of population, the services which are rightly expected of a communications authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I preface it by reminding the Minister of his references earlier this session to the lack of expedition on the part of his predecessor in the matter of deregistration proceedings against the Builders Labourers Federation and the lack of adequate consultation with industry employers in this matter. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that on 25 September he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it is . . . the intention of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors . . . to make a similar application to the Federal Court shortly . . . The other major industry organisation-the Master Builders' Federation of Australia-is now examining how best to play an appropriate role in the proceedings, including whether it also becomes an applicant.

Have either of those organisations, as of this morning, lodged such applications? Finally, have these organisations conveyed to the Minister their dissatisfaction with his handling of the matter and is this reflected in the delay in their lodging of such applications?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the third question is no. The employer bodies have not lodged their application as of today. That is being handled by their solicitors and their counsel in a way which the honourable member would well understand. I expect that the applications will be lodged when they have been prepared and when they are ready to lodge them.

—I ask the Minister for Transport: What means is the Government taking to bring to an end the delay to an enormous tonnage of shipping in Australian ports? I ask this question because there is now the possibility of the Panama Canal being closed to our beef exports to the United States of America.
—The honourable gentleman has asked his question. He is now giving information. I call the Minister for Transport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been concerned about the continuing waterfront and maritime dispute that has been plaguing the waterfront in Australia for most of this year. Indeed, there has not been a day during this year in which there has not been a major dispute on the waterfront in this country. The Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for National Development and Energy, the Minister for Industrial Relations and I met with the shipowners about three weeks ago, and there have been meetings between the shipowners and the maritime unions.

ANSWER.PARA: On 7 October the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Minister for National Development and Energy and I had a meeting with representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the maritime unions to discuss the whole range of problems that have been at the root of the industrial trouble that is causing enormous losses to Australian export trade. As a result of those discussions I am reasonably confident that the maritime unions will endeavour to bring to an end the ban that has applied on the flag of convenience ships. They were reminded, of course, that the Government acted in good faith last year to set up, under the chairmanship of Sir John Crawford, a joint committee between the Australian shipowners and the maritime unions to bring a report to the Government on the revitalisation of the Australian shipping industry. We expect to receive that report by the end of October.

One would have thought that the maritime unions and the industry generally would have endeavoured to bring about a reasonable environment in which the Government could give consideration to any recommendations that might flow from that report. Quite obviously, the Australian community generally, apart from the industries concerned, has suffered greatly as a result of these continuing disputes. I hope that the leaders of the unions and the ACTU will act with responsibility as a result of the discussions that we have had.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs that in answering a question from the honourable member for Deakin in this House on 27 May he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is no doubt whatsoever that the Government's economic policies are working.
He went on to refer to the April Australian Bureau of Statistics figures and stated that the figures:
. . . show a continuation of the underlying strength and increase in the employment situation in this country.

As these statements were made in relation to an annual employment growth rate of 146,000 in March and 197,300 in April, will the Minister now reverse his assessment of the labour market situation and the effectiveness of the Government's economic policies in the light of subsequent ABS statistics which show, firstly, increases in unemployment in each of the three months to September and, secondly, a persistent fall in the annual employment growth rate to a figure of less than 110,000 during the month of August?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member is prepared to use annual figures I am quite happy to accommodate him in that regard. He asks me to state what the present situation is on annual figures. I will proceed to do so with respect to unemployment. In the year to September 1981 there was a fall of 5,700 so far as full time unemployment was concerned. This is the lowest rate of unemployment for September for four years on a full time unemployment basis. With respect to those seeking part time employment, the number was likewise the lowest figure for four years. The honourable member may be also well aware of the fact that in relation to youth unemployment there was, again, a very substantial drop in the year-on-year figures. There was a fall of some 24 per cent in the number of 15 to 19 year olds seeking their first jobs. With respect to all teenagers seeking full time employment there was a drop of some 18 per cent. The position with respect to the overall employment situation is encouraging as it has been for the last two years. There has, in fact, been a growth of some 5 per cent in employment in Australia which is extremely healthy.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, as I have said on occasions before, if the Australian Labor Party wished to make a substantial and real contribution to the growth of employment and the reduction of unemployment in Australia it could do a number of things. The main thing that it can do, by virtue of its presumed influence with the trade union movement, is to encourage the trade union movement to lessen the extravagant wage demands which are continuing to be made in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, absolute humbug.

—With respect to those who scoff, as the honourable member for Melbourne is now scoffing, I ask them to take out and print in large letters the remarks made by the honourable member for Wills only a couple of months ago in a radio broadcast when he said-I entirely agree with the remarks, they go very close to the root of the unemployment problem in Australia-that if wages explode too fast then there is a problem. The honourable member said there is no doubt that if wages do explode too quickly that can have adverse economic impacts on unemployment. He can certainly say that again. If the Labor Party wants to make a substantial contribution to reducing unemployment it can make a contribution to lessening the demands of the trade union movement, or sections of it, in making extravagant wage demands which can only be destructive of this economy and, in particular, destructive of job opportunities in this country.

—Would the Minister for Defence advise how successful the school cadet scheme has been since its reintroduction and if and when it is contemplated that eventually young ladies may be introduced into the school cadet scheme? The Minister has received representations on lowering the admission age of certain cadets to 12 years of age when those cadets will turn 13 years of age in the year of joining the cadets. Is the Minister prepared to accept this change in age?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know of the honourable gentleman's sustained interest in the school cadets. I suppose we have all got to have an interest in something. Some other honourable members' interests are more active than the honourable gentleman's and more diverse. But I do treat the honourable gentleman's question seriously. No, there is no proposal to lower the age for entry into the school cadets. This is done, in general terms, on sound medical advice.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can illustrate the proposition very quickly. I strongly suspect that my honourable and distinguished friend, the honourable member for Petrie, was a lot larger at the age of 12 than, say, was the honourable member for Wills at the age of 12, and larger in a great variety of respects. It is a simple proposition. If somebody wants to see a double entendre in that observation then his mean mind can do so. The acceptance, formally, of young ladies into the school cadets remains under consideration. The honourable gentleman will acknowledge that there are some difficulties. The Department is, in terms of its priorities, addressing itself to those difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, in relation to the first question asked by my honourable friend, the response to the reintroduction by the Government of the school cadet program has, in my view, been outstanding. I thank the parents of the cadets associated. In particular, I take this opportunity of thanking, most warmly, the schools that have responded very generously to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry and I refer to the 3 October edition of Business Review Weekly. Did the Minister agree to the payment of $6,400 to the Australian Dairy Corporation by the former Chairman of the Corporation, Mr Webster, in June of last year? If so, where does this payment leave both the Auditor-General's and police inquiries into some of Mr Webster's transactions as Chairman? Does the payment exonerate Mr Webster? If not, why did he make it and, indeed, was this the understanding on which he made it? If the Minister did not assent to the payment, was it made with the authority of the Dairy Corporation Board? Did the Minister try to stop it?

—I will be making a statement in the House on all of these matters when reports have been brought down and the work on those reports is completed. In respect of this part of the reports, I will have a look at the honourable member's question and ensure that an answer is given.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer and refer to statements made by him that the increases in sales tax will 'increase the potential for reductions in personal income tax'. Is it not true that the whole of the revenue derived from the increases in sales tax will be spent in this current financial year on the services of government and that in fact we will finish the financial year some $146m in deficit? I therefore ask: How does the increase in sales tax increase the potential for cuts in direct taxes? Will that potential be created only by further increases in sales tax and other taxes or alternatively, and one would hope preferably, by reductions in government expenditure not yet announced?

—I think the answer to the honourable gentleman's question, which is a fair one, is that the potential that I was referring to in the Budget Speech pays regard to the fact that there are part-year and full-year effects of the sales tax measures. This year's Budget, of course, has the part-year effect from the night of the Budget in respect of some of the sales tax measures and from only 1 January in respect of the extension of the sales tax measures to items presently not covered by wholesale sales tax. So if one looks at it in a straight mathematic sense, one must look at the full year gain to the revenue that the new sales tax measures will yield-that represents $800m to $900m-versus about $400m-do not hold me to that figure; I would like to check it-in the current year. I think the honourable member should also be reminded that this year, for the first year for, I think, 12 years, there is a full additional payday which represents an addition to our expenditures of over one per cent in real terms, about $450m. So without in any way trying to speculate about the quantum of any taxation relief that might be available in future years, when I referred to scope and potential for personal tax reductions in future years, I very much had in mind, as the Government had in mind, the fact that with the full year effect of the sales tax measures our capacity to move in other areas would be greater given the right economic circumstances. Overwhelmingly we would have, through those sales tax measures, a more appropriate taxation mix in our community.

—How does the Prime Minister propose to reduce the added tax burden of this Government's wide ranging increases in sales tax on low income earners, particularly pensioners whose incomes are too low to be subject to personal income tax?

—In many quite specific ways the Government has sought to assist the lowest income people within the Australian community and the adjustments that were announced in the Budget on rental assistance to single pensioners paying rent are an example of the ways in which government policies are designed to get to areas of greatest hardship. In a full year the additional cost of those changed rental subsidy arrangements is, I am reminded by the Treasurer, about $50m in that one area alone. So obviously one has to look at the overall ambit of government policies in order to make judgments about those people on the lowest levels of income and the kind of support that we are able to offer.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of industrial action in the Australian vehicle manufacturing industry at present occuring in Victoria? Is he aware of any special circumstances which will affect the development of this industry? Was the union involved party to an advertising campaign aimed at influencing the Government to support the high level of tariff protection presently afforded the industry?
—Has the Minister heard the commencement of the question?
—He is not here.
—My question was directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I consider it a matter affecting industry.
—The Minister for Industry and Commerce is not in the chamber. I call the honourable member for Capricornia.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industry inform the House of any results of the meat species testing program, including, firstly, the numbers of firms and individuals detected substituting buffalo for other meats and, secondly, the identities of firms or individuals involved in meat substitution and/or the use of adulterated meat for domestic consumption, export or both? Finally, can he say whether any of the adulterated meat was buffalo and whether some of this meat has been exported?

—I will treat the first part of the question, because it would require me to give names, as being on notice and give the honourable member a considered reply. I do not think-unless something has occurred in my two-week absence-that there has been any positive discovery of buffalo meat in any of the meat substitution problems. Nevertheless, I will check to see whether those remarks are accurate and I will confirm them for the honourable member.

—I refer the Minister for Communications to his announcement on 23 September that Mr Malcolm King would be a member of the Government's committee of inquiry into the extent to which private enterprise could be more widely involved in the provision of telecommunications services. Was Mr King employed by the Government during 1980 and 1981 as a consultant to inquire into the respective roles of Telecom Australia and the private sector in the provision of telecommunications equipment? Did his consultancy cost $17,500? Was Mr King deputy general manager of CSR Ltd and a director between 1972 and 1980? Is CSR a member of the Business Telecommunications Services Pty Ltd consortium which is seeking a share of the private sector equity in the proposed domestic communications satellite? Did the original interdepartmental committee proposal on the satellite recommend that BTS Ltd be a participant in that private sector equity? Does Mr King still hold 2,952 CSR shares? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement by Mr E. E. Payne, Acting Secretary of his Department, in reply to questions at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing that he did not know whether CSR had any interests in the provision of telecommunications equipment? Under these circumstances is it a fact that CSR does have a clear interest in the provision of telecommunications equipment and services? Will the Minister, therefore, acknowledge that Mr Payne's professed ignorance of this fact is implausible? Finally, will the Minister acknowledge that Mr King's consultancy and membership of the Government committee involved him in a clear conflict between his private interests and his public duty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deplore the habit of the Leader of the Opposition of trying to debunk individuals and besmirch their names. As far as Mr Malcolm King is concerned, the normal procedure, I understand, would have been for this question to be put on the Notice Paper. However, because it has been asked I believe it proper and appropriate that I answer it now, without notice. I have no idea what shareholding Mr King has in CSR. If the figures are as the Leader of the Opposition suggests, I believe that would have no bearing at all on the policies of CSR, given the size of its present equity holding. It is true that Mr King was formerly Deputy General Manager of CSR, but he was not an employee of CSR at any time while he was an employee of the Government. In other words, he was no longer Deputy General Manager of CSR at the time when he was acting as a consultant to the Department of Communications giving advice on the degree to which there might be some broadening of the private sector's involvement in the provision of telecommunication facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of Mr King's employment as a consultant, he has provided a series of advisings to the Department. However, it has been thought appropriate, given the nature of the inquiry now to be conducted by Mr Davidson, that Mr King's report and his recommendations should be absorbed in that wider inquiry. It is felt, given the circumstances of the inquiry and the fact that it is necessary to ensure that there be a completely dispassionate assessment of the area in which there can be a maximisation of the funding of these telecommunications services and the extent to which the private sector might be involved, that it was better for Mr King's final report to be a matter for consideration by the Davidson inquiry. Of course, Mr King is a member of that inquiring group. As far as the Government is concerned, I am not aware of any conflict of interest which Mr King suffers and which would in any way prejudice him or the advisings he has made available to the Government. I believe that the involvement of CSR in BTS or in any other company involved in communications has no continued relationship to Mr King or to his employment as a consultant by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of industrial action in the Australian vehicle manufacturing industry, especially in Victoria? Was the union involved party to an advertising campaign aimed at influencing the Government to support the present high level of tariff protection afforded to the vehicle manufacturing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that, at a time when there has been a significant improvement in the passenger motor vehicle market, when compared with the position last year, there should be continuing industrial problems in the industry. I assume that the honourable gentleman is in fact referring to the dispute at the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd which certainly is seriously--
—Do we know that? Was that in the ad?

—I make the assumption that he is referring to that dispute at the Ford Motor Co. which in fact is seriously impacting on that firm's capacity to meet the strong demand for its products at present. It is a dispute about wages and it is a matter for the Ford Motor Co. to resolve. As I understand it and as I recall, it has not sought the support of the Government, and the Government certainly has not taken any initiative with respect to the dispute which, I emphasise again, is a matter for the management of the Ford Motor Co. to resolve. The honourable gentleman, for reasons that I well understand, seeks to enjoin in the context of a question concerning industrial disputes a matter which could be regarded as controversial on either side of the House. Of course, that is the question of tariffs. Whilst I understand the reason why the honourable gentleman was prompted to raise the question, he will equally understand the reasons why I frankly decline to be drawn into that dialogue ahead of the Government's decision which I have indicated to the House will start to be taken, in terms of papers before the Cabinet, towards the end of October or early November.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to reports, particularly by Australian non-governmental aid agencies, concerning the present situation in East Timor. Does the Minister have any information concerning these reports which relate to brutality, torture and murder of East Timorese civilians by Indonesian forces? Has the Government made any representations to or in any other way contacted the Indonesian Government about these reports? If not, will the Minister assure the House that he will investigate them and report fully to the House as soon as possible?

—I am aware of reports of the kind that the honourable member has referred to. I have not seen a copy of the alleged report myself, nor have I had a chance to make a judgment as to its authenticity. But I have instructed the Australian Embassy in Jakarta to seek a reaction from the Indonesian authorities on this and other allegations which have recently appeared in the Australian Press.

—Has the Minister for the Capital Territory received any representations in recent times about speed limits on certain highways in the Australian Capital Territory? What is the outcome of those representations?

—I did receive representations about the speed limit on a certain highway, which was 80 kilometres an hour. It is now to be 100 kilometres an hour. I am not sure whether it will assist the honourable member in a forthcoming court appearance, but I think it is a more realistic speed limit than the one previously in force.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that a number of copies of the South West Tasmania resources survey report prepared at a cost of $460,000 to the Federal and Tasmanian governments were received by his Department in mid-August this year? Is it a fact that the report says that no statement of environmental effects has been prepared for the Tasmanian Government-favoured Gordon above Olga Rivers scheme, and that neither the social and economic costs and benefits of the Hydro-Electric Commission proposals nor alternatives to water power to meet the demands for power in the next century have been adequately or independently investigated? Is it also a fact that a submission prepared by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment concerning South West Tasmania and presented to Cabinet last month was based on the result of this report? If the answer to any of these questions is yes, how can the Minister explain reports in which a spokesman for the Minister stated that the Minister had not seen the report and that he would release it when he received it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Government has made a substantial contribution to the State of Tasmania in the conduct of the survey to which the honourable gentleman has referred. But when the last amount of funding was made available it was made quite clear by my colleague the present Minister for Administrative Services that the latest allocation of funds for that project was made on the understanding that Tasmania would be prepared to match the amount, to complete the survey and to publish the working papers and the final summary report. It is true that a copy of that report has been provided informally to me and to my Department, but as yet the final report has not been officially submitted to me.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated to the former Tasmanian Minister that, if he wished to issue that report, it was a matter for his consideration once the report was made available to us. But as yet that report has not been officially submitted in accordance with the recommendations. When it is, I see no difficulty in its being published and I see no difficulty in the Tasmanians carrying out their responsibilities under the terms of the arrangement previously entered into when the final instalment was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long have you had the report?

—It is not relevant to question how long the copy that has been forwarded to us for preliminary study has been with us because it has not been officially submitted to us. When that occurs the Tasmanians and we, if they wish us to publish it jointly, will proceed immediately to its publication.

—I inform the House of the absence of the Chairman of Committees, Mr Millar, who is on parliamentary business overseas. I have requested the honourable member for Wakefield, Mr Giles, to carry out the duties of Chairman of Committees during Mr Millar's absence.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Trade and Resources)
