DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 52 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, I present the annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service for 1980-81.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Australian Biological Resources Study Advisory Committee report for 1979-80. I seek leave to make a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first published report of the Advisory Committee, which was appointed in December 1978. It describes the activities undertaken by the Committee in its first full year of operation. Honourable members will recall that the Australian Biological Resources Study is a program to describe and name the Australian flora and fauna and to gather information on their taxonomy and distribution. It is co-ordinated by the Bureau of Flora and Fauna, which is now part of the Environment Division of my Department. The Government increased its support for the ABRS program last year and again this year because it is convinced of the importance and the urgency of increasing our knowledge of the flora and fauna, not only for their great scientific interest but also because the knowledge is badly needed for economic and conservation purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: This 1980 report deals with recommendations rather than with results, but in 1981 we have begun to see a very significant output from the ABRS program. On 22 August I had the opportunity of attending the thirteenth International Botanical Congress in Sydney to launch the first major project of ABRS, the first volume of the new Flora of Australia. This work will comprise more than 50 volumes describing all Australian plant species. The first volume has been highly acclaimed by many of the distinguished overseas and Australian botanists attending the Congress. The project is proving to be a most successful exercise in Commonwealth-State co-operation. Already over 20 State government botanists are collaborating with the Bureau of Flora and Fauna in writing the flora. When one considers that we know about 20,000 different species of flowering plants in Australia-and are still discovering new ones-one will realise that such co-operation is necessary to what is in every sense a national project. It is a tremendous task, but it is essential to have all our flora and fauna properly described and named-a project that will require government support for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Biological Resources Study was established in 1973 by the Whitlam Labor Government to fill the pressing need to identify properly Australia's fauna and flora. As the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) has said, the Advisory Committee of the Study was appointed in December 1978 by the present Government. With the increased interest in the environment in the late 1960s and early 1970s taxonomy-that is, the naming of organisms-became an essential part of the study of the environment. The objectives of the Australian Biological Resources Study are set out in the report as follows: To co-ordinate all work aimed at collecting, describing, and classifying Australian plants and animals and determining their distributions; to maintain comprehensive information on and provide professional evaluation of national taxonomic collections; to establish priorities; to establish and maintain a national network of biotaxonomic data banks; to record and collate information on flora and fauna collected when geographical areas have been studied or surveyed in any way; and, lastly, to co-ordinate publication of a systematic series of flora and fauna handbooks and to prepare co-ordinating index volumes.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding for this program under the previous Labor Government was progressively increased until 1975-76 when the Australian Biological Resources Study received $806,000 in 1981 values. The present Government saw no need to maintain funding, so it slashed this figure in half in the 1976-77 Budget and then continued to cut funding in real terms until this financial year. These cuts were disastrous. This is illustrated by the Advisory Committee's comment in the 1979-80 annual report, which states:

The task of setting preferred objectives was made difficult by the urgent need to increase knowledge of almost all components of the flora and fauna. Bearing in mind the funds available ($192 000 in 1979-80), and the resources available in the Bureau of Flora and Fauna for the processing of grant proposals, the Committee invited applications within very restricted fields.

The advisory committee must have had a major influence on the Government because the Government decided to treble funding in 1980-81, and this year has raised fundings back to the Whitlam levels. The Minister, in his speech a moment ago, stated:

The Government . . . is convinced of the importance of the urgency of increasing our knowledge of the flora and fauna, not only for their great scientific interest but also because the knowledge is badly needed for economic and for conservation purposes.

It is obvious that with increasing stresses on the environment from resource development, urbanisation, primary industry and so on, the knowledge produced by the Australian Biological Resources Study will be ever more important. The Australian Labor Party firmly supports this essential program and we call upon the Government to continue present levels of funding in real terms.

DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN CONTROL OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to Australia's independence by foreign control of high technology industries.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the field of high technology Australia is strictly an occupied territory. Australia is reverting to the colonial model of technology transfer which we adopted in the nineteenth century. In 1835 the inhabitants of Melbourne traded a primary resource-their land and water-in exchange for beads, mirrors and tomahawks offered by John Batman, and 146 years later things have not changed very much. Australians are still selling our natural resources-things dug up out of the ground-in return for manufactured goods and increasingly sophisticated services which we are increasingly unable or unwilling to provide for ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we are not satisfied now with beads, tomahawks and mirrors-we have more sophisticated technology than that-we still seem to be unwilling and unable to provide the necessary intellectual investment that ensures that we are producing these goods ourselves. Unlike the Swedes, the Japanese or the Americans we have pulled back from ownership, control or even, in many cases, participation in high technology industries. Only Canada, of all technologically advanced nations, and New Zealand, of nations somewhat technologically less advanced, have as bad a record as Australia in respect of the foreign control of high technology industries.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics report Foreign Ownership and Control in Manufacturing Industry 1972-73, published in October 1976, is unfortunately the most recent analysis available of foreign ownership. It is overwhelmingly probable that the situation has deteriorated since then. Given the policies of the Fraser Government there is no way in which Australia could have increased its control of its own economy. We are still continuing to sell out the farm. The figures indicate how far the Government has gone in permitting the selling out of the national interest. The figures in the report relate to value added, that is the total value of all goods and services added as part of the production process. The tables give both the percentage of foreign ownership, that is the paid up value of the market shares and, even more important, the degree of foreign control. Even an equity control of only 25 per cent of shares in a single pair of foreign hands can ensure control.

I refer honourable members to the table. This is the order in which the Australian Standard Industrial Classification appears: Plastics material, synthetic resins and rubbers, $69m value added, foreign ownership 79.5 per cent, effective foreign control 94.3 per cent; organic industrial chemicals n.e.c.-not elsewhere classified-$46.3m value added, 71.1 per cent foreign ownership, foreign control 75.2 per cent; total basic chemicals $292.7m value added, 58 per cent foreign ownership, 78 per cent foreign control; pharmaceutical and veterinary products $140.8m value added, 76.3 per cent foreign ownership, foreign control 77.8 per cent; pesticides and agricultural chemicals $18.7m value added, 72.5 per cent foreign ownership, 85.7 per cent foreign control; cosmetic and toilet preparations $61.6 value added, 89.1 per cent foreign ownership, 91 per cent foreign control; petroleum refining, foreign ownership 90.8 per cent, and the degree of foreign control is not given in this table but one might assume it to be 100 per cent; rolling, drawing and extruding of aluminium 91.2 per cent foreign control; motor vehicles, perhaps the most significant figure of all, $424.6m value added, foreign ownership 98.8 per cent-the 1.2 per cent outstanding presumably being the Australian equity holding in Australian Motor Industries Ltd-foreign control 99.8 per cent; photographic goods, optical instruments and film processing 57.8 per cent foreign control; television, radios and electronic equipment, 69.3 per cent foreign control; construction and earth moving equipment-something we would think that within Australia we ought to have control of ourselves-59.9 per cent foreign control; and so it goes on.

The 1972-73 document does not give the figure for foreign control of the computing industry. I have asked specifically in a question on notice that we be given that figure because we do not know the precise amount of value added in computers in Australia but we do know of the industry within Australia that 92.7 per cent of purchases are from foreign sources. I draw the attention of honourable members to the remarks of the Governor-General in his introduction to the booklet Technological Change-Impact of Information Technology 1981. He wrote:

The 1960s and 1970s in Australia saw advanced technology, in the form of information processing equipment, become a major import. This type of import, it is said, could well become Australia's largest in the decade of the 1980s unless concrete steps are taken very soon. Information technology giving facts, and often more than that, 'interpretation' and 'analyses', has become a major tool in the further development and even the maintenance of an industrial capacity in western societies. Australia is rapidly becoming totally dependent on imports for the supply of its information technology. Increasingly it is said, the technology being imported requires specialised overseas training for its maintenance and even the supply of spare parts from overseas. The situation is said to exist where it is either economically or technically essential for some sub-assemblies to be repaired overseas.

This raises questions of policy; I point only to the problems which this generates for a society dependent in many vital and sensitive areas on operating computers. What if sources of supply are threatened in an international crisis? This directs attention to the vulnerability of a computerised society, about which the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Kirby, has recently spoken. He has referred to a Swedish government report which I have seen and which examines some aspects of vulnerability. There is the threat of acts of war-capture the computer centres, says the report, and you capture the society which depends on them; there is the vulnerability to acts of terrorism to which such installations are susceptible and which have occurred in parts of Europe. There are the risks from disasters and accidents. The dislocation of sensitive systems can have adverse effects on production and operating systems and the Swedish report points to the need to devise strategies to prevent excessive functional and geographic concentration of sensitive and vulnerable data bases. As a society becomes increasingly dependent in its public and private operations on computers, these concerns assume increasing importance.

It is extraordinary and shaming to recollect that Australia was one of the earliest nations into the computer industry and then we abandoned any decisive role in it. Australia produced one of the earliest first-generation computers, originally called CSIRO Mark I Automatic Computer, later renamed CSIRAC. It was probably the fourth or fifth stored-program computer in the world. CSIRAC was designed in 1947 by Maston Beard and Trevor Pearcey, who both worked for CSIRO's Division of Radio Physics in Sydney, had its first test run in 1949 and was fully operational by early 1951. At that stage only the United States of America and Great Britain were running their own computers. CSIRAC was used by the CSIRO until 1956, when it was transferred to the University of Melbourne and remained in use until 1964, when it was handed over to the Science Museum of Victoria, which hid it away in a store.

A conscious political decision was made not to develop Australia's potential for designing and manufacturing mainframe computers and a decision was made to buy that equipment off the shelf. The CSIRO preferred to put its funds into radio astronomy and rain making experiments. If a choice had to be made, that choice had a rational basis. The tragedy was that short-sightedness by the Menzies Government in starving research and development forced a choice to be made and Australia lost an opportunity to take a leading role in the development of the computer industry. Even worse, Australia has been forced into total dependence on overseas computer suppliers, mostly from the United States and Japan. For every $1 spent in Australia on computer equipment, $14 is spent on imports. No other technologically advanced nation has such an unfavourable ratio of imports to local supplies.

There is some local manufacture of components by AWA and Philips and several firms have designed and assembled their own small mainframe computers for specialised use: For example, Hartley Computer Applications Pty Ltd of Brisbane and Computer Manufacture and Design Pty Ltd of Melbourne. Electronics Research Australia Pty Ltd is now moving from Canberra to Brisbane. There is also D. D. Webster Electronics Pty Ltd of Melbourne. Fairchild and National Semiconductor, two of the Silicon Valley giants, both set up small facilities in Victoria for making components in the 1960s. Both were closed after the 25 per cent tariff cuts of 1973. In 1981 National Semiconductor-Natsemi-was offered by the Fraser Government a $19m inducement to carry out a feasibility study into setting up a silicon wafer fabrication plant, not a chip plant, in Canberra. Trevor Pearcey, the father of computing in Australia, has called that 'a tragic mistake'.

This is exactly the same story as we had with General Motors-Holden's Ltd. We once had, believe it or not, something called 'Australia's own car'. But by the 1980s Australian motor manufacture was essentially derivative, even parasitic, with engines designed in Europe and bodies designed in Japan. Sir Laurence Harnett's book Big Wheels and Little Wheels has described how the indigenous Australian motor industry was absorbed into the global industry.

Australia is being deindustrialised by the Fraser Government, which has undermined much of our technological capacity by a quisling-like approach which asserts that Australia's best interests are served by taking a subordinate role in a global economy. If this policy were taken to extremes, as seems likely, Australia would be confined to the supply of raw materials. Small nations would be converted into completely sterile and derivative societies marked by the downgrading of intellectual capacity and competence. The work force would become progressively deskilled and dominated by the performance of routine service jobs by a servile army of wood and water joeys.
Honourable members will be relieved to hear that I do not intend inflicting my excruciating French on the House, but President Mitterrand stated recently:
France's future lies in the exploration of unsuspected layers of our intelligence.

That is a very profound remark. I do not think the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) would be prepared to make such a remark here. In Australia we have the persistent, deliberate, the quisling-like winding down of our national intellectual capacity. This is the Government which has cut back in real terms on research and development. In a world context Australia is already in an extraordinarily vulnerable position in high technology areas where the commanding heights-computers, plastics, pharmaceuticals, petrol and petrochemicals, electronics, motor manufacturing-are completely in foreign hands. The fact that we are merely standing still in the areas of science and technology where other nations-the United States of America, Japan, USSR, West Germany, France, Italy and even Great Britain-are spending increasing amounts of their annual budgets represents an effective decline for us. We are standing still on a descending escalator.

In the recent Budget only 0.9 per cent of the total government outlays are on research and development, a figure which is admittedly higher than it was at its nadir in 1977-78, when it was 0.7 per cent. But in terms of world competition we are not doing well. I think that largely reflects the bullying attitude which the Treasury takes towards the Department of Science and Technology. Science and Technology is inevitably an interventionist department. It has to be. The only basis for its existence is its view that its activities cannot rely on market forces alone. It was said that the Minister's moderate success, on which I congratulate him, in making sure that the Budget was not an utter disaster for research and development was a victory like Dunkirk. It was not a victory like Stalingrad or El Alamein; at least Science and Technology survived and may survive to fight again. Under a Labor government this Department will be fighting very vigorously.

We have to recognise that the most important element in the economies of the nations with the highest living standards is education. We cannot allow our educational base to wind down and expect that we can develop and expand at the same time. A country cannot contract in this area and expand its output simultaneously. I hope that the Government will recognise the extreme importance of Australia rejecting its overwhelming dependence on foreign controlled technology and that it will try to follow the advice of Sir John McEwen and buy back the farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very interesting speech. We always have interesting speeches from the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). He made some interesting observations and a number of criticisms, but he did not make very many constructive suggestions. He did not say what we should be doing about the problem. He did make a comment, an accusation, that the Fraser Government was assisting to deindustrialise Australia. That is absolute nonsense. The worst time for deindustrialisation of Australia occurred between 1972 and 1975, when the Labor Government made such a dreadful mess of our economy. We had a downturn for some years after that. We are now going up again because-
—Have you compared the 1981 figures with 1955?

—The honourable member for Lalor has a magnificent voice. I have heard many good voices on parade grounds around the world and I can see him as a first-class sergeant major. Perhaps he has missed his vocation. I heard the honourable member in silence and I would be very grateful if he would use that magnificent voice outside this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The main aim of the Government has been to improve the economy of Australia. In that we are succeeding magnificently. We have now undone the damage which was caused by the Labor Government's policies between 1972 and 1975. Only by having a strong economic base will we improve our high technology industries. Of course, a great deal has to be done. Of course we have weaknesses in the structure. But that is because of history as much as anything else. It was interesting to hear the honourable member's comments on the car industry in Australia. A Labor government under Chifley invited the General Motors Corporation to take over Australia's indigenous car industry. He stated also that two firms from Silicon Valley had set up in Victoria and they had shut down after the Labor Government's disastrous 25 per cent across the board tariff cuts-

TALK.START.PARA: —Leaving nothing behind.

—Leaving nothing behind. That was because of the short-sighted policies of the Labor Government. This Government has a strong commitment to the development of greater Australian investment in high technology industries. There are several reasons for this. Firstly, many of our industries are directly competing with overseas countries and we must match production facilities in Australia. Secondly, all the projections indicate that on a world basis a number of high technology industrial areas are likely to experience very strong growth. Biotechnology, which I know is of great interest to the honourable member for Lalor, is one of those. I will mention that later. Thirdly, many high technology Australian companies can sell on a world market rather than a local one. I will mention some cases of that. Fourthly-this is important-history shows that technological advances generally lead to improved standards of living, better working conditions and more jobs. That is what the Government's policies are aiming for at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: As one of the smaller industrialised countries we are naturally a net importer of technology. It is interesting that Japan and Germany are often quoted as successful, industrial technological countries. One of the factors contributing to their success has been their readiness to go out and import technology, and to buy patents and licences from other countries. They have spent six times more money taking in patents and licences than they have actually sold. They have succeeded. We have to do the same thing. As the honourable member knows, an inquiry into the whole patent system which will decide what is best for Australia is continuing at the moment. That is the aim of that inquiry. We cannot view high technology industries just as an internal matter. It is a world-wide situation. Where there is ready access to patents and licences and freedom to exchange ideas we will prosper. We have to look outwards, and import technology where it is necessary. We cannot always restrict our industries to Australian inventions. It would be very nice if we could. We must concentrate on the things in which we have an economic advantage. There are many of those. Reprocessing of our raw materials is just one of them.

The Government's economic policy is aimed at establishing an environment which is favourable for business. That is a very different policy from that which was pursued by the Labor Government. It must be favourable to business prosperity to improve our international competitiveness; those are two very important things. In this environment, many Australian firms have been able to succeed on world markets with products and processes which are innovative and technically sophisticated. The importance of overall economic activity in the promotion of high technology industries can be seen in some overseas figures. In the United States of America in 1969 200 technology-based companies went public. When the United States economy faced a downturn in 1974, only four high technology companies went public. That vindicates the Government's emphasis on improving economic conditions as a whole. A strong Australian economy certainly will assure that high technology industries will be created and will thrive in this country.

I mention two industries which I visited in the last week or so. One of them was in Sydney-the Nucleus group of companies-a most interesting Australian group of companies, which specialises in the manufacture and distribution of high technology products, advanced medical products, diagnostic ultra-sound equipment and heart stimulators, most of them very complex, micro-electronic products. It employs about 800 people world wide and it has annual sales of about $50m. It is interesting to see where its sales are. Thirty per cent of its sales are in the United States of America, 33 per cent in Europe, 23 per cent in Australia and 8 per cent in Asia. Most of its sales in Asia are to Japan. We are exporting high technology, electronic medical devices to Japan. That is what can be done when an Australian company goes out without protection and tariff barriers. This year the Nucleus group of companies spent about $3m on research and development. A good deal of that has come from the industrial research and development grants administered by my Department. It is one of the greatest success stories of those grants.

The second company I visited was F. H. Faulding and Co. Ltd in Adelaide. It has just signed agreements with two major overseas companies to export $50m worth of an antibiotic drug which it makes called erithomycin. It has perfected a process which overcame a problem which had prevented the general use of this drug. I repeat that its sales in this drug in the next year will be $50m. It is interesting to note that that company told me that the company in the United States, to whom it had given a licence to sell its product, has 800 highly qualified salesmen all, I believe, with academic degrees going round the States to sell its products in the next couple of weeks. That just shows what two companies can do-one in a high technology micro-electronic world and the other in the medical world-by innovativeness, research and development and by get up and go. This has been made possible by the Government's policies to encourage such activities, to encourage industrial research and development, to encourage industries which are efficient and innovative, internationally competitive and export oriented. Of course, not every company in Australia is as good as that but there are examples which the rest of Australia could well follow.

Our manufacturing industry will certainly expand as will our mineral and energy-based industries. The manufacturing industry needs to embrace new technologies if it is to improve its productivity and create new products. We must have policies and programs designed to give Australian industries the capability to evaluate foreign technology to ensure that we are in a position to use the technology which best suits our requirements. Against this background, Australia's foreign investment policy has a positive effect on new technology. The policy does this in two ways: These are by facilitating the introduction of advanced overseas technology and by providing the stimulus for Australian industry to compete technologically with overseas firms. In considering foreign investment proposals, the Government expects significant economic benefits and/or significant equity before approvals are granted. I believe the Foreign Investment Review Board is doing a good job in this field.

As the honourable member for Lalor knows, takeovers of existing Australian businesses come within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Where local technology is an important asset of the target business, the proposed takeover is examined very carefully indeed. The Government must ensure that the potential benefits to Australia of this technology transfer are maximised. In proposals to establish new high technology firms, the Government will ensure Ausralian participation and a share of the benefits from the use of that technology. This is a fairly slow process. It is speeding up now and there are very encouraging signs. Foreign investment policies recognise that national economies are interdependent and that there needs to be a transfer of technology across national boundaries. We cannot afford to re-invent the wheel. The honourable member for Lalor well knows that the Government's policy is one of 50 per cent Australian ownership where this is possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the motor industry?

—As I said, the rundown of the Australian motor industry was started by the Labor Government. Australia cannot afford to re-invent the wheel. There are limits to the extent to which Australia is able to develop its own technology. We must allow imported technology through foreign investment if we are to benefit from world-wide technological developments. The Government has been encouraging industrial research and development. We have spent $50m this year. We are trying to persuade private industry to spend much more money on industrial research and development. Our ratio of government to private industry contribution is in inverse proportion to that of the rest of the world-it is about 70 to 80 per cent government and 20 to 30 per cent industry.
—I support you very strongly there.

—We must try to persuade industry-I welcome the support of the honourable member for Lalor-to increase vastly its investment in industrial research and development. I have issued a challenge to Australian industry to double its expenditure on industrial research and development by the end of this decade. I would very much welcome the support of the honourable member for Lalor and the Opposition in this area. I am sure I will have it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other ways in which we are helping to support high technology industries. The special public interest projects administered by my Department under the Industrial Research and Development Grants Act are one way. The bionic ear, which has possibilities for a large export market, is one of the most exciting of these ways. It must be realised that all the considerations which surround the import and transfer of technology are very complex. They are not ones that a government can handle. They have to be handled by private enterprise selecting the technology most suitable for its needs and then proceeding to negotiate the terms and conditions. The major justification for government intervention is when restrictions are placed on the use of technology which adversely affect other government policies.

If I had time, I would speak about venture capital, which is a very important part of the whole problem. The Government's policies will ensure an environment which is conducive to the development of high technology industries. We must use all our resources, including our most important resource, the Australian people. We have a highly educated work force. We must put people to work as much as possible in high technology industries. The Government has created policies and programs to ensure that Australia is in a position to develop and use new technologies. We have an economic environment which will lead to the establishment of new high technology industries. I mentioned two, the Nucleus group of companies and F. H. Faulding and Co. Ltd. There is no doubt that the result will be an improvement in the overall strength of industry, particularly its economic capacity. This will enable industry to control its own destiny and to take advantage of research developments which best suit Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the excellent speech by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). This Government lacks any concept of what constitutes the long term national interest in the area of science and technology. It has failed to promote the establishment of Australian based and Australian owned high technology industries and to change Australia's adverse position on technology transfer. We have a long tradition of avoiding the challenge of developing our own indigenous technology and we have relied upon technology transfer. The sell-out to foreign investment by post-war conservative governments has cost us dearly. The distribution of wealth and income in our community is becoming more lopsided every day. On the other hand, we could follow the path of many European countries, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Malaysia and develop our own corporations with minimal dependence on foreign equity. We could use our strength as a major supplier of raw material to strike a better bargain from foreign investment proposals. We have failed to do so. We could insist on the transfer of technology to Australian control as the price for exploitation of our resources. We could insist on more processing, research and development being done in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening to research and development in this country? The figures speak for themselves. Between 1973-74 and 1976-77 gross expenditure on research and development in Australia as a percentage of gross domestic product fell from 1.29 per cent to 0.97 per cent, a reduction of 25 per cent. The government sector increased in importance as a source of funds, providing 77 per cent of the total in 1976-77, compared with 63 per cent in 1973-74. The business enterprise sector's contribution dropped dramatically from providing 35 per cent of total expenditure in 1973-74 to only 19 per cent in 1976-77. Manpower employed in research and development by private enterprise fell by 40 per cent in 1976-77 when compared with 1973-74. Australia, the poor little rich country, has fallen almost to the bottom of the list of technologically advanced nations in expenditure on research and development with a mere 0.9 per cent of Budget outlays this year. The private sector has made an absurdly small contribution.

In terms of patents taken out each year per million people, which is the standard international test, or per $US1 billion of gross domestic product Australia ranks eighteeenth and twenty-first respectively out of 25 advanced nations. It is a disgrace. R. B. McKern in an article entitled 'Foreign Investment and Technology Transfer in the Australian Mining Industry'-the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) ought to have dwelt on this a little more than he did-points out:

It is significant that Australia's largest mining company, BHP, well equipped with its own research and technical facilities, found it essential to form a partnership with an overseas source of technology and experience (Esso).

That related to the exploitation of the Bass Strait oil and gas fields. In another case, he considered that Amax Exploration (Australia) Inc. could not find local partners to take up even the proposed 25 per cent Australian equity for its bauxite project in the Kimberleys because 'The problem was not so much a shortage of Australian capital, but rather a shortage of suitable investment vehicles: enterprises equipped with the financial, technical, marketing and entrepreneurial skills to undertake direct investment'. The substantial government supported scientific and technical resources in Australia are not geared to assist the generation of such locally owned investment vehicles. Again, this contrasts strongly with the policies of many other developing and developed nations where government funds are often spent in paying for duplication of foreign technology which could have been bought through a direct foreign investment bargain simply to avoid the constraints associated with the importation of that technology in a foreign investment package. It is a pity the Minister did not dwell on that aspect. He might point that out when he talks to the Foreign Investment Review Board. We are so far behind the rest of the world that we are getting lonely.

With regard to market access, McKern considered that the serious delays which the two major bauxite and alumina projects planned by Australian companies encountered could be largely attributed to the inability to secure long term contracts without the equity participation of one of the alumina majors. Whilst government supported marketing agencies such as the Australian Wheat Board and the International Wool Secretariat have been established in the agricultural products field, no similar organisation has been established in the minerals area, even though Australia has enjoyed world dominance in minerals such as rutile, tantalite, zircon and monazite.

Technology transfer is a vital but ignored consideration in the evaluation of foreign investment. Norwegian involvement in deep sea oil exploration provides a good example of how foreign investment can be used to nurture a new domestic industry. I say briefly to the Minister that at least the Norwegian Government through statutory oil corporation, invited American oil companies to take out tenement leases in its sector of the North Sea, but one of the conditions which it laid down was that it had to transfer its technology. The first rig drilling in Russian waters was a Norwegian rig with a Norwegian crew. It is about time we did a little bit better than we are doing.

The aluminium industry provides a classic example in Australia, particularly after the First World War. Proposals to produce aluminium in Australia had to be shelved because of the ease with which international aluminium cartels could destroy the new local industry. Even when World War II and a world-wide shortage of aluminium forced Commonwealth involvement in aluminium production, the design and construction of a plant was delayed by the refusal of Alcoa of Australia Ltd to provide or transfer its technology. It was left, in fact, to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, with British help, to develop an Australian designed Bayer-Hall process. An aluminium commission was formed in 1944 and extensive surveys of bauxite reserves were undertaken. A plant was finally commissioned in 1955 after five years of construction at Bell Bay. The plant was operated jointly by the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments for several years before it was sold to two transnational corporations. Why did we feel obliged to transfer our technology when ultimately this country has been held at ransom ever since 1955? It is a national scandal. It is a national disgrace. It is a shocking indictment of Australia's foreign investment policies.

The same sorry story could be told about the mineral sands industry where wartime development could have provided the basis of an industry producing titanium dioxide pigment. The nature of other recent foreign investment proposals ought to concern this Government. Almost every day large, transnational oil companies are swallowing up our mineral and energy resources, whether the alternatives be coal or oil shale. Oil shale technology and oil from coal technology are obviously areas where Australia could develop a key industry if the Government were, in fact, to lead the way. What makes the situation worse is that the Federal Government seems unconcerned about the long term implications of foreign dominance of high technology and industrial research development in Australia.

Recent examples of the lack of interest of the Minister for Science and Environment and particularly the Government in promoting high technology are the Starlab project and the Interscan project. In the case of Starlab the Government has allowed a French company to provide a small sum of money needed for the feasibility study rather than provide the funds itself. It is interesting to note that Matra S.L. is one of the French companies that the Mitterrand Government is proposing to nationalise. We therefore have a situation where the French Government would be paying for the feasibility study on behalf of the Australian Government. The sell out of technology, in particular, and foreign investment has reached appalling proportions in this country. It is time that this Government put its act together. The potential in Australia of technology, science and research is enormous. What the country really needs in a depressed economic market is more government initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The spokesmen for the Australian Labor Party this afternoon completely failed in their attempts to establish a case of a threat to Australia's independence by foreign control of high technology industries-the subject of their matter of public importance. To establish that case, the spokesmen should establish three points: Firstly, that there is excessive foreign control of high technology industries; secondly, that that foreign control is a threat to Australia's independence; and, of course, thirdly and implicitly, that the Government is in some way to blame for this. Labor Party spokesmen have failed this afternoon in all three aspects. They have, of course, indicated a measure of foreign ownership of high technology industry, but in so doing they have--
—A measure? There is 99.8 per cent in the motor industry. A measure?

—The honourable member refers to the motor industry and the levels of ownership of that industry. Well, certainly, a degree of high technology is involved in that industry, but a large sector of that industry does not involve high technology. It is quite false to raise that industry as a high technology industry per se and cite it as indicating something like 98 per cent or 99 per cent of high technology industry being foreign owned.

SPEECH.PARA: In the remarks of the Labor Party spokesmen, of course, they have ignored the interdependence of national economies and particularly the interdependence of the development of high technology. They have also ignored that in Australia in particular it is difficult to establish high technology industries for several reasons. Firstly, we have a small population and, therefore, a small domestic market which is geographically scattered and therefore lacks the opportunity for economies of scale to be applied. The Australian economy is also a great distance from foreign markets and that militates against our capacity to develop export markets. We have also high wages relative to those of our near neighbours. Those wages are less than offset by productivity advantages. We have also a large low cost mineral base which sustains a high exchange rate to the possible disadvantage of manufactured exports.

Of course, a very important aspect is the negative attitude of the trade union movement. We have on the one hand the excessive wage demands of the trade union movement combined with its disastrous record of industrial unrest which encourages the introduction of labour saving technology because such technology does not go on strike. On the other hand the trade union movement has revealed militant opposition to the introduction of new technology, despite its action in hastening its introduction. This militates against its development here in Australia. This attitude was most recently evident in the proposal put to the Australian Council of Trade Unions congress whereby unions would refuse to co-operate with regard to the introduction of technological change unless unrealistic benefits were provided for their members. On the one hand we find their militant attitude to industrial matters quickens technological change whilst on the other hand their militancy prevents its development in Australia. But employers need to introduce technological change quickly because of that militant attitude so far as industrial relations are concerned. To satisfy that need quickly they will purchase the technology overseas rather than take the longer term approach, which a better industrial relations climate would allow, and develop it here in Australia.

Of course, this fear of technology, which is evident among the trade unions, is not justified. The Bureau of Industry Economics report on the long run impact of technology on Australian industry, a report which the Bureau recently released, predicts a growth in the demand for labour in 38 occupational categories which are affected by technology, despite technological change. Indeed, that report concluded that technical change at the anticipated rate would result in more rapid economic growth, in higher per capita consumption and wage levels and in enhanced living standards for all Australians. So, the encouragement of high technology is of benefit to all Australians.

If foreign investment is to be undertaken in high technology industry that has extensive foreign ownership and control already, the Government's foreign investment rules require significant economic benefits and/or significant Australian equity participation before approval will be granted. In cases involving foreign takeovers of Australian firms which have developed special technology, the Government seeks to ensure that some level of Australian ownership be retained or that the benefits be demonstrated sufficiently to outweigh the loss of Australian control of the technology. Takeovers of existing Australian businesses come within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Where indigenous technology is an important asset of the target business the Government will ensure that the technology is applied and developed in Australia and that the potential benefits to Australia of that technology will be maximised. In the area concerning the proposals for establishing new businesses involving the use of high technology, the Government seeks to ensure that opportunities are provided for Australian participation and that Australians share in the benefits derived from the use of that technology. High technology is important to economic growth. Therefore, the issue really to be considered is access to and application of that technology as much as its ownership and control.

The policy which has been consistently pursued by the Government with regard to foreign investment in this area successfully prevents excessive foreign control through those investment rules. This excessive foreign control has been prevented also by Government direct programs, programs which promote high technology industries such as the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme, the support of CSIRO and other laboratories, energy research, the pilot enterprise development program and technology transfer programs. The total appropriation for science and technology under the recent Budget for this financial year is about $427m. This represents an increase of 15.6 per cent over last year-a real increase after allowing for the effects of inflation. Similarly, under the industrial research and development scheme there is a provision of $50m which, in real terms, is the same amount as last year. But the levels of support for industrial research and development programs within individual companies will rise considerably because of the large increase in ceiling payments. For example, the projects grant limit was raised to $750,000 per year, which is an increase of a quarter of a million dollars. This scheme has also been extended for a further five years. It now covers computer software, where relevant to the objects of the Act. So, the Government provides direct support in that way. It is continuing to support major industrial research projects considered to be in the public interest.

An amount of $700,000 will be spent on pilot programs of technology transfer and the commercial development of Australian inventions. A major component of this scheme is the technical referral network, a three-year pilot program in the metals industry. Then, of course, we come to the Government's commitment to CSIRO. Its allocation has been increased by $48.3m this year to $226.9m, an increase of 27 per cent and a real increase of great magnitude. In the direct assistance to manufacturing industry development there has been an increase of 22 per cent. So, we see this Government's commitment demonstrated by the provision of funds.

It is only now that the results of this positive approach by the Fraser Government are being demonstrated in the field, if one likes, by increasing Australian ownership of high technology industry. It is worth providing a few examples of these, some of which are in my own State of South Australia. Recently there has been the development of a new solar heater power project which provides a solar heating panel of over 50 per cent greater efficiency than that produced so far anywhere in the world. World patents on that project have been taken out. This panel works at an optimum of 45 degrees angle to the sun rather than 180 degrees as did previous panels. So a wall panel or a roof panel can be used which does not have to point directly at the sun. This will sell well in international markets at current prices.

Other examples in South Australia and of particular relevance to my electorate of Kingston are the development of an automatic grape picker and, also, an hydraulic pruner to assist the development of the grape producing and wine producing industries there. There is also the CSIRO program of very large-scale integration which aims to put 100,000 circuits on one computer chip. This is another project which has been developed in Adelaide with the direct support of the Federal Government. Then, of course, there are examples which abound from existing firms such as Sola International Pty Ltd, the lens manufacturing firm, which is, once again, located in my electorate of Kingston. This firm has succeeded in developing technology and products which have sold successfully on international markets. So, once again, we see Australian technology to the fore. The Sola company was recently bought out by Pilkington ACI Operations Pty Ltd, but by that does not lose control of its own technology. It further enhances its capacity for additional technological development. Indeed, the management of the firm and the policies of the firm and its independence have been specifically maintained under this arrangement.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill, the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill and the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills now before the House are reasonably non-controversial, with one exception and that is the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill. This Bill is a machinery measure to formally impose the rates of personal income tax for 1981-82 at rates declared in the Income Tax (Rates) Act. The other two Bills are the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill 1981 and the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The first of those two Bills is also a machinery Bill to formally impose tax for 1981-82 on the 1980-81 incomes of companies, superannuation funds and some unit trusts at 46c in the dollar. The Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill contains a number of measures which, in summary, are: It expands tax deductibility to the Victorian Arts Centre Trust and funds established to observe the International Year of Disabled Persons; it revises the form of assessing tax on friendly society dispensaries; it sets the basis for calculation of provisional tax for 1981-82; it reduces the rate at which mining companies can write off their capital expenditure, other than plant and machinery, incurred in developing a mine or an oil field; and it eliminates the use of public unit trusts by companies as a means of avoiding company tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's attitude to these Bills is that we do not oppose the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill or the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill. We do, however, oppose the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill. We oppose that Bill because it imposes an income tax burden which, for the great majority of taxpayers, is the heaviest such burden ever in our history. Total income tax to be paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers in 1981-82 is, as the Budget Papers show, to increase by 22 per cent on the assumption of an increase in employment of 2 per cent and an increase in average weekly earnings of 13 1/2 per cent. So, with pay up 13 1/2 per cent and employment up 2 per cent, that is a 15 1/2 per cent increase in total incomes by wage and salary earners, but total tax paid by wage and salary earners is to go up by 22 per cent. It is quite clear from that simple arithmetic that the burden of income tax which is imposed by the Bill now before the House is to increase considerably in the course of this year. That, of course, is absolutely nothing new. It has happened in almost every year in which the Fraser Government has been in office. There has been a quite considerable increase in the income tax burden, particularly for those on lower and middle incomes, in the course of this Government's period of office. In almost every year in which it has been in office such an increase has occurred.

The way in which it occurs this year is by the Government's decision to apply only half tax indexation. Tax indexation was introduced by the Fraser Government with an enormous flourish in its early years of office. Tax indexation is that process by which the tax scales are adjusted in line with inflation so that people whose incomes are keeping up with inflation do not, simply by that process of having their incomes increased with inflation, move into higher tax brackets as would be the case in a progressive income tax system if no adjustments occurred. In no year of the Fraser Government has there, in fact, been full tax indexation although, supposedly, full tax indexation applied initially. Various discountings have been made over the years, but now we have reached the stage where, this year, there is to be half tax indexation and, next year, no tax indexation whatever. The relevant point for the House at the very present time is that the tax rates which are to be imposed on individuals this year by this legislation are rates and a schedule which result from the application of only half tax indexation. In fact, it is less than half tax indexation if one takes account of the discounting factor involved.

Previously this year there has been a long discussion on this subject. I do not intend to delay the House by going, in great detail, into the subject of tax indexation again, except to make the point, as I have already done, that the application of less than half tax indexation inevitably means that unless there is some other discretionary change in the tax schedule, those whose incomes are simply increasing in line with inflation, or are greater or less than inflation-as long as they are increasing-will pay a higher proportion of their incomes in income tax with a progressive tax schedule. The impact of that is shown by the tremendous increase in the income tax burden which clearly occurs this year with the 22 per cent increase for pay-as-you-earn taxpayers as against a 15 1/2 per cent increase in their income and also if one looks at what has happened over the course of the Fraser Government's period of office. In fact, if we go back and have a look at the past six years we see that the income tax burden for 97 per cent of all taxpayers is higher now than it was in 1975-76. Single taxpayers, all those people whose incomes have risen at the rate of average weekly earnings and who now earn less than $31,000 per annum, to take a round figure, will pay more of their income in income tax this year than in 1975-76.

Of course the $31,000 cut-off point is extraordinarily important because clearly the vast majority of taxpayers earn less than $31,000. Undoubtedly all taxpayers below that level, those whose incomes are doing no more than keeping pace with average weekly earnings, move into higher tax brackets and pay more of their incomes in tax. Quite obviously, the vast majority of taxpayers are in that situation. On our calculations, 97 per cent of taxpayers earn less than $31,000 a year; so they will pay a higher proportion of their incomes in income tax this year than they paid in 1975-76. Of course, as we go down the line from $31,000 the increase in the tax burden becomes greater. It is not some even application which suddenly cuts out at $31,000. Lower income earners pay the greatest increase in the income tax burden. A taxpayer who was on a very high income-say, $50,000 in 1975-76-and whose income increased in line with average weekly earnings, this year would earn $94,000. But his tax would be reduced by about $43 a week compared with what it would have been had he paid the same proportion of his income in income tax as he paid in 1975-76. So there are large tax concessions for very high income earners, assuming of course that people at that level pay their taxes and do not indulge in tax avoidance as do a substantial number of people on that high level of income. Leaving aside tax avoidance and looking simply at very high income earners who pay tax according to the tax schedule, they have been given large tax concessions by this Government at a time when the vast majority of taxpayers are paying a much higher proportion of their income in income tax.

The figures I have given relate to single taxpayers. A similar situation exists for a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children. In that situation the cut-off point is $33,000 and that takes account of the fact that there was a change in 1976 from the previous system of child endowment plus tax deductions for children to a straight-out system of family allowances. But we still find that families in that situation, who earn up to $33,000 a year, are paying more of their income in net tax. Furthermore, if we take into account another factor related to income tax, that is, the increase in the cost of health insurance which in 1975-76 was provided without cost under Medibank Mark I-Medibank as was originally introduced by the Labor Government-we find that the increase in net tax payable by taxpayers who are on anything but very high incomes is very great indeed. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables which show the effect of the Fraser Government's tax policies. One table relates to a single taxpayer and the other to a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children.
