TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The tables which I have incorporated in Hansard show the situation between 1975-76 and the current income year for income earners at four levels: 85 per cent of average weekly earnings; average weekly earnings; 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings and twice average weekly earnings. Assuming that the Budget calculations of the increase in average weekly earnings are correct, there will be an 88 per cent increase in average weekly earnings between 1975-76 and 1981-82. But whilst income has increased by 88 per cent, we find there has been a much greater increase in what I describe as net tax. This table looks at the increased tax payable and also takes account of the fact that people now have to pay for health insurance which they did not have to pay for in 1975-76. It also takes account of the fact that this year, although people will have to pay for it, there will be a tax rebate for health insurance. Taking all those factors into account, we find that the net tax situation is one in which people at all of those income levels that I have mentioned are paying a higher proportion of their income in net tax. That is taking into account health insurance as well as income tax, for the reason I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: A person on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings finds that although his income has increased by 88 per cent, his net tax has increased by 124 per cent. A person on average weekly earnings finds his net tax is up by 111 per cent compared with his income increase of 88 per cent. For a person earning 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings, the net tax rise is 103 per cent, and for a person earning twice average weekly earnings the net tax increase is 91 per cent. This gets closer to the increase in income but it is still above it; so there is still some slight increase in the burden of taxation borne by that taxpayer. People who this year earn twice average weekly earnings will earn $33,216. Again we are talking about people who are on quite high incomes compared with the incomes of most people in the community. Even so, at that level there is still some slight increase in the burden of the net tax in the way that I have described. The figures that I have given relate to a single taxpayer. For a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, the situation is similar, except that the increases are much greater at lower income levels.

Thus the taxpayer on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings, whose income has increased 88 per cent, finds that his net tax has increased by 241 per cent and that his net tax as a proportion of income has increased from 8.9 per cent to 16.1 per cent. Those are very large increases. It is almost double the tax burden. The proportion of income paid in income tax and health insurance, in net terms, has almost doubled for a person who earns 85 per cent of average weekly earnings. This is from a government which said in 1975 that it would reduce the tax burden. It made enormous play of that issue. Ever since it has talked about the need to reduce income tax. The Government made enormous play of the fact that income taxes were too high and what it must do is reduce them. The gap between the rhetoric and the performance is absolutely mind-blowing, especially for people at lower income levels. People on average weekly earnings-the families I have described-have had an increase in their tax burden of 172 per cent compared with an income growth of 88 per cent; so the proportion of income paid in net tax increases from 12.8 per cent to 18.5 per cent and to lesser degrees for the other two incomes levels that I have mentioned.

What flows quite clearly and incontrovertibly from these tables is that during the course of the Fraser Government's period of office, for the overwhelming majority of taxpayers-all but the top 3 per cent or so-there has been a very considerable increase in the tax burden and that increase in the tax burden has been the greatest for taxpayers at the bottom end of the scale. Consequently, there has been a great reduction in the equity of the tax system as well as a great increase in the burden of the income tax system. Those are developments which are deplored by the Opposition. For those reasons we oppose the measures which are contained in the legislation before us today, which impose for this year the highest level of income tax in our history.

Of course, it is interesting to note that at the same time as this legislation comes before the House we find a great deal of public discussion occurring outside about the possibility of reduced income tax. Just a few days ago the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that we are getting close to the point where income tax cuts can be introduced. One might ask, 'Isn't it about time?', because for the last six years the Prime Minister has introduced almost continuing increases of a very large scale in income taxes for the great majority of wage and salary earners and taxpayers in general. At the same time as that has been happening there has also been an increase in indirect taxation. The burden of indirect taxation-that is, sales taxes, customs and excise, crude oil levies and so on-in total has increased as a proportion of total taxation. That is, indirect taxation has increased faster than income tax and therefore there has been, along with this large and growing income tax burden, a large and growing burden of indirect taxation. So there has been no compensatiof on the indirect tax side. As we know now from the sales tax issue, which is very much before this Parliament and presumably will be before the House directly in the next day or so, the Government is still trying to increase indirect taxes rapidly.

Prior to the sales tax increases brought in by the last Budget, the way in which indirect taxes were increased was through the crude oil levy, which has increased to an astonishing degree from $250m in 1975-76 to approximately $3,500m in this year's Budget-an extraordinary increase in such a short time. That has been the major way in which indirect taxation has been increased. But now that the sting is running out of that, with world oil prices stabilising, the Government has shifted to sales tax to keep the drive in indirect tax increases going. So taxpayers have been getting it all ways-on their incomes and indirectly. The only ones who have been able to escape this large burden of increased taxation have been high income earners who have been paying their taxes according to the schedule-which means quite high income earners-and those who have been avoiding tax. As everyone in this Parliament and in the nation is aware, there has been an enormous increase in tax avoidance in this Government's period of office, as shown by the one simple fact that the number of tax avoiders identified in the Taxation Commissioner's report last year was 20 times higher than in 1975. So there is no doubt that there has been an enormous change in the equity of the tax system.

I will not go into the aspects of equity related to indirect taxation at this stage, but on the income tax side, as I have shown quite clearly, the burden of tax has fallen increasingly on lower income earners. The overall burden of income tax has increased considerably and that has occurred at the same time as a growing burden of indirect taxation. This Government has an enormously long way to go before it can stand before the nation and say that it is a low tax party. If it thinks it can say to the people in the next few months or by the next Budget: 'Here is a little cut in income tax; are we not marvellous?', it has a long way to go before it gets the people of Australia to accept that as evidence that it is a low tax party. The fact is that it is anything but a low tax party. It is a very high tax party, the highest tax party in our history, particularly for people who can least afford to pay more taxes-the people on lower and middle incomes.

The Bills before the House, as I mentioned, relate to other measures which we do not oppose. I would like to refer briefly to a couple of those. The Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), relating to the taxation of public unit trusts, is an important development which we thoroughly support. On 16 July 1980, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced a crackdown on unit trusts formed by the reorganisation of the businesses of public companies in order to avoid tax. A unit trust is a trust where the beneficial ownership of the trust property is divided into units which are allocated to unit holders. According to the Master Tax Guide, which is published by the publishing firm of CCH Australia Ltd, during the late 1970s the unit trust flourished as a vehicle for tax planning directed at reducing the double liability to tax imposed upon profits derived by companies in the form of primary company income and taxed upon the dividend subsequently distributed. In other words, the point of using the trust was that companies would be able to avoid company tax and that company income, therefore, would be taxed only once, that is, in the hands of the shareholder.

Basically these schemes involve the public company entering into a scheme of arrangement to divide the company into a new holding company and a unit trust. Income producing assets were transferred to the unit trust and income from those assets taxed only in the hands of the unit holders. Of course, previously the income was taxed at the company level and again at the shareholder level. The Australian Financial Review reports that a number of public companies were in the process of setting up such schemes when this legislation was announced, whilst others already had such trusts set up and operating. Those companies which were apparently already using this form of operation included Westfield Ltd, Paynter and Dixon, Nock and Kirby Ltd and Perth Arcade. Those in the process of thinking of using it were the Swan Brewery Co. Ltd, Stockland, Myer, Tooth and Co. Ltd, Hookers, Repco, Woolworths and Carlton and United Breweries. That is as reported in the Australian Financial Review. All those are large companies. Quite obviously if this process had gone on very far, if all major companies were using this form of unit trust to avoid company tax, company tax would have become a thing of the past.

The Swan Brewery was the most publicised of those which were seeking to use this tax avoidance device. It did not get to use it although it had, it said, obtained a written clearance from the Australian Taxation Office on 13 December 1979. I must say that I find it quite extraordinary that the Taxation Office could have given a written clearance to a company to indulge in a process which was patently one of tax avoidance. Whether the company is misrepresenting what it received from the Taxation Office I am not in a position to say, but I think it would be interesting if the Treasurer, or whoever is representing him in this debate, could tell us in the course of this debate what the Taxation Office did do in relation to the Swan Brewery because, if the Taxation Office was giving the nod to tax avoidance, that would be a disturbing development. I frankly do not think that would have been the case, but the Swan Brewery claimed that it had this clearance from the Taxation Office and that, therefore, it was thoroughly within its rights in going ahead in the way it was. It was very indignant that the Government moved to block off this tax avoidance device before it could finally get the company reorganised onto a unit trust basis.

There are a couple of interesting points in relation to this legislation. The first is: Why has it taken so long for the Government to bring it in? It was announced in July 1980. We are in October 1981 and here is the legislation which was announced a year and a quarter ago. It seems an extraordinarily long delay. Also, the measures taken in the legislation to prevent the operation of this tax avoidance scheme-that is, by taxing the unit trust at 46c in the dollar and, therefore, taking away all the tax advantages of moving into that process-do not apply to companies which had already established such a scheme prior to the legislation being announced. We cannot for the life of us see why the Government would want to give three years grace to those companies which had been able to introduce such a tax avoidance scheme prior to July 1980. The Government is saying by this legislation that those companies will not have to face up to this tax on their unit trusts until income year 1983-84. Last year, this year and next year, they are all to be tax free in that respect. This seems a quite extraordinary development, thoroughly unexplained in the second reading speech by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) and totally unsatisfactory as far as we are concerned. I think the Government has some explaining to do in the course of this debate as to why it is allowing companies which have undertaken this sheer tax avoidance device to get away with it for three years. We think it is an extraordinary activity. Although the total revenue losses may not be all that enormous, I am sure they are extraordinarily beneficial to the companies involved. We believe the morality of it is such that they should not be allowed to get away with it.

We are also concerned that, as we read this legislation, it is possible for companies still to avoid tax in the future by means of a unit trust which does not involve the reorganisation of the company but which is established for any new business and into which the company puts the new income producing assets. As we read the legislation, it would seem that in that situation, where there is no company reorganisation involved but simply a unit trust established for new business, company tax could be avoided. If that is the case, we would certainly be very disturbed. I would like some reassurance in that respect in the course of this debate. If the reassurance cannot be given, I would like some change made to the legislation to ensure that such an obvious loophole is not allowed to remain.

I want to make a quick comment on the change in the rate of write-off of capital spending by mining companies. Such capital expenditure does not include plant and machinery which is depreciable in the ordinary way, but it does enable companies to write-off the very considerable capital expenditures they have in developing a mine or an oil field, which is expenditure not normally able to be written off by other businesses. The position before this legislation was that the deduction was calculated by reference to the lesser of the life of the mine or to six years, which meant a rate of 16 2/3 per cent per annum was adopted using a six-year basis and that became the basis for a diminishing balance form of calculation. Rather than a straight out 16 2/3 per cent per annum, it is a diminishing balance process. So it takes much longer than six years to write-off the capital expenditure. This legislation extends that six-year period to 10 years. So it is 10 per cent per annum on a diminishing basis, which means that it takes much more than 10 years to write-off the total amount of the capital. In fact, on our calculations, it would take over 30 years for the capital to be totally written off on the 10 per cent basis, unless the life of the mine expired before that time, in which case whatever is remaining could be written off at the end of the mine's life.

The Government has received a considerable amount of criticism from the mining industry for this change in the legislation which was announced as part of the Budget. In our view, that criticism is not justified. We believe that the concession which is there remains a very significant one indeed. It is expenditure which is peculiar to mining companies. Other companies are not allowed to write-off depreciation on buildings, for instance, whereas mining companies can do so in this way. We believe that the change from six years to 10 years is not unreasonable.

One other query I have in relation to this legislation relates to the granting of tax deductibility to gifts to the Victorian Arts Centre Trust. We in no way oppose that amendment to the tax law, but we would ask the Government to state what has happened to the action which the Government is supposed to be taking in respect of the Victorian Arts Centre. Earlier last year a tax avoidance scheme was discovered relating to gifts of art works to the National Gallery of Victoria. At that time a quite notable tax avoidance scheme was brought to light by myself. The Government said at that time that the Taxation Office would look at ways of stopping such a tax avoidance scheme continuing in the future. No such action has been announced by the Treasurer since that time. Since we are talking about tax deductibility for the Victorian Arts Centre Trust, it would not hurt for the Government to say, during the debate, what it intends to do to prevent further tax avoidance schemes through deductions for gifts of art works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most concerning elements of the discussion on tax at the moment has been the unbelievable volume of nonsense being spoken about the impact of indirect tax on Australians, particularly those in lower income groups. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) mentioned the allegation that lower income groups have suffered more under the present Government than in fact is the case. It seems to me to be unfortunate that the honourable member for Gellibrand conveniently omits from these discussions reference to the enormous number of lower income people in Australia who are now totally exempted from tax as a result of the Government's continuing policies involved in lifting, as it will do once again this year, the cut-off level at which tax is paid in the first place. In fact, one of these Bills increases the cut-off level, as a result of half indexation, below which tax need not be paid. As a result of these policies, there are many hundreds of thousands of Australians who are not paying tax and who would have paid tax had the system that was used when the Labor Government was in power still been employed.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is very important indeed to examine the false allegations that sales tax rises will have an unfair and unreasonable impact on lower income groups in Australia. This seems to me to be one of the basically dishonest elements of the discussion of tax in Australia at the moment. What I will put to the House is very simple. I am certain that members of the Opposition will be able to follow it. I direct their attention to it. I hope that honourable members opposite-the few who are here-listen with great diligence because it is a very important point. I am putting the simple proposition that sales tax is not unfair to lower income people, particularly pensioners, not only because, obviously, richer people buy more expensive items, when they buy items that have sales tax, than poorer people generally do, although I admit that a lot of the objections to sales tax has been on the basis that it applies equally to rich and poor when they buy an item. If a relatively poor person buys a frock for, say, $20 she pays a lot less sales tax than a rich person who buys a frock for $200. That is self evident. That is not the main objection to the nonsense being spoken about sales tax. Nor is it only because the Commonwealth Statistician's surveys have proved that poorer people spend a far smaller proportion -about 25 per cent-of their expenditure on items that will be taxable under the new sales tax arrangements than do richer people. Well over half of their expenditures ends up on items that are taxable. That is not the main issue either. That is simply another example of how dishonest the campaign is. The basic burden--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Bills now before the House have nothing to do with sales tax. I would like the honourable member to relate his remarks to the Bills.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I would like to point out that a discussion has been allowed in this place of the basis and the balance of taxes in Australia. The honourable member for Gellibrand made the point that there was an unfair distribution of sales taxes, indirect taxes. I am replying specifically to the point raised by the honourable member for Gellibrand, who complained about the distribution of sales tax to direct taxes in his speech. I believe I have a right to respond to those points. It is not simply because sales tax gathers revenue from the tax avoiders either. That is another part of the great lie. The honourable member for Gellibrand insists on talking about tax avoiders all the time. They are still able to get away with not paying some of the direct taxes they are supposed to pay by using certain devices, despite the enormous volume of anti-avoidance legislation that has been introduced in this Parliament. Some of the recent legislation is yet to be tested in the courts. I hope that it will prove successful against them. An incidence of sales tax on items means that people who avoid direct taxes cannot avoid sales tax. The wife of someone who avoids income tax is, in fact, contributing to the revenues of the Government and, therefore, to its capacity to provide finance for welfare, health and other benefits for the Australian people when she buys a $200 frock. It is a fact that indirect taxes, such as sales tax, hit the rich equally. They are at last brought into the tax net if they have been avoiding it. There are many other reasons why indirect taxes can be much fairer.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to recognise that Australia is totally out of step with the rest of the developed world, which relies much more heavily on indirect taxes than Australia. One of the reasons that Australians have the false impression that Australia is a highly taxed country is that direct taxes make up a relatively high proportion of their total tax cake. In fact Australia is the fifth lowest of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in terms of the total tax people are required to contribute. That is self-evident. It is demonstrated by the statistics that are readily available.

The major reason sales taxes will not be unfair to most poorer people is that pensioners make up the great bulk of poorer people. They are the largest element in Australia's lower income group and they will be totally protected by increased pensions that will result directly because of the sales tax rises and other higher prices. Pensioners in fact will get roughly double protection against the sales tax rises, though as usual there will be some delay before it takes place. That is an essential point to recognise. The pensioners in Australia who receive full adjustments of their pensions as a result of automatic indexation introduced by this Government will receive double cover-double protection-over the increased cost that will follow as a result of sales tax rises. So people who come into this House or who are outside with bleeding hearts talking about the terrible impact on pensioners of sales tax rises are talking arrant nonsense. The figures-I will demonstrate the figures for the benefit of those people-are simply these: The Statistician's survey indicates that because there will be no sales tax rise whatsoever on food and rent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet.

—There will be no sales tax on food and none on rent. None is intended, none is introduced, and no one is seriously suggesting it in this House, except the honourable member opposite. There will be no sales tax whatsoever on food, rent and other items. Only about $18 a week of pensioners's spending will be on items that will suffer from sales tax rises.
—Order! I remind the honourable member that we are discussing the Income Tax Amendment Bill and ask him to confine his remarks to that Bill.

—I intend to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I wish to demonstrate that the argument about the proportional impact raised by the honourable member for Gellibrand is arrant nonsense. I take your point. I will complete the point I am now making and then refer to the more general aspects of the Bill, which I must say the honourable member for Gellibrand mentioned in passing. As I said, because food and rent is excluded only about $18 of pensioners' spending will be on items that suffer from sales tax. A single pensioner's cost will rise by an average of 50c a week as a result of sales tax increases, but because these sales tax rises will have a far bigger impact on the cost of living index than on pensioners' costs as they spread across a lot of other items which most pensioners do not buy, the Budget estimates there will be a three-quarter per cent increase in the cost of living index as a result of these sales tax rises. A three-quarter per cent increase will have the impact of a 53c rise per week in pensioners' incomes as a result of automatic indexation. Added to that is a similar rise as a result of the health charges because the index does not take into account the fact that people will be better off when they get their tax rebate. But when we add the three-quarter per cent increase also from the increase in the cost of living resulting from the health charge rises of which pensioners do not have to pay one cent, there is a benefit to pensioners of $1.05 a week, but an increased cost of only 50c as a result of sales tax rises. Yet people, both inside and outside this House talk this kind of nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to stress that the same sort of nonsense as I have outlined in relation to sales tax applies to the argument about taxation in general and the Government's approach to taxation. I remind the House that in fact the increases in direct taxes over recent years bear no sort of relation to the enormous increases that took place under the previous Government. When we hear members of the Opposition complaining about huge tax rises under this Government, it seems extraordinary that they have such a short memory and cannot remember that under Mr Whitlam's three Budgets there was an average increase of $867m a year in constant dollar terms compared with the rise in the present Government's six Budgets of only $750m per year. We have to recognise that there is a lower rate of increase in taxes in real terms-that is total tax collections-under the present Government than there was under the previous Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement.
—Is leave granted?

—Whilst leave is granted, I wish to make the point that we have had only 40 minutes notice of this statement. I hope that in future the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will give us the courtesy of two hours notice because the Leader of the Opposition has to reply. I think the Prime Minister has sufficient staff to enable us to get a better result than that which we are achieving.

—I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I regret that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has not had greater time. I thank him, in spite of that, for giving leave. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, held in Melbourne and Canberra between 30 September and 7 October, was a success for Australia and the Commonwealth and it can be expected to have an influence on world discussions. The Meeting confounded the critics who had predicted that differences of view would lead to division and that irrelevant issues would distract attention from the fundamental themes. In fact, a spirit of compromise and practicality enabled 41 very disparate countries, most with strongly held views of their own, to reach agreement on a range of issues, and indeed, to agree to act on many of them. The Commonwealth is a remarkable international organisation not only because its meetings are for heads of government rather than for officials or foreign ministers; not only because the meetings themselves occupy a period of time which allows for thorough as well as wide-ranging deliberations; not only because the membership of the Commonwealth cuts across some of the most significant lines of division in the world; and not only because the Commonwealth countries themselves comprise above one quarter of the world's population.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has said that the sole common link between the members of the Commonwealth is that they are all former British colonies. But in addition to the fact that we all also speak a common language, in addition to the fact that we all, as President Kaunda of Zambia put it, gained our independence from the British using their language, there is the further bond, again remarked on by President Kaunda, of a similar legal and administrative background among Commonwealth countries. I would add that in a world which is still unfortunately marred by racialism, it is a truly satisfying experience to be in and of a gathering which repudiates racialism not only in words but also by its nature. In the Commonwealth, brown, black, and white meet as equals and friends, and as President Kaunda put it: 'If God had made people green I am sure they would be represented in the Commonwealth as well'.

So far as Australia itself is concerned the success of the Conference must be measured not only in the fact that the issues we had identified beforehand as central indeed turned out to be so, and not merely in the fact that our contributions to the discussions on these central issues were successful in advancing several initiatives regarding them. I believe that we have emerged from the meeting with an enhanced reputation as an active and concerned member of the Commonwealth and as an enlightened and responsible middle power.

Earlier this year, the Leader of the Opposition, in discussing the Australian Labor Party's foreign policy beliefs, said: Australia and Australians can achieve anything on their own. Such words are not mere grandstanding; they are fanciful and ill-considered, especially when he has no practical proposals to help create more wealth or to improve the living standards of people in developing countries, or indeed to advance the causes of peace and stability on any other significant issues. The Government's approach to its role in world affairs is vastly different for we recognise the contribution we can make and the role we can play. We accept the responsibilities of that role, and are prepared to take such steps as we can towards helping to make the world a better and more secure place for our children.

From the purely Australian point of view a further gain and success from the Commonwealth Meeting has been that our visitors were impressed by Australia as a friendly and vital country with a great future.

I pay tribute to those people, for the most part ordinary Australians, from right around the country but especially from Melbourne and Canberra, who conveyed to all the visitors the friendliness and confidence that the world now regards as characteristic of this country and who helped to make our visitors ambassadors for Australia. The tributes to Australia from the visitors will surely be pleasing to all members of the House and, indeed, to all Australians. Pierre Trudeau went so far as to say that the twentieth century can be said to belong to Australia. President Kaunda said that in the last few years his view of Australia has changed from one of 'a country where there was indifference to suffering people of the rest of the world' to one of 'decent human beings, an Australia with which we are very proud to be associated'. Sir Dennis Hamilton, of the Commonwealth Press Union, which was meeting at the same time went out of his way to say:

The sense of self-confidence of people (in Australia) at every level . . . that they can tackle any problems . . . is a bit of a refresher and encouragement for some of us who have come from some of the old countries.

I could instance many other tributes of a similar kind, but these are representative and give the House the flavour of our visitors' impressions. They show that the view of the Leader of the Opposition of the Meeting, at least before it was held, as 'an extravagant indulgence' reflected a quite distorted idea of the impact which the Meeting would have on the way in which Australia is regarded in other parts of the world. I add that, as Mrs Gandhi has said, when the expenditure on armaments in so many countries is so high, an amount of $10m, $15m or $20m spent on the pursuit of peace is small compared with the vast billions of dollars that are spent on armaments. If that sum spent in the pursuit of peace can help to make the world a safer place, surely it is worth spending.

From the Commonwealth point of view, the success of the Melbourne Meeting can be measured in several ways. The vitality of the Commonwealth was evident in the fact that three new members were present. Let me add that not a single member of the Meeting, in welcoming Zimbabwe, would have found anything 'quaint' or 'ironical', to use the words of the Leader of the Opposition, in the fact that Australia played a role in the establishment by the Commonwealth at the Lusaka Meeting of the conditions in which Zimbabwe was able to achieve independence.

The nature of the discussions between the Commonwealth leaders in Melbourne and Canberra-the meeting of minds that occurred, the understanding and friendships which were created-was a further confirmation of the relevance of the Commonwealth in a world in which divisions can too easily become entrenched and in which a needless lack of understanding so often prevents the achievement of real solutions.

I believe that the success of the Meeting for the Commonwealth will also turn out to be a success so far as the international community is concerned. The Commonwealth is obviously not an organisation with the power to settle major world issues, but between the extremes of either achieving a dramatic, conclusive impact which will turn everything around or of having no effect at all there is room for the kind of influence which the Commonwealth can have and which can be so important in achieving the right outcome rather than the wrong one. The Commonwealth role is to a considerable extent a matter of helping, in an incremental fashion, to shape opinion one way rather than the other; to change the balance of considerations operating on those who have to make larger decisions; to ensure that there are no miscalculations because strongly held views have not been clearly heard.

The Melbourne Meeting sent out a number of signals which, because of their timing and because they represent the views of a significant group of leaders, will register with other governments. Indeed, they are already registering and having an impact. Strongly supportive comments about the value of the Melbourne Declaration and the Communique, such as that the Declaration appears to be a 'very significant document which would no doubt be widely discussed' and that both the Declaration and the Communique would be helpful in 'setting the scene' for Cancun, the meeting to be held in Mexico, have been received at many of our missions abroad.

The Melbourne Declaration and the Communique from the Meeting are complementary documents. The Melbourne Declaration is a statement of resolve by 41 Heads of Government designed to demand urgent action to alleviate the plight of hundreds of millions of people living in absolute poverty. It is designed also to point out the despair which these conditions engender and the insecurity which can so easily be encouraged when such conditions prevail. Its purpose is to achieve a wider recognition that there is a massive problem in terms of the way in which hundreds of millions of people live out their lives on this earth and the need for nations to do more about that than they have done up to this point in time.

When the House ponders the Melbourne Declaration it might bear in mind the words of Pierre Trudeau at the Meeting, that 'history will judge this year as a watershed in North-South relations'. I known quite well that it was Pierre Trudeau's view that one of his principal tasks at the Ottawa Summit, at which the seven major economies were represented, was to achieve a recognition of the fact that progress must be made in North-South discussions, that global negotiations on economic relations between the rich and the poor must be got under way. It is my understanding that he believes that the Ottaw Summit, which Canada was responsible for chairing and organising, the Melbourne Meeting and Cancun are three steps along a similar path. It was Mrs Gandhi's hope that the voices of the countries of the Commonwealth would reach out to Cancun, as she very clearly expressed.

The Communique addresses virtually every major issue facing the world today and it reaches conclusions and makes recommendations concerning many of them. Despite the need for compromise to achieve maximum consensus, it says some very pointed things indeed. On the economic side, it addresses all the main topics encompassed by the North-South dialogue. It expresses strong support for an early resumption of global negotiations and seeks ways of improving the negotiating process. It is worth noting that this is the first time that there has been a suggestion that the rigidities in the negotiating process itself might be one of the contributing factors towards lack of progress in that area. It is the Commonwealth that has suggested that the actual negotiating process involving the different blocs and groups in the world should be examined to see whether there are not within it impediments that can be overcome. I think it also was widely recognised that there was a need for the global negotiations to be resumed so that all nations-large, small and very small-can feel that they are participating in the process. So often in the affairs of men it is the small nations that believe they are acted upon by events and that they have no power to influence events or in a real way to shape their own future. That is one of the real reasons so many people believe that global negotiations are important: To enable all nations to feel that they are part of the process and can contribute towards modifications to arrangements in the world which are designed and are able to advance the cause of their peoples, to be part of the act rather than to be merely acted upon.

The Communique also strongly reaffirms opposition to protectionism and establishes an expert study group to examine the impact of protectionism on developing countries in particular. Studies undertaken by our own officials and based on United Nations Conference on Trade and Development studies indicate that the impact of agricultural protectionism on a range of products, not the kinds of products that we expect, but those which are of concern to developing countries, reduces financial flows to developing countries by over $30 billion a year. If that extra $30 billion were in the hands of the developing countries, how much more would they be able to do for themselves, how much less would they need to ask for aid, how much greater would be their capacity to help themselves? I believe that those studies are important. I pointed out in the debate in Melbourne that for some people it could be uncomfortable if that course were to be followed. It could be uncomfortable in part for Australia, but if it were uncomfortable, so be it. We would need to examine it and work on it.

The Communique supports also the early establishment of an energy affiliate of the World Bank and a number of other practical measures relating to energy to be taken by the Commonwealth itself. It expands the Commonwealth's capacity to assist the food needs of developing Commonwealth members. It supports increased food aid, improved food security arrangements and increased assistance for agricultural developments. It reaffirms support for the Common Fund and outlines practical measures to be taken with the Commonwealth to assist commodity exporters. It makes a number of recommendations for an expansion of the capacity of international financial institutions to help developing countries. But it also noted the changes and modifications that those international financial institutions have in fact made over recent years.

I should add that, in addition to what is in the Communique, Australia has taken a number of initiatives of its own which will support and supplement the Communique's contents and general thrust. Among these are an increase in overseas development assistance for 1981-82 by $100m or 18 per cent which, of course, was announced during the Budget, the details of which were announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). That increases for the first time in a number of years the ratio of official development assistance from 0.43 per cent to an estimated 0.45 per cent of gross domestic product.

Australia's food aid program and assistance for agricultural development has been substantially expanded. Food aid has been increased by 15 per cent to $100m allowing about 445,000 tonnes of grain to be given, up from 400,000 tonnes in 1980-81 and 225,000 tonnes only a very few years ago. Australia is more than satisfying its obligations under world food program targets.

Australia has increased its contribution to the International Emergency Food Reserve from 30,000 tonnes to 45,000 tonnes. We are paying the freight on an increasing proportion of our food aid, including on 80,000 tonnes to Africa. Australia is establishing a centre for international agricultural research to mobilise Australian agricultural expertise which is very considerable indeed to address problems of importance to developing countries. We are delighted that Sir John Crawford has agreed to be the initial chairman of this body. In addition, we are continuing to give priority within our regular aid program to agricultural development.

On energy, Australia has pledged an additional $1m in Nairobi for assistance for new and renewable energy sources. Australia has offered also to make available to all Commonwealth countries, information and experience through the Commonwealth Regional Renewable Energy Resource Information System run by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and also to make available to Commonwealth countries an exhibition of new and renewable energy technology which is being perpared as part of the work of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting energy group. It is worth noting that those are initiatives taken out of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meetings which have flowed over to the main Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

On commodity trade, Australia has signed the instrument for ratification of the Common Fund and is making a voluntary ontribution of $5.5m to its second account for the promotion of development, marketing and production.

On trade, Australia has recently extended and liberalised preferences of significant interest to developing countries to the whole textiles, clothing and footwear area. Imports in 1977-78 account for about 40 per cent of the Australian market for textiles, 20 per cent for clothing and 28 per cent for footwear. Those percentages stand reasonably well by the access that is available for other advanced countries. In addition, a wide variety of products now receives special preferences in the South Pacific trading region. Australia's continuing examination of protection and the Industries Assistance Commission general reference were noted and appreciated by Heads of Government.

On the political side, there is in the Communique a reaffirmation of the Gleneagles Declaration; a strong statement on Namibia with agreement between the contact group, front line and other members on the need for intensified efforts to seek settlement on the basis of United Nations resolution 435; on Poland: Agreement that the people of Poland should be left to determine their own destiny free from foreign or outside interference; on Afghanistan and Kampuchea: Strong agreement on the need for the withdrawal of foreign troops; on Africa: The view that African states should be able to pursue their own affairs without outside interference from any source; on the law of the sea: Affirmation of the need for a convention to be concluded speedily; on the South Pacific: Support for the call by the countries of the region for an immediate end to nuclear testing, and a welcoming of the decision by the South Pacific Forum to send a mission to France to discuss the future of French territories in the Pacific. There was also informal discussion among some leaders on the general question of readmission to the Commonwealth. This is a new question which the Commonwealth has not had to consider before, and government leaders will be keeping in touch on the matter.

Mr Speaker, at the opening of the conference two weeks ago I spoke of the intractable nature of the problems on our agenda and of the need, therefore, to think in terms of improvements and progress rather than of total solutions. I spoke of the need to define success in realistic terms. In those terms-which are the only ones which can seriously be countenanced-this conference speaks for itself.

I want to make one comment about the security arrangements for the conference because they have attracted a good deal of interest and attention and the Leader of the Opposition actually described them as 'somewhat ridiculous and, frankly, frightening'. The frightening thing is not the arrangements that we made, but the fact that we live in a world in which such arrangements are necessary. But the inconveniences were minimised and I am sure that I speak for the vast majority of Australians when I say, especially thinking of the assassinations and attempted assassinations of world leaders which have taken place this year, that I am glad we took the precautions we did; I am glad that so many leaders commented so favourably on the arrangements we had made; and I am glad that the meeting passed without any incidents occurring. I must say that this was a great credit to both the Commonwealth and Victorian Police. I think many honourable gentlemen will not know that the Victorian Police had their leave cancelled. They had many hours of overtime so that their normal responsibilities could still be undertaken without any diminution right across the State. I believe that they did a really wonderful job and that everyone in this country has every right to be proud of what they did.

Three years ago, and again seven months ago, the Leader of the Opposition said that the Commonwealth is an 'anachronistic institution, a talk shop of dubious value for Australia'. I hope that the success of the Melbourne Meeting has changed his view as it has undoubtedly convinced countless Australians of the value of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is an instrument which enables the leaders of many countries, from many continents, to come together as colleagues and friends to make a contribution to the continuing process of resolving the world's problems. That is what the Meeting at Melbourne was all about. I table the Declaration and a copy of the Communique.

DECLARATION
We, the Heads of Government here assembled, drawn from Five Continents representing a quarter of the World's entire population:
(1) Affirm our strong and unanimous conviction that all men and women have the right to live in ways that sustain and nourish human dignity.
(2) Believe that this right imposes obligations on all states, large and small, not only in respect to their own people but in their dealings with all other nations.

(3) Assert that the gross inequality of wealth and opportunity currently existing in the world, and the unbroken circle of poverty in which the lives of millions in developing countries are confined, are fundamental sources of tension and instability in the world.
(4) As a consequence, assert our unanimous conviction that there must be determined and dedicated action at national and international levels to reduce that inequality and to break that circle.
(5) Believe that for all these reasons it is imperative to revitalise the dialogue between developed and developing countries.
(6) Declare that this will require a political commitment, clear vision and intellectual realism which have thus far escaped mankind and to all of which the Commonwealth can greatly contribute.
(7) Believe that the dialogue must be conducted with a genuine willingness to accept real and significant changes commensurate with the urgency of the problems we now face.
(8) Firmly believe that the choice is not between change and no change but between timely, adequate, managed change and disruptive, involuntary change imposed by breakdown and conflict.
(9) Maintain that success will only be achieved as states recognise and give due weight to the essential inter-dependence of peoples and of states.

(10) Declare that, while the most urgent humanitarian considerations demand action, self-interest itself warrants a constructive and positive approach to these great human problems by all governments.

(11) Recognise that in the process of negotiations, nations must cast aside inhibitions and habits which have thwarted progress in the past and find new ways of talking constructively to one another so as to reach agreement on effective joint action.

(12) Note that, as well as technical economic considerations, it is imperative that states keep in the forefront of their attention the larger moral, political and strategic dimensions of what is at stake.

(13) Maintain that while the problems are formidable, they are not of such a weight that they will defeat our purpose, given political will and an understanding of the needs of different countries and groups.

(14) Assert that what is at stake-in terms of how hundreds of millions will live or die; of the prospects for cooperation or conflict; and of the prospects for economic advance or stagnation-is of such vital importance in human terms that it would be an indictment of this generation if that political will and the readiness to find a creative compromise were not found.

(15) Firmly believe that the issues are so important that they require the personal commitment and involvement of political leaders who, representing the will of their peoples, have the greatest power to advance the common cause of mankind.

(16) Attaching the highest importance to the principles and objectives of this document, recognising the mutual interests and interdependence of all nations, declare our common resolve: To end the present impasse; to advance the dialogue between developed and developing countries; to infuse an increased sense of urgency and direction into the resolution of these common problems of mankind; and solemnly call on all leaders of all countries to join us in a commitment to taking prompt, practical and effective action to that end.
Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting
Melbourne
October 1981
COMMUNIQUE
Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting Melbourne
30 September-7 October 1981
FINAL COMMUNIQUE

1. Commonwealth Heads of Government met in Melbourne from 30 September to 7 October 1981. Of the 41 countries which attended the Meeting, 30 were represented by their Presidents or Prime Ministers. The Prime Minister of Australia Mr Malcolm Fraser was in the Chair.

2. Heads of Government sent a message of felicitation to Her Majesty the Queen as Head of the Commonwealth. They welcomed with great pleasure the opportunity of meeting in Melbourne, and expressed their appreciation of the excellent arrangements made for the Meeting and the warm and generous hospitality of their Australian hosts.

3. Heads of Government warmly welcomed their colleagues from Zimbabwe, Vanuatu and Belize which had become members of the association since their last Meeting, and extended similar greetings to St Vincent and the Grenadines which had become a special member.

4. Heads of Government expressed their deep grief at the death of President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh, President Sir Seretse Khama of Botswana, President Benjamin Henry Sheares of Singapore and Prime Minister Eric Williams of Trinidad and Tobago and recalled their deep commitment and significant contributions to the Commonwealth.

5. Heads of Government recalled with particular satisfaction the Commonwealth's role in helping to bring Zimbabwe to independence under majority rule following their Meeting in Lusaka. They were encouraged by this demonstration of the contribution their Meetings could make to the resolution of long-standing international problems.
World and Commonwealth Trends

6. Heads of Government were conscious that they were meeting at a time when there was a growing sense of insecurity among the people of the world; they expressed grave disquiet at the marked deterioration that had taken place in international relations since their last Meeting. Central to their concern were the slide from detente to confrontation, mounting tension between the Super Powers and the build up of nuclear arms threatening the very survival of mankind. Heads of Government contrasted the increasingly large resources devoted to the manufacture of ever more destructive weapons with the growing inadequacy of the resources available for international economic co-operation and continued inability of the international community to agree on ways and means of alleviating world poverty. They were disturbed that in this situation, which called for new and enlightened policies, there was evidence of a weakening of the spirit of internationalism. They believed their association could help to reverse this trend and contribute to a safer and saner world.

7. Heads of Government asserted the right of all peoples freely to determine their destiny and noted with concern that this right was being denied in widely different circumstances in many parts of the world. They recognised an obligation to work for conditions more conducive to respect for sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity and the right to self-determination.

8. Heads of Government emphasised that as an association of aligned and non-aligned states, the Commonwealth was uniquely well placed to make a substantial contribution to defusing international tensions in a divided world. Believing that it was in the highest interest of the international community that the non-aligned countries should be able to continue to play their constructive role and pursue the policies and principles of non-alignment free of outside pressures, they especially endorsed the role of the non-aligned members of the Commonwealth.
Southern Africa

9. Heads of Government reviewed developments in Southern Africa since their Lusaka Meeting which established the basis for Zimbabwe's independence under majority rule. They affirmed that the Lancaster House Conference and the negotiations which preceded it, demonstrated in a decisive and compelling manner the ability of Commonwealth members to work together to achieve consensus and to make a positive contribution to the resolution of major problems. In this respect they paid tribute to the central role of Britain in facilitating the process which enabled Zimbabwe to take its place as a sovereign independent country in the international community and the Commonwealth.

10. Heads of Government congratulated the Government of Zimbabwe which had earned the respect of the world community and fully justified the trust placed in it by the Commonwealth. Deep concern was expressed that, despite the significant achievement of Zimbabwe's independence, grave problems remained to be resolved in Southern Africa. Heads of Government acknowledged that, in fact, the situation had deteriorated. They recognised the urgent need to find solutions to these unresolved problems and renewed their total commitment to this objective.

11. Heads of Government stressed that at the core of these problems is the apartheid system which the white minority regime in South Africa continues to sustain and strengthen in a variety of ways, including the brutal internal repression of the African majority, the persistent refusal to implement the relevant Security Council resolutions providing for Namibia's long-delayed independence, the pursuit of policies of destabilisation against neighbouring states, the repeated threats to and violations of their territorial integrity and the expansion of South Africa's military capability. They considered that these developments not only threatened the stability of the region but also gravely endangered international peace and security. They therefore called on the international community to strengthen its collective resolve to eradicate apartheid.

12. Recalling their Declaration on Racism and Racial Prejudice proclaimed at Lusaka in 1979, Heads of Government reaffirmed their total and unequivocal condemnation of apartheid as a crime against humanity and their total rejection of all policies designed to perpetuate this inhuman system. They accepted that it was the solemn and urgent duty of each of their Governments vigorously to combat the evil of apartheid by the adoption of effective measures against it and to assist those struggling to rid themselves of it.
13. Heads of Government reaffirmed their Gleneagles Agreement of 1977 and reiterated their commitment to fulfilling effectively their obligations under it.

14. Heads of Government took special account of the efforts of the United Nations to reach universally accepted approaches to the question of sporting contacts within the framework of the international campaign against apartheid. They agreed to redouble their own efforts to secure such international agreement.

15. Heads of Government expressed deep concern that there had been no progress towards the achievement of independence for Namibia. They registered their grave disappointment that the Pre-Implementation meeting in Geneva in January 1981 had been aborted by the refusal of the South African Government to agree to a date for the implementation of Security Council Resolution 435. Heads of Government reaffirmed their determination to ensure that the people of Namibia should be allowed without further delay to exercise their right to self-determination and independence. Mindful of the role being played by the Western Contact Group, which included two of their members, they urged the Group, as a matter of particular urgency, to intensify efforts to secure the implementation of Resolution 435 without modification or dilution as early as possible in 1982.

16. Heads of Government noted that, notwithstanding Security Council Resolution 418 (1977), imposing a mandatory arms embargo against South Africa, the apartheid regime's expenditure on military expansion and nuclear development had increased alarmingly. They therefore called for a full and effective implementation of the arms embargo, including its efficient monitoring, and urged all governments to desist forthwith from any collaboration with South Africa which undermined the implementation of the arms embargo.

17. Heads of Government condemned the South African regime's repeated threats to and violations of the territorial integrity of the States of Southern Africa, in particular its recent invasion and occupation of Angolan territory. They called for an immediate withdrawal of all South African troops from Angola and an end to all such violations. They also condemned any attempt from any quarter to subvert the legitimate government of Angola through interference in the internal affairs of the country. In this connection, they expressed strong solidarity with the Front-Line States. They also expressed the view that African States should be able to pursue their own affairs without interference from any source.

18. In endorsing the report of the Commonwealth Committee on Southern Africa, Heads of Government expressed appreciation for the effective and constructive manner in which the Committee had discharged its responsibilities in the past two years. They authorised the Committee to continue its work and to pay particular attention to developments in Namibia. They noted with approval the important role played by the Commonwealth, both bilaterally and multilaterally, in enhancing the supply of trained manpower for both Zimbabwe and Namibia, and commended the Secretariat for its efficient administration of Commonwealth humanitarian assistance prorammes in this regard.

19. Heads of Government noted that the increasing number of young refugees from South Africa in neighbouring countries was imposing severe burdens on those countries. They therefore approved in principle the recommendations of the Committee for the establishment of a Commonwealth education and training programme for the benefit of these refugees as a concrete manifestation of their concern and reinforcement of their political commitment against apartheid and their support for majority rule in South Africa. They requested the Secretary-General to prepare detailed proposals for establishing such a programme for consideration by Commonwealth governments through the Committee. Heads of Government also welcomed the recent UN/OAU/UNHCR conference on refugees in Africa and expressed appreciation to the participating countries and institutions and urged them to fulfil their pledges made at the conference to help alleviate this grave humanitarian problem.

20. Heads of Government recalled that at their Lusaka Meeting in 1979, they had acknowledged that the persistent problems of Southern Africa were damaging the development efforts of the States of the region which were in great need of further international assistance on a substantial scale. They therefore specially welcomed the establishment of and the progress made by the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCC) aimed particularly at strengthening co-operation among the majority-ruled States in the region and reducing their economic dependence on South Africa. While noting that significant bilateral and multilateral assistance is already being provided to SADCC to which Commonwealth countries are contributing, Heads of Government draw attention to the need for even greater international assistance to meet the emergent needs of SADCC countries.
Afghanistan

21. Heads of Government expressed grave concern at the situation in and around Afghanistan and its implications both for the region's peace and stability and for international security. Although there were differing perceptions about the developments leading to the present situation, Heads of Government were united in calling urgently for a political settlement on the basis of the withdrawal of foreign troops and full respect for the independence, sovereignty, and non-aligned status of Afghanistan and strict observance of the principles of non-intervention and non-interference. They affirmed the right of Afghan refugees to return to their homes in safety and honour. They urged all concerned to work towards a negotiated settlement which would leave the Afghan people free to determine their own future.
South East Asia

22. Heads of Government were gravely concerned by the continuing tension in South East Asia arising especially from the armed conflict in Kampuchea which affected the peace and security of the whole region and if left unchecked would result in the active intervention by major powers in the affairs of the region. They reaffirmed their support for the principles of non-interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states and the inadmissability of the use of force in international relations. They agreed on the urgent need for a comprehensive political settlement which would ensure the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of all states in the region, including Kampuchea. They reaffirmed the right of the people of the region to determine their future free of outside interference, subversion or coercion, and called for the speedy withdrawal of all foreign forces from Kampuchea. Heads of Government endorsed the conclusions of the New Delhi Conference of Foreign Ministers of Non-aligned Countries in this regard. They noted various proposals, decisions and efforts of the various parties concerned directed towards finding an early political settlement of the problem.

23. Urging all states in South East Asia to develop peaceful and friendly relations, Heads of Government noted with approval the efforts being made for the early establishment of a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality in the region, and called on all states to fully support these efforts.
Refugees

24. Heads of Government also noted with concern the problem of Indo-Chinese refugees/illegal immigrants caused by the continuing instability in Indo-China. They expressed their appreciation to countries of first transit burdened with this problem and to the resettlement countries for accepting these refugees/illegal immigrants. They were convinced that the root cause of this problem could be eliminated through a political solution to the conflict in Indo-China. They urged the countries which have the primary responsibility to tackle the problem of illegal departures at source by fostering the establishment of circumstances in which all the people concerned can live in peace and harmony and by co-operating with the UNHCR and resettlement countries to implement the Programme of Orderly Departures.
Cyprus

25. Heads of Government, reaffirming their Lusaka Communique and their decision regarding the Commonwealth Committee on Cyprus, reiterated their support for the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and non-alignment of the Republic of Cyprus and their solidarity with its Government and people. They stressed the importance of respect for the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all Cypriots and called for an end to all foreign intervention and interference in the Republic of Cyprus. While welcoming the resumption of inter-communal talks under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary-General, they expressed their concern that these talks have not yet produced a solution and stressed the need to achieve early progress towards a just and lasting solution, based on the implementation of the relevant United Nations resolutions and the High-level Agreements. They noted that the President of the Republic of Cyprus had once again drawn to their attention his proposal for the total demilitarisation and disarmament of his country, put forward as a significant contribution to the search for a solution to the problem of Cyprus, a member of the Commonwealth.
Zones of Peace

26. Heads of Government noted the trend inherent in the call by the states of various regions represented in the Commonwealth for the creation of zones of peace in their respective regions. They saw this trend as a reflection of the concern of the peoples of those regions to safeguard their political independence and territorial integrity free from interference by extra-regional forces. They undertook to give consideration to requests for support for the establishment and consolidation of new zones of peace.
Latin America and the Caribbean

27. Heads of Government reviewed recent developments in Latin America and the Caribbean and noted that the region had not escaped the vicissitudes and the dangers which beset the international community elsewhere. They upheld the sovereign right of each state to continue to pursue its own political, economic and social development free from all forms of external interference, coercion, intimidation or pressure. Most Heads of Government further called upon the international community to respect and support the wishes of the people of the Caribbean for the Caribbean area to be recognised as a zone of peace.
Belize

28. Heads of Government reviewed developments leading to the independence of Belize. They expressed satisfaction with the role played by the British Government and welcomed its commitment to make adequate provision for the security of Belize. They commended the Commonwealth Ministerial Committee on Belize for the effective manner in which it had discharged its mandate. Noting the continuing threat to the security of Belize in the absence of a final settlement with Guatemala, Heads of Government reaffirmed their full support for the efforts of the Government of Belize to maintain Belize's territorial integrity and to achieve a final resolution of the outstanding issues on the basis of the Heads of Agreement signed in London on 11 March, 1981. They requested the Secretary-General to convene the Committee, whenever necessary, to assist the Government of Belize in finding a lasting settlement in accordance with the Heads of Agreement. They noted the helpful attitude of the United States Government as reflected in its affirmative vote for the Belize resolution in the United Nations General Assembly in 1980 and expressed confidence that this attitude would be maintained.
Guyana

29. Heads of Government expressed their deep concern at the threat to the territorial integrity of Guyana arising from the resuscitation by Venezuela of a claim to more than two-thirds of the territory of Guyana and the steps taken by Venezuela in pursuit of the claim. Noting that the existing boundary was laid down by an international arbitral award in 1899 and accepted by all concerned as a final settlement, they expressed support for Guyana and called for the peaceful settlement of the controversy in accordance with established procedures and with full respect for the sanctity of treaties.
Middle East

30. Heads of Government expressed grave concern that the unresolved problems of the Middle East, especially the central question of Palestine, remained a serious threat to peace and security in the region and throughout the world. They recognised that a just and lasting settlement should be on the basis of the relevant United Nations resolution and recognition of the rights of the Palestinian people, including their inalienable right to a homeland, as well as the right of all States in the region to live in peace within secure borders. Stressing the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination, most Heads of Government affirmed that the Palestinian Liberation Organisation, recognised by a substantial majority of them as the legitimate representative of the Palestinian people, must be involved in negotiations for a settlement.
Mediterranean

31. Heads of Government reiterated their conviction, expressed in the Lusaka Communique of 1979, that the implementation of the Mediterranean Chapter of the Helsinki Final Act would enhance the security of the Mediterranean, Europe and the Middle East and urged its full implementation. They noted the declaration by the Government of the Republic of Malta proclaiming Malta as a neutral State adhering to a policy of non-alignment as an effective contribution to detente, peace and security in the Mediterranean region.
Indian Ocean

32. Heads of Government noted with disappointment that despite the expressed wishes of the littoral and hinterland states there had been a further increase in the military presence of outside powers in the Indian Ocean and a deterioration of peace and security in the area. The concept of the Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace enshrined in the 1971 United Nations Declaration had been gravely undermined by increased military activity on the part of outside powers. They called upon the governments concerned with the pursuit of the objectives of the Declaration to co-operate in steps to remove sources of tension in the area and to make progress towards the creation of the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace. In the belief that the proposed United Nations Conference on the Indian Ocean could contribute positively to the implementation of the Declaration, they expressed the hope that agreement would be reached to convene the Conference at an early date.
South Asia

33. Heads of Government noted with satisfaction that the countries of South Asia had initiated constructive steps with a view to increasing regional co-operation among themselves, thus contributing further to the climate of peace, stability and economic progress in the area.
Poland

34. Heads of Government discussed the situation in Poland. They were concerned that it could have serious implications for the international community as a whole. They considered that the people of Poland should be left to determine their own destiny free from foreign interference.
South Pacific

35. Heads of Government expressed their satisfaction at the resolution of the difficulties which had attended Vanuatu's accession to independence. They agreed that it was vital for the peace and stability of the region that all people of the South Pacific should be given the opportunity to exercise their right to self-determination as laid down in the United Nations Charter. In this regard, they welcomed the decision by the South Pacific Forum to send a mission to France to discuss the future of the French territory of New Caledonia.

36. Heads of Government shared the concern of member governments in the South Pacific over continued nuclear testing in the region. The South Pacific countries were strongly supported in their call for an immediate end to such tests.

37. Heads of Government noted the opposition in the South Pacific region to the proposals for dumping and storage of nuclear waste in the Pacific ocean and the deep concern at the serious ecological and environmental dangers to which member countries could be exposed. In this regard the resolution adopted at the recent meeting of the South Pacific Forum was strongly supported.
Disarmament and Arms Control

38. Heads of Government were profoundly disturbed by the lack of progress in implementing measures of disarmament and arms limitation contained in the Final Document of the UN Special Session on Disarmament held in 1978. They saw this as a particularly serious matter in a situation in which there was mounting tension and lack of confidence amongst states. They agreed that practical measures directed towards nuclear disarmament and the avoidance of all armed conflict, particularly nuclear conflict, must have the highest priority on the international agenda.

39. On that basis they welcomed the decision of the United States and the Soviet Union to reopen theatre nuclear force negotiations and urged the reopening of talks on strategic arms limitation at the earliest possible date. These initiatives pursued in a genuinely constructive spirit would bring renewed hope to the rest of the international community. They would also inspire all concerned to bring a new sense of purpose to their negotiations on specific measures of disarmament and arms control.

40. Heads of Government emphasised the importance of an early conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty as a crucial first step towards the cessation of nuclear weapons tests by all states in all environments.

41. Reaffirming their support for the objective of the Second Disarmament Decade proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly in 1980, Heads of Government considered that the Second Special Session on Disarmament scheduled for 1982 would provide a significant impetus for a process of genuine disarmament particularly in the nuclear field. They expressed their determination to contribute effectively to the success of the Special Session.
Drug Abuse

42. Heads of Government expressed concern at the problem of drug abuse which affects humanity. They recognised its grave danger to national security, stability and resilience. They agreed that this was not only a social problem but that there was also a clear link between drug trafficking and other types of organised crime, including illegal traffic in firearms, which could pose a serious security problem in some countries. They recognised that this menace had the potential to destabilise societies and nations. Heads of Government stressed the need to foster closer co-operation within the framework of international and regional agencies to combat this menace.
Law of the Sea
43. Heads of Government stressed the importance they attached to securing at an early date a comprehensive and widely accepted Convention on the Law of the Sea.

44. They observed that such a Convention would enhance the prospects for peace and security in the world. It would define, inter alia, the rights of coastal states and other users of the sea; assist the rational exploitation and management of the living and non-living resources of the oceans; provide increased protection for the marine environment; give practical effect to the principle that the resources of the seabed beyond national jurisdiction are the common heritage of mankind, and permit all States to participate in the exploitation of those resources, either directly through national operators or indirectly through the Enterprise.

45. Heads of Government noted with satisfaction that negotiations at the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea had reached a very advanced stage, but recorded their disquiet at developments which over the last two sessions, have prevented the Conference from concluding a Convention in 1981. They expressed the hope that the Conference would complete its work in 1982 in accordance with the decision taken at its Tenth Session.
The Melbourne Declaration

46. Recalling their Melbourne Declaration, agreed and issued during their weekend retreat, and recognising the importance of carrying forward the political commitments reflected in it into areas of practical action, Heads of Government approached their consideration of the world economic situation with a deep sense of urgency and practicality. They were determined to help the international community to usher in a new era of constructive economic relations between developed and developing countries, based on interdependence, mutual respect and a shared interest in change.
The World Economy

47. Heads of Government reviewed developments in the world economy and the deterioration in it since they met in Lusaka in 1979. They recognised that they were meeting at a time of economic crisis. Recession was persisting and was accompanied by stubbornly high inflation and rising levels of unemployment and under-employment. Prospects for many developing countries were particularly grim; they were experiencing serious balance-of-payments and debt service problems, further erosion of their terms of trade, acute poverty, hunger and malnutrition. Heads of Government stressed the global character of the problems facing the contemporary world and expressed their firm belief that domestic policies to counter these problems needed to be supplemented by collective action and a global approach. They noted that the growing interdependence of the world economy rendered it imperative that urgent action be taken to deal with the economic problems of both developed and developing countries, with special attention being paid to the needs of the Least Developed Countries which were engaged in a desperate struggle for survival.

48.
