Heads of Government reaffirmed their conviction that the persistence of widespread poverty underlined the importance of promoting rapid economic growth and development and of pursuing necessary structural and institutional changes in international economic relations, in order to create a more equitable economic order. In approaching the critical issues, they took account of the analysis and recommendations made by the Reports of the Brandt Commission and the Commonwealth Group of Experts. They noted with satisfaction the international recognition accorded to the report of the Commonwealth Group of Experts which they had commissioned at their Lusaka Meeting.

49. Heads of Government were conscious of the significance of their Meeting for the outcome of the Cancun Summit. They believed that the issues to be considered had major implications for the recovery of the world economy as well as for relations between developed and developing countries. They expressed the hope that Cancun would make a bold start by putting international economic co-operation on a new and constructive course; and that it would unequivocally reaffirm the commitment to Global Negotiations, thus giving a much needed political impetus to those negotiations. They resolved to make every effort to remove obstacles to an early start to the Global Negotiations.

50. Heads of Government noted that the Global Round of Negotiations would cover wide fields and could be a time-consuming process. At the same time, they recognised the need for immediate and effective action in such critical areas as trade, energy, food and money and finance, and called on leaders of all countries, without prejudice to the Global Round of Negotiations, to join them in commitment to such action.

51. Heads of Government noted the conclusions on North/South issues at the Ottawa Summit of industrialised countries, and expressed the hope that the attention given to those issues at Ottawa would be advanced at Cancun. They requested participating colleagues to provide to other Commonwealth governments, through the Secretary-General, their assessment of the Cancun meeting.

52. Heads of Government noted that co-operation among developing countries was a growing and welcome element in international relations. They urged that this process should be appropriately facilitated and supported so that it might make its due contribution to the resolution of the problems affecting the global economy.

53. Heads of Government noted that lack of progress in negotiations between developed and developing countries resulted in part from obstacles in the negotiating process itself. They requested the Secretary-General to convene a high level group to study and report on the issues involved.
Financial Issues

54. Heads of Government attached high priority to the resolution of current problems in the financial and monetary fields, and stressed the urgent need to restore world economic growth and curb inflation. They noted that financial markets were unsettled; interest rates had reached unprecedented levels; exchange rates were subject to severe, and often disruptive, fluctuations; and there were pervasive and persistent imbalances in international payments. In an interdependent world, the resolution of these problems required greater co-ordination and co-operation on economic policy. They called upon all governments, particularly the major economic powers, to show greater concern for the repercussions of their policies on other countries; and, in the context of promoting economic recovery, to give urgent consideration to measures to bring stability to the financial and exchange markets and reduce upward pressure on interest rates.

55. In the light of the critical economic situation facing many developing countries, Heads of Government emphasised the need to increase official development assistance, particularly to the least developed and other disadvantaged countries. They welcomed the decision of some countries to increase levels of official development assistance and called upon all industrialised countries which have not already done so, to reach the internationally agreed targets as soon as possible. They also called upon the developed centrally planned countries to substantially increase their development assistance. They noted the decision at the recent UN Conference on Least Developed Countries in Paris to make additional resources available to these countries. The prospects for flows of concessional assistance to these and other low-income countries had been adversely affected by delay and uncertainty regarding IDA VI. They expressed the firm hope that the funding of IDA VII would be placed on a sounder footing. They attached importance to program lending, including support for structural adjustment, and agreed that there was a case for a significant increase in such lending. They noted the prevalence of tied aid, which can distort the priorities of recipient countries, and urged all donor countries to give aid as far as possible in untied forms.

56. Heads of Government recognised the substantial contribution that multilateral institutions had made to economic development, and emphasised the major role they should play in expanding the flow of resources to developing countries. They agreed to make special efforts to ensure that progress in strengthening the resources of these institutions would not falter at this critical time. They stressed the need for these institutions to avoid political and ideological considerations in determining their operational policies.

57. Heads of Government recognised the role of private non-concessional flows, including direct investment, in facilitating development and stressed the continuing need for adequate financial mechanisms for the recycling of surplus funds. They noted that the commercial banking system had performed well in recycling funds; however, in their view, it might not be able to do so in future at levels and on conditions that would not impose intolerable debt service burdens. They agreed that international financial institutions should play an expanding role in the recycling process. In this connection they drew attention to the proposal of the Commonwealth Group of Experts for the establishment of appropriate guarantee facilities which would enable surplus funds to be channelled to developing countries on appropriate terms, including longer maturities. The present financial difficulties of developing countries were such that they required innovative approaches. Among other measures, Heads of Government called for consideration to be given to increased use of mechanisms such as export credit insurance and the exchange of commodities on a barter basis.
Trade and Protectionism

58. Heads of Government expressed their anxiety over the trend towards increased protectionism. Aware of the importance of expansion of world trade to economic recovery and growth, they agreed that governments should make further efforts to reduce tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade and to achieve international agreement on effective rules covering resort to emergency safeguards. They noted that little progress had been made in eliminating quantitative restrictions against certain categories of manufactured exports of particular importance to developing countries. They noted also that the process of reducing barriers to trade in agricultural products had scarcely begun. The export of processed commodities continued to be constrained by trade barriers which escalate with the degree of processing. They welcomed the proposal for a Ministerial Meeting of the GATT and urged the Contracting Parties of the GATT to take a positive decision to convene the Ministerial Meeting in 1982 to consider these and other problems of trade faced by all countries.

59. In view of their strong interest in the issues involved and in order to assist the deliberations, Heads of Government requested the Secretary-General to commission a group of independent high-level Commonwealth experts to investigate the impact of protection on developing country trade and report in time to assist governments in their preparations for the proposed GATT Ministerial Meeting. They agreed the group would examine the effects of protection on developing countries, including the impact of tariff and non-tariff barriers on industrial and agricultural products. In this respect the group should consider, inter alia, the question of emergency safeguards, and non-conventional measures which, among other things, include such matters as voluntary export restraints and orderly marketing arrangements; structural adjustment; the escalation of tariffs and trade barriers that constrain the expansion of trade in processed commodities; and the adequacy of existing arrangements for the settlement of disputes.
Commodities

60. Heads of Government noted that unstable prices and declining terms of trade were having an adverse effect on commodity-exporting developing countries, especially at a time of recession. They welcomed the agreement to establish the Common Fund and noted that progress made to secure its implementation had been slow. They urged all governments which had not done so to take urgent action to sign and ratify the Agreement to enable the Fund to become operational as early as possible and to contribute to its Second Account. They took note of the limited progress made in establishing effective international commodity agreements and urged governments to intensify their efforts to establish such agreements. They asked the Secretariat to give priority to identifying ways and means to expand processing in developing countries and to measures to maintain and improve commodity export earnings, and also to study the need for the adoption of a global scheme for the stabilisation of commodity export earnings.
Energy

61. Heads of Government re-affirmed their conviction that the energy situation required short, medium and long-term measures to be undertaken within the framework of wider international economic co-operation. Such a policy must ensure adequate returns to exporters of oil and secure supplies to consumers. Oil prices should be set in such a way as to avoid sudden major increases, and at levels which would encourage production and conservation. Within this framework, immediate consideration should be given to devising special arrangements to meet the energy needs of low-income countries facing difficult balance of payments problems. They welcomed the concessional arrangements for the purchase of oil introduced by several oil exporting countries including Commonwealth members, Nigeria and Trinidad and Tobago, for designated groups of developing countries and urged that consideration be given to their wider application.

62. Heads of Government emphasised the urgent need to devote sufficient resources for the development of conventional and new and renewable energy sources. They recognised that some progress had been made at the UN Conference on New and Renewable Sources of Energy held in Nairobi, and that some governments had offereed to provide increased assistance for energy development. They noted in this connection, however, that there was no agreement on an appropriate multilateral financing mechanism. Mindful of the large increase in investment required for energy development in developing countries, they called for substantial additional multilateral provision of resources supported by both the industrialised and oil-exporting developing countries for the development of conventional and non-conventional energy sources. In this regard they supported the proposal for the establishment of an energy affiliate within the World Bank.

63. Heads of Government underlined the importance of meeting the technical assistance requirements of Commonwealth developing countries in energy development, particularly in respect of programs to disseminate technology and to provide the necessary training facilities. In this context they noted the proposal under examination for a Centre for Research and Development on new and renewable sources of energy within the United Nations system. They believed that the Commonwealth could play an expanded role in providing technical assistance for the development of conventional and non-conventional energy in Commonwealth countries. They asked the Secretary-General to examine the possibility of strengthening Commonwealth efforts in this field.

64. They noted with interest the work that was being done through the Commonwealth Regional Renewable Energy Resources Information System (CRRERIS). This system, which was established as a result of a decision of the New Delhi Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting, made available information on renewable energy technology. In this context they welcomed the Australian Government's offer to make available to all Commonwealth countries, information and experience through the CRRERIS.
Food Problem

65. Heads of Government were disturbed by the continuing precarious state of world food security and the persistent food shortages in many developing countries. An urgent need was a dependable system of world food security. They agreed to make greater efforts to secure the early establishment of an international grains arrangement with effective economic provisions which would safeguard the interests of both exporting and importing countries while recognising the special needs of developing countries, to reach agreed food aid targets and to provide adequate food reserves, including emergency reserves. They also emphasised the importance of replenishing the resources of the International Fund for Agricultural Development and the World Food Program to levels necessary to enable them to discharge their functions effectively.

66. Heads of Government recognised that the ultimate solution to the world food problem lay in greater food self-sufficiency in developing countries. They stressed the importance of measures to provide essential agricultural inputs on reasonable terms. They emphasised further the special importance of appropriate domestic policies and strategies including the pricing and marketing of agricultural products.

67. Heads of Government endorsed the recommendations of the Commonwealth Ministerial Meeting on Food Production and Rural Development held in February 1981 in Dacca. They recognised that the Commonwealth should mobilise its resources and experience to assist its developing members, and act as a catalyst for effective use of wider international assistance. They agreed that there was need for an enlarged Commonwealth role in agricultural project identification, preparation and management, the management of fisheries resources, the preparation of food strategies, training, improvements in food storage, the reduction of post-harvest losses, and ensuring the increased participation of women in food production. They requested the Secretary-General to give priority to work in these areas through technical assistance activities in response to requests from member governments, and welcomed offers of additional financial and institutional assistance from Commonwealth Governments.

68. Heads of Government welcomed the decision of the Australian Government to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and the decisions of the Canadian Government to establish an International Centre for Ocean Development and a training program for agricultural extension workers which would reflect the important role of women in agricultural production. They recognised that these initiatives would contribute to the effectiveness of an enlarged Commonwealth food production program.
Regionalism

69. Heads of Government recognised the dynamic character of regionalism of which the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCC) was the most recent manifestation. They noted with satisfaction the support provided by Commonwealth countries and the Secretariat for regional efforts and agreed that they should continue to assist regional and interregional co-operation.

70. Heads of Government noted in particular the useful contribution made to Commonwealth co-operation by the Meetings in Sydney in 1978 and in New Delhi in 1980 of Commonwealth Heads of Government in the Asia/Pacific region. They noted that the Meetings had significantly contributed to co-operation and had become established as useful and regular forums for exchanges between Commonwealth countries of the region. They further noted the important areas in which practical co-operation between members had commenced-namely trade, energy, industry, and combating terrorism and the traffic in illicit drugs.
Island Developing and Other Specially Disadvantaged Countries

71. Heads of Government discussed the special problems faced by developing and other specially disadvantaged member countries. They noted with concern the particularly difficult economic and trading situation which currently faced small, poor states because of their limited human and natural resource endowment, small size and specific transport and energy problems. It was agreed that these countries needed special measures of support.
72. The importance of measures to assist island states in developing their resources within their Exclusive Economic Zones was recognised as being of crucial importance to their development efforts.

73. Heads of Government noted that the Special Action Programme approved in Lusaka had been of some benefit to these countries but that much more needed to be done within the Commonwealth and on a bilateral basis to help alleviate the problems of these states. Heads of Government noted the offer by the Government of Australia to fund appropriate facilities in New York to enable Pacific island states not presently represented to maintain representation at the United Nations. They also noted the initiative within the Pacific to establish a regional advisory service. The Governments concerned agreed to consult to formulate more detailed proposals.
74. Heads of Government requested the Secretariat in consultation with member countries to strengthen further Commonwealth assistance to small island and other disadvantaged member countries.
Women and Development

75. Heads of Government noted with satisfaction the establishment of a unit on Women and Development in accordance with the decision reached at their Lusaka Meeting. The unit was already doing valuable work, especially in the smaller states and in helping to upgrade the status and broaden the experience of those working in women's bureaux. Recalling that this unit was established to advance the interests of women in the Commonwealth through exchanges of experience, training programmes and other activities, they expressed the hope that its services should be used increasingly by government agencies as well as by non-governmental organisations which are concerned with matters of interest to women. It was recognised that if women are to benefit from Secretariat activities, governments wil need both to ensure their inclusion as participants in conferences and workshops and actively to search out suitable candidates for scholarships and training programmes.
International Year of Shelter for the Homeless

76. Heads of Government noted with satisfaction the proposal made by the United Nations Commission on Human Settlements at the meeting held in Manila in April 1981 for an International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, and the recommendation made by the Economic and Social Council at its meeting in July 1981 to declare 1987 as the International Year. Heads of Government expressed their support for this recommendation.
International Year of Disabled Persons

77. Heads of Government acknowledged that their Meeting was taking place in the International Year of Disabled Persons, and noted the related activities being conducted by the Commonwealth Secretariat and by member governments.
CFTC

78. Heads of Government, reaffirming that the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation should be assured of the resources required to exploit the many comparative advantages of Commonwealth functional co-operation, welcomed the arrangements for the Fund's restoration, replenishment and governance, made by its Board of Representatives. In particular, they agree that the level of activities carried out by the CFTC should be restored by 1983-84 to the level attained in 1978-79 as a basis for future growth, and expressed their satisfaction that indications from major and minor contributors suggested that the necessary resources would be made available over this three-year period.

79. In order to foster wider awareness of the Commonwealth among its peoples and as a contribution towards the financial stability of the CFTC, Heads of Government agreed in principle to the proposal for a special Commonwealth stamp issue every five years. Stressing the necessity of every Commonwealth country participating, they authorised the Secretary-General to prepare, for consideration by governments, detailed plans for the first issue which would commemorate Commonwealth Day in 1983.
Commonwealth Youth Programme

80. Heads of Government noted with pleasure that the Commonwealth Youth Programme had continued to make a valuable contribution to the development of national youth policies and programmes and expressed satisfaction with the results of the restructuring of the Programme requested by them at Lusaka in 1979. They stressed the importance of ensuring that the Programme's resources should not be allowed to fall below their present level if the current planned level of activities is to be sustained. To this end, Heads of Government agreed to endeavour to maintain the value of their contributions in real terms.
Commonwealth Foundation

81. Heads of Government expressed satisfaction with the valuable work of the Commonwealth Foundation and approved the recommendation of its Board of Trustees that the Foundation be accorded the status of an international organisation by the host government. Noting with appreciation that the budgetary target approved in Lusaka in 1979 had almost been reached, they agreed that governments should endeavour to maintain this level of funding for the present.

82. Heads of Government expressed their warm appreciation to the retiring Chairman, Sir Adetokunbo Ademola of Nigeria, for his services to the Foundation over the last four years. They appointed Dr Muhammad Abdur Rashid of Bangladesh as the new Chairman.
Human Rights

83. Heads of Government considered the Report of the Commonwealth Working Party on Human Rights and reaffirmed the importance which all Commonwealth governments attached to the observance of human rights. They urged those governments which have not yet done so to accede to relevant global and regional instruments on human rights. They endorsed in principle the recommendations of the Working Party concerning the establishment of a special unit in the Secretariat for the promotion of human rights within the Commonwealth, subject to agreement being reached on the appropriate method of financing the unit. They requested the Secretary-General to consult further with member governments on an agreed definition of human rights within the Commonwealth context as well as of the unit's functions. They took note of the Working Party's proposals for an Advisory Committee for the protection and maintenance of human rights and asked that these should be further considered by the next meeting of Commonwealth Law Ministers.
Student Mobility

84. Heads of Government reaffirmed that student mobility and educational interchange within the Commonwealth were important to the national development efforts of Commonwealth countries and to maintaining Commonwealth links. While noting the factors contributing to the situation, they recognised that there was widespread and serious concern that the recent very substantial increases in overseas student fees in some countries were creating impediments to the movement of students and teachers between member countries. They expressed their appreciation of the Report of the Consultative Group on Student Mobility within the Commonwealth and urged that early and sympathetic consideration be given to the implementation of its recommendations.
Communication and the Media

85. Heads of Government welcomed the Report of the Commonwealth Committee on Communication and the Media. They expressed satisfaction with the operation of the Commonwealth Media Exchange Fund and noted the Secretariat's proposals to broaden the scope of its application. They noted with appreciation the contributions by the Governments of Australia and Britain to the Fund and welcomed offers of additional support from other governments.
Culture
86. Heads of Government expressed appreciation of the work of the Commonwealth Institute and commended it to all member countries.
Commonwealth Employment/Labour Ministers Meeting

87. Heads of Government noted a proposal by the Commonwealth Trade Union Council for a meeting of Commonwealth Employment/Labour Relations Ministers at the time of the International Labour Conference, and requested the Secretary-General to make arrangements for such a meeting in 1982.
Report of the Secretary-General
88. Heads of Government commended the Eighth Report of the Secretary-General and noted with appreciation the progress made in various areas of Commonwealth activity since their last Meeting.
Next Meeting

89. Heads of Government, recognising the growing contribution which the Commonwealth is capable of making to the solution of world problems, reaffirmed the importance which they attach to their biennial meetings and the opportunity which such meetings provide for consultations aimed at forging a consensus on some of the major issues facing the world.
90. Heads of Government accepted with pleasure the invitation of the Government of India to hold their next Meeting in India.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following paper:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-Ministerial Statement, 13 October 1981.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from speaking for a period not exceeding 21 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the eight-day $20m Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting has concluded in Melbourne. I have stated on record many times in this House and outside my views about the Commonwealth. I do not propose to go over them again. I remind honourable members, however, that there has been, unreservedly, commendation of the role of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in relation to the settlement in Zimbabwe. That commendation stands in spite of the querulous comments made by some other members of the Commonwealth in the course of the past couple of weeks which found their way into the media.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that probably the most significant spectacle to occur in this country in the post-war period has been completed. There is no disputing the conscientious nature of the declarations which were constructed by members of that conference and one does not in any way quibble about the hope, as distinct from the optimism, which rests behind those declarations. I stress the difference between 'hope' and 'optimism'. I suspect that, for the developing countries of the world, optimism is a quality that has long run out of any momentum. It is now more a matter of hope. Even hope recedes in the face of events internationally. The United States of America, the most powerful economy in the world, has declared that there will be tougher responses by it, through pressures applied to international institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in relation to the provision of aid for developing countries. That is scarcely an encouraging prospect.
The Opposition endorses the tough statements opposing racism, commercial imperialism, unequalled trade and development relations and interference in the domestic affairs of developing countries.

Indeed, there has never been any dispute about these matters on the part of the Opposition. However, there has in the past been conflict between members of the conservative coalition parties, in government and the opposition, and the Labor Party on these issues. We commend the Prime Minister on this recent conversion. Late as it is, it is just as welcome. We defend his declarations, in spite of the open hostility of a large number of back bench members of the Government towards the views he puts. We agree in relation to Namibia and Poland, the need for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan and Kampuchea, and the right of African nations to exercise their sovereign independence and be free from outside interference.

We endorse the need for urgent action on the law of the sea and the views of the South Pacific countries, endorsed by the communique from Melbourne, that nuclear testing ought to be ended in that area of the world. It is a pity that the Prime Minister did not evidence as much enthusiasm on this matter when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised it in this Parliament. It is not now a case of easing back into the big comfortable chair in the corner, suffused with the warm inner glow of having achieved something. Now is the time for action. Over the decades in the post-war period there have been too many instances of major international conferences carrying quite moving and impressive motions of intent and commitment after which there has been no real action. If rhetoric were gold there would be an avalanche of riches tumbling on all the Third World countries today from the preceding fortnight in Melbourne.

I shall illustrate the point about hope and optimism. I came to the Parliament in 1961. We were then in the full flush of enthusiasm about the decade of development. It was said that within 10 years one per cent of the world's gross domestic product from the developed countries of the world would be transported through a redistributional process to the developing countries. The formulations were exciting. The prospects were ecstatic. Within a decade the developing countries of the world would be very largely at the take-off stage, some well beyond that. The problem of world poverty would be receding. This has never happened. In spite of so many instances of declarations of intent in the succeeding years and the formulation of grand and exciting international policies for the amelioration of the difficulties of developing countries in the world the progress has been dismally, disappointingly slow.

There can be no quibbling about the Australian Labor Party as a democratic socialist party being firmly committed to mechanisms which will lead sensibly and practically to the redistribution of wealth and opportunity in the world from the well-off nations to the less well-off nations. Having said that, I repeat that there must be action to follow up what has been transacted in rhetoric at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne. One approaches this matter with some reservation as to just what may happen when one reads in the media criticisms expressed by leaders of Commonwealth countries as to what will be achieved. The Prime Minister of Vanuatu, Father Lini, expressed reservations, according to the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 October, about the way in which the Melbourne Declaration had been drafted for the Commonwealth meeting. He said that he would agree slightly with the New Zealand Prime Minister that the announcement of the Declaration had perhaps been premature. In fact he was saying more than that. Mr Seaga of Jamaica said that he thought that the Declaration was, quite frankly, a waste of time. Mr Mahathir, the new Prime Minister of Malaysia, in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 25 September, said:
I feel that we can achieve more here in the country than at such meetings which are just talk and very little progress.
The Prime Minister of Fiji, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, said CHOGM had been full of good philosophies and good intentions, but very little action. He went on to say:
What is glaring, however, is that we have done very little to find effective solutions.

They are only a small selection of the reservations which are being expressed by leaders of Commonwealth countries who participated. In the circumstances, it is not unreasonable for people such as myself to express concern that this may be a duplicated exercise similar to so many exercises internationally in the past when grant declarations were carried and the resulting follow-up, at best, limited.

There are two key thrusts by which Australia will be judged as to whether its credentials are genuine-aid and trade. Whilst there is no dispute between this side of the House and the Government in relation to the condemnation which the Prime Minister properly and persistently expresses on racism in Southern Africa-he persists with that condemnation in spite of the efforts of some of his colleagues on the back bench to undermine him-there are vast differences between the Government, the conservatives, and the democratic socialist Labor Party on the issues of aid and trade. Australia will be seen to stand or fall on these two issues. It will be seen either as a bellows, constantly gushing out windy platitudes, or, if substantial practical action follows that conference, a forge for reshaping world attitudes, policies and commitments to the lesser developed countries.

Let us look at aid under this 'progressive reform Government inspired by the Prime Minister'. I put all that in inverted commas to show the appropriately clumsy irony which covers it. Let us look at Australia's performance. In 1975 the then Labor Government expended 0.65 per cent of gross domestic product on official development aid. We were on the threshold of fulfilling our commitment to be one of the few countries in the world providing 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product as official development aid. What has the average been since? It has been 0.45 per cent of gross domestic product. Let me put that into measurable terms, quantifiable dimensions. If the Fraser Government had maintained the level of spending on official development aid that the Labor Government had established by 1975, even if it had forgone the objective we set ourselves of reaching the United Nations declared target of 0.7 per cent and had just stuck to the point we had reached, it would have spent $1,720m more in its five Budgets than it actually spent. This year, to buy off a little pressure and to use lucre to try to get a bit of respectability back and when moralising on this issue the Prime Minister said: 'We will provide an extra $100m for official development aid.' He did not do it last year, the year before, the year before that or the two years before that, but he proposed it this year as the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting was to be held in Australia. The public and international observers are justified in being cynical about the motivation. Let me amplify that. Even by providing the extra $100m, he still falls more than $300m below the level that would have been provided if 0.65 per cent of gross domestic product had been the commitment of the Government consistently throughout its term of office since 1975. There is no commitment by the Prime Minister in terms of a concrete timetable that within a specified period we will provide, according to our commitment to the United Nations objective, 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product in official development aid. A Labor government would do so and it would do so within one term of Parliament. We would firmly commit ourselves to the second step of official development aid-that is, one per cent of gross domestic product-by, at the latest, 1990.

How good is the Government's record? How genuine can it be regarded in relation to the North-South dialogue which, I point out to honourable members, is a softer proposition than the new international economic order? The new international economic order proposes a series of hard international reforms. Some of them would have practical difficulties but overall they would make a valuable contribution to alleviating the difficulties of developing countries. I refer to an article by Neil Dias Karunaratne entitled 'Australia and the Challenge of the New International Economic Order.' He said:
Australia, after much vacillation in 1978, gave its support to the Common Fund (CF) for establishing buffer stocks after the United States gave its assent to the CF in principle.

That is, we had to wait for the Americans to send us a letter by air mail telling us that it was appropriate to support the Common Fund. The Fraser Government could not make an independent determination on the matter. Mr Karunaratne went on:
Australia's financial commitment to the CF as a trade-weighted GNP ratio would be only US$25 million or 0.4 per cent of the initial US$6 billion required to set up the CF.

We were not exactly busting ourselves. Therefore, it is difficult to comprehend why there was such opposition initially to giving support to the proposition and then subsequently such reluctance to moving with celerity towards a conclusion to this. I tell the House why we ought to move with celerity-because there are advantages for Australia as a primary producer. I quote again from the article, which states:
Australia, which is a primary producer par excellence, receives nearly 70 per cent-
Nearly 70 per cent, mark this-
of her export earnings through primary commodities. The benefits that would accrue to Australia by implementing commodity stabilisation schemes are enormous.

I suggest that on our record we do not stand too well in relation to this sort of matter. What it boils down to is the fundamental philosophical difference between conservatives in the coalition parties and radicals in a democratic socialist party like ours. We believe in government intervention because we do not believe that the market forces, certainly not internationally, work in a fair and regular way. We have transnational corporations dominating more than a third of the world trade, and something like another third of the world trade being regulated by international cartels. Market forces certainly do not operate internationally when the rate of real price increases for the products of industrialised countries far outstrips the rate of price increase for the produce of developing countries. That means those countries have to work harder. They have to produce greater volumes of their commodities to buy the tractor they need or to buy the pump they require for water redistribution. The Government is opposed to that sort of intervention. Is there a quibble about it? I quote the remarks of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 29 November 1979 when he was giving an assessment of the new international economic order and extolling the virtues of the Treasury's view. The Treasurer's Press release states:
The Treasury paper suggests that to approach the subject in these terms-
That is, endorsing it-

is to misunderstand the fundamentals of economic development and the economic interests of developing countries themselves, including the benefits to be obtained from an interdependent international economic system. The thrust of the paper's argument is that the proposals for an NIEO, and the thinking on which they are based, generally represent-
Mark this-
an inappropriate and misconceived approach to the problem of raising standards of living in developing countries . . .

The Treasurer went on to condemn the new international economic order proposals for emphasising government intervention rather than the operation of market forces. I do not have enough time to quote fully this significant extract from a document by the Treasurer. It explains the hypocritical, sanctimonious posturing of certain members of the Government. On their record they have been seen to be abysmal and on their statements they have shown a flat opposition to the sorts of things that the Prime Minister is now trying to moralise upon.

Let us look at the actions of the Prime Minister on things like debt relief. The disasters in the past two decades have been caused, firstly, by the way in which the Johnson Administration in America sought to pay for the ill-conceived Vietnam commitment by printing bank notes, which flooded the world with liquidity, which forced up inflation, which undermined the economies of, indeed, all countries of the world but particularly the non-oil producing developing ones. That resulted in prices in the member nations of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries going up to offset inflation. It was not because the Arabs were scoundrels, albeit commercial scoundrels. They had to face the fact that in real terms American economic policies were disastrous for them.

Now in the wake of all this we have the highest real interest rates in the world. The burden of interest rate repayments is more crippling for developing countries than any other single economic pressure contemporaneously or in the recent past. Why does the Government not talk about that? Why does it not commit itself to a mandatory code on the conduct of transnational corporations, on a common fund, and push ahead with it in a determined fashion? It received the okay in 1977. It has not proceeded much farther since. We have not heard about the allocation of special drawing rights, two-thirds of which go to the developed and the oil producing countries and the least of which go to the developing countries which have the greatest need.

We have heard no discussion about the nonsense of the 'trickle down' effect in developing countries' economies, the idea that strong economic development in developed countries, especially by major capital investment programs, will automatically lead to a vast improvement in the economies of those countries and then the benefits will trickle down. The only countries in the developing part of the world where this has happened have been countries where there has been direct intervention-Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea, to mention the four of them. For the rest of the world the evidence is, in fact, that real per capita income for people has gone back.
There is posturing on the issue of trade. Let me remind honourable members? On 9 May 1979 at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Manila the Prime Minister said:
What we must do now is to look beyond the MTN towards the reduction of barriers of all sorts to the freer flow of goods.

He went on with this ringing declaration of virtue. Only a few weeks later on 16 July in this Parliament, we had a statement from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), a report of which stated:

The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Phillip Lynch, and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Wal Fife, announced today that the Government had decided to extend by one year the current three-year program of assistance for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

There is a fundamental conflict in what he was talking about. Only a few weeks after that initial UNCTAD declaration, honourable members will recall, the Treasurer came into this House with a packet of interim economic measures, one of which was to impose Customs duties on all imports to this country where Customs duties did not apply already. The CHOGM paper which was circulated by the Government states that there had been a 40 per cent reduction in nominal assistance to manufacturing industry between 1968-69 and 1978-79 and that there had been a 12 per cent reduction since 1973-74. A 70 per cent effective reduction in protection between 1968-69 and 1973-74 took place in 1973-74 due to a 25 per cent tariff cut, for which the then Labor Government was responsible. The movement in protection subsequently has been appallingly small-no more than a couple of percentage points. The significance of that is that the Prime Minister said in opposing this:
For every additional car, every additional washing machine and every additional television set that comes into Australia, Australians are being put out of work.

I accept that there has to be a restructuring in manufacturing industry but it has to be done sensibly. But the crude broad axing of tariffs is not the solution. We will be better off if we have more export oriented industries. But the Prime Minister is the man whom I am seeking to nail on this for his double standards, inconsistency and, frankly, for the sanctimonious nonsense and hypocrisy we have seen on an unparalleled scale in this Parliament. On his record he cannot be believed as having a genuine commitment to the aid and trade needs of the developing countries of this world.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sainsbury) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.3 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate will be allowed covering this Bill, the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill and the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trust and Superannuation Funds) Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was reminding the House that one of the functions of these Bills is to provide for half indexation of personal tax rates for the current financial year-in other words, to provide a reduction in the rate of tax which would have applied had there been, of course, no tax indexation. There is no doubt that in the following year there will be a need for reductions in the rates of income tax if, in fact, a similar or even better concession is to be introduced next year. The important thing we must realise is that the activities of the Government in recent times has, in fact, enabled such significant concessions to be allowed in the following year without disrupting the economy after a very difficult six years because there is no doubt that reductions in income taxes can flow only from either cuts in government spending or a switching to other taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Bills include, as I said, provision for a reduction in the rates of income tax for the current year as a result of the part indexation of tax. But, of course, much more is needed and, I trust, will take place next year. There is now an early prospect of achieving these further reductions, but only because of the achievements which we have managed in the last few years. When people complain about the rate of tax, I think I have demonstrated that, in effect, their complaints are fairly unrealistic in relation to the rest of the world in particular. I think we have to realise that the total government tax revenue in the current fnancial year as a result of the Bills that we are now discussing will rise only by about 5.3 per cent in real terms after we take inflation into account. That is the lowest rise for three years. Certainly, of course, it is far lower than the rises in real terms that took place in two of the Australian Labor Party's three Budgets. The same situation, of course, goes for the indirect taxes which I mentioned earlier where, in fact, the increase of 3.7 per cent in real terms in the current Budget is far lower than the 5.1 per cent of the previous year. The 3.7 per cent rise, even after taking increased sales tax into account, is the lowest rise in indirect taxes for four years.

It seems extraordinary that we have had this massive campaign alleging huge and disruptive increases in indirect taxes, particularly through the sales tax, when, in fact, this year's rise is to be the lowest, in real terms, in four years for indirect taxes, and for total tax revenue is to be the lowest real rise for three years. So, it does put in a real perspective the absolute rubbish being talked in the tax debate in this country about what has really happened to taxes under the present Government. I should stress also, of course, that the latest rise in indirect taxes of only 3.7 per cent in real terms, compares to, say, an 8 per cent rise in real indirect taxes in Mr Hayden's last Budget as Treasurer in 1975. In other words, the rate of rises in indirect taxes in the current year is less than half what it was under the Labor Party's last Budget. Yet, honourable members opposite come into this place and cry crocodile tears about the impact of indirect taxes. What a load of bunkum.

The other prospect that we have of reducing taxes is if we can, in fact, hold down government spending. There is no doubt that rises in government spending have been held down dramatically, having been cut under the present Government by 84 per cent from Labor's average rise in its three years in office. I think people do not realise, when they talk about this Government being a big government, that really what they are talking about is not any increases in spending by this Government but really increases in revenue to make up the enormous gap between revenue and expenditure that developed during the Labor years. While the Fraser Government's spending has gone up only by a total of $1.5 billion in six years in constant terms-that is, in 1974 dollars-its revenue has had to rise by three times as much in order to close the gap when Labor increased its spending by a massive $2.1 billion more than the revenue it raised, so opening up a deficit that caused inflationary chaos in Australia.

It is true that our tax revenues have risen under the present Government. They had to in order to pay the Whitlam bill, to close the gap that, at last, closed in the current Budget after six year. But only one-third of this revenue rise of $4.5 billion in 1974 terms-that is, constant dollars-over the six years of the Fraser Government's Budgets has gone to finance $1.5 billion of the Government's own spending. The remaining two-thirds-that is the rest of all this revenue-of the enormous revenue rise has had to go to pay the Whitlam bill. So, the present Government, in tax terms, has had all the pain of collecting the money that should have been collected along with the enormous rises in spending of the previous government and has had very little of the pleasure involved in handing the money out to the people and in financing its own undertakings or its own projects for the people of Australia. Only one-third of its total revenue rises has gone to finance its own capacity to provide money to the people. Two-thirds has had to pay the bill that the Whitlam Government refused to pay when it brought its favours without paying the bill.

It is extraordinary that many people, including, for example, some at the Sydney Morning Herald, have accused the Government of being a big spending government when, in fact, on the basis of the enormous revenue it has had to collect, that revenue has gone to pay other people's bills. The significant thing is that these bills are now paid. Next year we will have the capacity to introduce cuts in income taxes, provided, of course, a fair degree of our revenue is fed through indirect taxes. As I pointed out before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, there is nothing immoral, indecent, obscene or unfair about indirect taxes. Pensioners, as I said, will be totally protected-in fact, doubly protected-against sales tax rises because of automatic indexation to rises in the cost of living which we, in fact, introduced for pensioners.

I will concede, however, that there are some problems in the tax situation. On these I think I am inclined to disagree with the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) in his reasoned speech. He said that he did not agree with the mining industry which is most concerned about some sections of the changes in the mining taxation. I make the point that there have been continual changes in the situation affecting the mining industry in the rates of depreciation. It seems to be most unfortunate to impose on an industry this kind of continual change and particularly on an industry which is required to plan many years in advance when it undertakes a major mining project. On a similar basis I am concerned about the retrospective impact of some of the sales tax changes in the anomalies list. I am not referring to sales taxes that will affect things like clothing, footwear and so on which, I have demonstrated, are not unfair to lower income groups at all and certainly are not unfair to pensioners who will be totally protected from them because of their cost of living adjustments. I am concerned, however, about retrospectivity in the sense that many items had been ordered and largely paid for but not delivered within some of the anomaly sales tax corrections. There are, in fact, people who will face enormous additional costs because of, I think, an unintentional impact of the sales tax rates. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) who preceded me in this debate used this trilogy of Bills to provide himself with a platform from which he could again expound the discredited opinions that he has expressed tonight and on previous occasions in relation to sales tax. The honourable member for Macarthur has claimed that lower income earners within the community pay a smaller proportion of their income in the form of sales tax because, as he put it, the wives of workers buy $20 dresses but the wives of the affluent buy $200 gowns. It is remarkable that the honourable member for Macarthur should find himself one out as far as these questions are concerned, because no reputable opinion in Australia would agree with the position which he has adopted. I will have an opportunity later during this debate, when I turn to one of these three Bills, to refer to some of the figures that he mentioned in relation to taxation. At this stage I will comment briefly about two of the Bills. As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has indicated, the Opposition will not oppose two of these three Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The first Bill-the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3)-is designed to give effect to proposals that were announced in detail on 16 July last year. It deals with the threat to company tax revenues that is posed by the growing practice of public company groups organising their affairs to eliminate company tax on some of their income. The practice involves the transfer of profitable assets, particularly investments in property, to unit trusts. In addition, of course, this Bill also seeks to achieve other purposes. The particular purpose involved here is to reduce the effectiveness with which public companies can pursue tax avoidance. In this connection the Bill proposes to treat unit trusts, which have been formed for this purpose, as if they were companies and the income earned by these public trusts will be taxed at 46c in the dollar-the same as public companies. Also, the distribution of income and profits from these unit trusts to the units holders will be taxed as if they were dividends being paid by public companies to their shareholders.

The chief reason the Opposition does not oppose this Bill is that we support any action, and we will support any action which this Government takes in any attempt to reduce tax avoidance in Australia. I will give some figures which indicate the possible extent to which tax avoidance practices are being undertaken by the corporate sector in Australia. Between 1965-66 and 1981-82 the proportion of total tax which was paid by the corporate sector fell from 19.3 per cent to 13.7 per cent. It is significant to note that if, in this financial year-1981-82-companies paid the same proportion of total tax which they paid in 1965-66, they would pay $7,289m. In fact, the corporate sector, by way of company taxation, will pay only $5,170m. The shortfall in this contribution from the corporate sector to Commonwealth revenues of $2,119m must be made up. It is made up. It is being made up by that section of taxpayers in Australia who do not have the opportunity to pursue forms of tax avoidance that are being pursued by other income earners, including the corporate sector. I refer, of course, to wage and salary earners-the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, the people whose contributions to total individual tax during that same period increased from 67 per cent to 82.7 per cent.

There are certain aspects of this Bill which do cause me concern. The Bill will extend the existing gift provisions of the income tax laws which confer deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds or institutions. One of two extensions in this provision will authorise deductions for gifts made after 30 June 1981 to the Victorian Arts Centre. Again, the Opposition does not oppose this provision. In fact, tax deductions of this kind which encourage institutions such as the Victorian Arts Centre are supported by the Opposition and variations of that type of provision would be pursued by us. But there have been too many cases of tax avoidance by artificially inflating the value of gifts made to institutions of this kind. There have been examples of works of art of various kinds being hawked from one person to another. The documents of sale show a continuing increased appreciation in the value of those particular items. So without any real expense being incurred by the so-called donors of these works of art to various institutions, by the time they are donated their inflated value results in considerable tax savings for those people who are hardly acting in any socially responsible way. I am concerned about this matter and I would appreciate it if we could be given advice during the course of this debate or subsequently about a recent case which concerned the Victorian National Gallery. Of course that case is very well known to honourable members and to members of the community generally. For example, as a result of manipulations of this kind, pre-Columbian art acquired in Mexico was inflated from an original purchase value of $1m to $2.7m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the tax relief they got.

—The tax relief provided by the particular items which were donated provided $2.7m to those people who were acting in what they would like the public to think to be a responsible way. Of course it was nothing of the kind. I would like some indication to be given as to what progress, if any, has been made by the Australian Taxation Office in attempting to close those loopholes. When that incident concerning the Victorian National Gallery was being considered, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) indicated that the Taxation Office would look at these types of actions.

SPEECH.PARA: One other aspect of this Bill to which I will refer is that it, probably more than any other measure in recent times, indicates the Government's absolute and complete confusion and lack of consistency in tax matters. This concerns particularly the provisions for capital expenditure on the development of a mine or an oil field. Prior to 1974 there was a 100 per cent deductibility for investment expenditure in this area in the first year. In that year the Labor Government applied the write-off to a period of 25 years. These are the changes which have occurred during the last six years of the current Government. In 1976 the period of write-off was reduced to five years. In 1981-this year-as a result of the decisions made following the razor gang's inquiries the period of write-off was increased from five years to six years. In the same year, 1981, as a result of the provisions of the present Budget, the period of write-off will again be increased to 10 years, unless, of course, it is qualified by the estimated life of the mine being less than 10 years. So any mine which started in 1974 would have been subjected during the intervening period to four separate write-off periods. Also the legislation refers to deductibility over 10 years. But that is not exactly what it appears to be because rather than having 10 per cent of the original capital expenditure written-off each year so that the total is written-off over 10 years, in fact it is applied by allowing 10 per cent of the diminishing value to be written-off each year. The result is that it will take over 30 years to write-off the full 95 per cent. If the mine ceases to operate within the period, then the remaining amount can be written-off. But it is not in fact a provision for the write-off over a 10 year period, as the legislation may suggest.

During the inquiry into the mining industry by the Industries Assistance Commission, the Australian Mining Industry Council recommended 10 years to 12 years for this purpose. The Western Mining Corporation Ltd and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd recommended 7 years to 10 years to the inquiry and the IAC settled finally for 15 years. Of course, that became the recommendation to the Government. In the face of that recommendation, the Government now has applied a write-off period of 10 years. I know that the mining industry has expressed some concern about that but, in light of its own recommendation to the IAC that the period be 10 years to 12 years, I cannot find a great deal of substance in the concern which the mining industry is expressing at present.

The second Bill, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill, is also supported by the Opposition. This is simply a machinery Bill to impose tax formally for 1981-82 on the 1980-81 incomes of companies, superannuation funds and some unit trusts which are subject to the provisions of the Bill to which I have just made reference at the rate of 46 per cent.

The third Bill of this trilogy is the Bill which the Opposition opposes. It will continue to oppose provisions of this kind. This Bill is certainly essential to the Budget, but the Opposition has expressed its concern on previous occasions and will continue to make public its concern about the way in which continuing decisions by this Government have been responsible for the burden of the total taxation being increasingly applied to the shoulders of those sections within the community who are least able to bear the burden. The Opposition is becoming increasingly intolerant, as is the Australian community, as it becomes better informed and more aware of exactly what is involved. We oppose this Bill and we are proud of the position that we have adopted in relation to it. We do not need to explain our position but this Government has a damned great deal to explain as far as its position is concerned. We cannot and will not give any support to proposals which contribute to the constant shift of the tax burden on to the shoulders of pay-as-you-earn taxpayers.

For example, since 1965-66 the proportion of total individual income tax paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers has grown, as I indicated earlier, from 67 per cent to 82.7 per cent during the current financial year. If PAYE taxpayers this year were to pay the same proportion of total individual tax as they paid in 1965-66, they would be paying less than $14,000m. In fact pay-as-you-earn taxpayers will be paying this year in excess of $17,000m. That $3,000m extra which has been dragged out of the pockets and the pay envelopes of PAYE taxpayers is made necessary because of all the corporate tax dodgers and individual tax dodgers who are ripping off the Treasury and the Australian people to an increasing extent as every year progresses.

In addition to that, a sales tax extension is provided for in legislation accompanying the Budget. This year it will rip off another $900m from the Australian people. Despite claims to the contrary by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), these contributions will be made mainly by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. Since 1960-61, the percentage of total tax revenue provided by personal income tax has grown from 36.4 per cent to 55.2 per cent. Since 1965-66, net paid taxation as a proportion of all wages and salaries has increased from 11 per cent to 20 per cent. Let me repeat that point: The proportion of total wages and salaries in 1965-66 which was taken from those wage and salary earners by way of income tax was 11 per cent. It is now 20 per cent. So the burden continues to increase.

The Treasurer has claimed that in the current year the Government is applying half tax indexation. That is not correct. The claims in relation to tax indexation that have been made by this Government and by successive Treasurers since this Government came into office in 1975 have not been correct either. For example, in 1976-77 full tax indexation was supposed to apply. After all the discounting for items like indirect taxes, adjustment in health schemes and revaluation, the percentage indexation which was applied was 93 per cent. In 1977-78, it was supposed to be full indexation again. In fact the index which was applied was only 80 per cent. In 1978-79, half in- dexation was to apply. To normal people, half indexation means 50 per cent indexation. In fact after all the discounting had been applied it was 35 per cent. In 1979-80, indexation was abandoned altogether. In 1980-81, half indexation was supposed to apply again. Again, to reasonable people, that means 50 per cent. In fact that year 39 per cent was applied. The same type of thing is going to occur this year, the last year of indexation, that system of taxation which according to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was supposed to keep the Government honest with the taxpayers money. During this year half indexation will mean considerably less than 50 per cent.

If we start just from 1977-78, when the number of steps in the progressive tax scale was reduced to three-I will not go back to the year when the Government originally claimed it was going to apply tax indexation-had 100 per cent full in- dexation been applied in every year since then, in the current year the tax-free threshold would be about $5,400 a year. That means that any taxpayer in Australia earning less than $5,400 of taxable income would pay no tax this year, had full taxation income been applied in the last three years. But, as a result of the failure of this Government to apply full tax indexation, the tax-free threshold will be $4,195, which means that all those people who earn between $4,195 and about $5,400 this year will pay tax which they should never have had to pay had full tax indexation been applied. Of course, this will bring into the basket of taxpayers thousands of low income earners all over Australia. Of course, they include pensioners. Pensioners who earn up to the allowable income level will now find themselves in this tax paying group. They are people who should never be taxed. They are being savagely ripped off by this Government. They are becoming increasingly aware of it. I have indicated that the Australian community is becoming increasingly aware of the justice, equity and simple fair play which apparently escape this Government. The Australian people know it. A couple of weeks ago in New South Wales there was a massive and record victory for the Australian Labor Party. That victory will be repeated in Victoria in 1982, and in 1983 it will be repeated federally because the people of Australia will not continue to tolerate the sort of injustice and inequity which is being perpetuated and persisted in by this Government. Members opposite might as well come over here now and feel the comfort of the Opposition seats, because in 1983 this Government will go down the national gurgle hole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have covered those areas of concern to my electorate. I now refer to the matter of Aborigines. I represent a lot of Aborigines in Maranoa and I think this matter is important to us. A lot has been said of late about this group of people within our society. Lang Hancock has had a bit to say. I do not necessarily agree with everything he has said. I believe we are incurring more than adequate special expenditure. The Commonwealth's contribution now totals $234m. It is quite ridiculous. I believe that unfortunately it is mitigating against some of the things we are trying to do for those people. In fact we are putting them in a position in which racial tension is building up against the fact that we are giving them too much as a special group. This is really what they do not want.
—You should be ashamed of yourself.

—I should be ashamed of myself but I am not. I believe it is something that was needed but I think enough is enough. As we heard this morning on AM, enough is enough. I think it is important for us to remember that apart from the $234m that is being spent by the Commonwealth the States also are spending quite a deal of money. In Queensland we hear all sorts of wild accusations from members of the Australian Labor Party and from radical Aboriginal groups regarding land rights. I wish to make my position clear in regard to this problem. I believe I have also got most of the people in my electorate, including Aborigines, on side regarding this matter because they do not want to be put-
—Do you speak to them?

—I do all the time. I mix with them; I have to. They are constituents of mine; they vote for me; I need their votes to get elected. It is important for us all to speak to them, and I do. What I point out is the hypocrisy of members of the Australian Labor Party saying to us in Queensland that we should grant the Aborigines freehold land rights when in Queensland they are totally opposed to freeholding. I think it is important for us to remember this. On the one hand we see a Bill brought into the Senate by a certain senator of the Labor Party-Senator Ryan-asking for freehold land rights, and on the other hand I and others in my electorate are opposed to such a thing. I believe that as Queenslanders we are offering equal rights to all people.
—Except if they are black.

—No, that is not true. Each and every one of us has the same rights. If I want freehold title I have to buy it. I believe that people of Aboriginal descent should have to do the same thing. We should not have to specialise and give these people special consideration. I heard someone interject: Is he one of yours? Yes, he is, and very proud of the fact. If he does not like me, he will not lose me that easily, I can assure honourable members. We in Queensland are a different breed from the rest of Australia. We have only to look at the trouble the Northern Territory has got itself into over the matter of Aboriginal land rights. I mention this because of the amount of funds that have been allocated. The Northern Territory Government has got itself into a-
