SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a shame that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) cannot have an extension of time. I am sure it would ensure that the Australian Labor Party would win that seat. The 1981-82 Budget, the sixth Budget of the Fraser Government, promises many things to Australia: A rise in inflation, increased interest rates, higher taxes, reduced services, a reduction in living standards and no reduction in unemployment. Honourable members should look at the effect of government policies on ordinary family living standards. For the family purchasing their own home, government decisions in the short space of one month this year have cost each family at least $35 per week in increased costs. This is made up of $15 per week for increased payments to meet interest rate rises on home mortgages, $10 per week for health and hospital coverage for the family and now approximately $4 per week as a result of the imposition of sales tax on the necessities of life. The total increase in costs is at least $29 per week. To earn an after-tax increase income of $29 a wage and salary earner would have to receive a $40 per week rise. Thus under this Government in one month alone the ordinary family has had its standard of living reduced by between $35 and $40. What compensation has it received for this reduction in buying power? Will services to the community be increased? No. In fact health, education, urban affairs, social welfare and many other services have been drastically reduced. Will the tax burden be eased? No. In fact the Government is collecting 22 per cent more in revenue from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers this year. In total the Government will collect another $5,300m in taxes from the Australian people in the next 12 months. For the person on the average wage this means that this year an extra $11.10 in tax will be extracted from the weekly pay packet. Today I warn the Government that it cannot continue to get away with this.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite should listen because in two years time they will find that my words are true because ordinary Australians are at last waking up to this gross deception and neglect by the Government. Already in several cities there have been spontaneous rallies and marches, mainly by women, because of these Government imposts. My office, for example-it would do honourable members opposite well to listen to their constituents-has been inundated with letters and calls, mainly from women, I must say, expressing their total opposition to these savage cuts in their living standards. I will tell honourable members why I receive complaints from women. It is women who are feeling the effect of this Budget because in the great majority of cases it is they who balance the family budget and who notice that the housekeeping money does not buy as much any more. It is they who have to explain to their children why they cannot have the same food, the same clothes and goods as they had last year. I wish to read extracts from a few of those letters from my constituents. This one is dated 9 September 1981 and it most clearly expresses my point about the Budget. It states:
Dear Mrs Kelly,

Although I am a working single parent and average $230 per week, my net take-home wage is $170 (i.e. after tax and superannuation.). As I have two mortgages plus a number of other commitments associated with living and bringing up two children and running a car to be able to get myself to work in time and yet not qualifying for the increased child endowment, I am finding it impossible to manage with the extra burden of health insurance and increased prescription charges. Until now my doctor kindly classified me as disadvantaged and with a minimum of visits to him we were able to manage. A few weeks ago we thought we were lucky in that we were granted a long awaited pay award of 4 per cent, which made an approximate difference of $12 per fortnight take-home pay. However, as the Government has seen fit to take it away through health insurance, and to hell with the increase in the price of food, electricity, rates, petrol, etc., how can they justify themselves by saying that the Budget was reasonable since we all had a national pay award recently. They may be able to fool some of the people some of the time but definitely not all of the people all of the time.
Another example is a letter from a woman, sent to me before the Budget was announced. She said:

At present I earn $161.00 (gross) per week in a casual part-time job . . . which allows me to see the children off to school each morning and be home when they return in the afternoons. I also receive a part widows pension of $29.00 per week and family benefit of $8.00 per week.
She went on to list for me her average expenditure on items such as food, mortgage repayments and car running costs. All that expenditure amounts to $185. She said:

Thus, out of a gross income of $198 per week $185 is already committed, leaving $13 for clothing, toys, household maintenance, entertainment, babysitters for night outings . . . and any other needs we might have. The prospect of paying some $600 per year . . . for medical care equal to that we have at present fills me with horror as we will then be left with only $5.00 per week uncommitted income.

That is an example of a person earning $161 a week, but what of those who earn less than that, who fall below the Henderson poverty line-the pensioners, the lone parents, the invalids? How can they possibly cope? The short answer is that they cannot cope. They go without adequate food, accommodation and medical care. How will families such as the one which sent me the letter which I have just read make ends meet after the latest Federal Budget attack on family living standards? I think the difficulty of their situation was highlighted today in an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald, which demonstrated that a single income family with two dependent children is paying up to 81 per cent more tax in real terms than it was paying six years ago.

What about indirect taxes? The imposition of sales tax on a wide range of ordinary necessities of life has been universally condemned by consumers, manufacturers and retailers. The Australian Labor Party unequivocally opposes sales tax because it is an inequitable form of taxation. Sales taxes have the greatest effect on low income earners and constitute a regressive form of taxation. They do not apply equally to all people. Those on fixed and low incomes are hardest hit by such consumer taxes. Those taxes are not incurred by choice; they apply to a wide range of common goods required by all of us. People have to buy basic necessities such as shoes, clothing, gloves, hats and towels. The thrifty person who wishes to avoid purchasing ready made clothes and soft furnishings will find that this Government has also taxed yarns for knitting and sewing; it has even taxed knitting books.

Home buyers are faced with an average price rise of $500 on the cost of building materials because sales tax has been extended to apply to most building materials. When the home buyer has managed to pay for the building, he or she finds that taxes have been increased on the cost of fitting out the house with the ordinary requirements for daily living, such as cooking stoves, electrical fittings, baths, showers, et cetera. The thrifty householder prepared to forgo modern amenities and to look for a cheaper lifestyle has been thwarted as the Government has increased taxes on fireplaces and grates, household washing coppers and all related accessories. Even if a person could avoid purchasing all those items, no one could avoid paying higher prices for food. That is due to the increased sales tax on packaging. Waxed and greaseproof paper, paper bags, aluminium foil, string, rubber bands, even sticky tape now have been subjected to increased sales tax. What next! People who seek to escape all this and seek solace in literature and magazines find that they also are to be taxed. I believe that that is a pernicious tax as it strikes at the heart of civilised society by taxing the dissemination of knowledge.

All those sales taxes place a totally unjustified burden on the consumer. The Budget Papers show that in a full year sales tax increases will raise $892m, equivalent to $60 a person. For a four person family that represents $240 a year or $4.60 a week. That may not seem to be a great deal to honourable members opposite or to those who can avoid and evade taxes, but for all wage and salary earners who cannot deduct the cost of the long lunch or the car from their taxes, $4.50 a week added to the increase in interest rates and health costs, plus the increased tax burden, all add up. Wage and salary earners are making a record high contribution to the taxation coffers-an increase of a staggering 22 per cent. To put that in context, the average tax that will be paid next year by each member of the labour force will be close to $3,100. That means that next year each member of the labour force will pay a massive $500 more in tax. At the same time as the Government collects more and more revenue, it provides less service to the Australian people.

In particular, the Budget is bad for women. In the areas of health, housing, education, training, employment, taxation and social welfare services, women are seriously disadvantaged. Despite the fact that we are all paying more and more taxes, those services for women have been reduced. The Government has employed a strategy of withdrawing from providing services, leaving private individuals and organisations to step in, thus creating extra burdens for women. It is women who care for the aged and the sick, who do the hard work in fund raising for charities and parents and citizens bodies and other voluntary work. Increasingly, as this Government abrogates its responsibilities in the provision of services, it is women without income who continue those services.

The Budget fails to provide adequate funding for women's refuges, rape crisis centres and other services. The Federal Government, by abrogating its responsibilities in those areas, has ensured that many of those services will collapse altogether. By handing over to the States responsibility for those services while at the same time reducing the allocation for State health programs, this Government is fully to blame for any loss of those facilities and the women of Australia will hold this Federal Government accountable. In the area of health, women will be most seriously disadvantaged by the increased cost of health care as they are much more likely to be clients of health services than men are. Women with children and aged women are the greatest users of health services, but at the same time they are the lowest income earners in society.

In relation to employment, the Budget contains no program or strategy aimed at reducing the extremely high unemployment levels for girls. In education and later in training and employment schemes, women are disadvantaged. The draft scheme which encourages employers to take on apprentices does not specifically encourage female apprenticeship. Currently, over 90 per cent of apprentices are male and it is patently obvious that the current arrangements discriminate against women. The Government should take immediate steps to guarantee equal access for women to apprenticeships and other training schemes and to all areas of employment. Employment opportunities determine incomes. Without access to the higher paid employment areas, women will continue to comprise a disproportionate percentage of those on low incomes and social security benefits. Budget figures on the taxable incomes of males and females show that, whilst 90 per cent of men earn less than $30,000 per annum, about 90 per cent of women earn less than $15,000 per annum. About two-thirds of those who rely on social security benefits for the major proportion of their income are women. Thus women are over-represented among the low income and social security recipient groups.

The Fraser Government's magnanimous gift to the Australian family has been to increase the family allowance for those with three children or more. I congratulate it on that move but it applies only to a small percentage of Australian families. Seventy-four per cent of Australian families miss out. Seventy-four per cent of families receive no extra benefits. This Budget continues the trend of the last five years, whereby the real value of the family allowance has fallen dramatically. If the family allowance had been indexed it would now be 75 per cent higher than in 1976, making the family allowance for two children $14 a week instead of $8 a week.

The family allowance is of great importance to women since it is the women who largely have the responsibility for rearing children. Meredith Edwards of the Canberra College of Advanced Education has recently completed a major study on the financial arrangements within families which highlights the importance of the family allowance to women. Edwards found that the family allowance helped an overwhelming majority of women as managers of family finances in making ends meet, or in providing them with a measure of economic independence. The decline in the real value of family allowances over the past five years has hit women the hardest as they struggle to cope with family budgets and rising prices for the necessities of life.

For the majority of women the family allowance is their only independent source of disposable income to buy goods and services for themselves and their children. But this Budget continues this trend of the last five years by allowing the erosion of the real value of family allowances. The value of this cash transfer which is so important to women has been reduced by 75 per cent during that time. But in the same period the real value of the dependent spouse rebate, a tax benefit mainly for males, has increased by 23 per cent. Family allowances and the dependent spouse rebate each cost the Government about the same amount-approximately $1 billion. But the emphasis should be on the provision of benefits to families and children. After all, the period of greatest financial burden to families occurs when they are raising children. Thus it is the family allowance which I believe should be increased.

There is a new form of poverty in Australia today. Even people on so-called comfortable incomes are feeling the pinch. The average family budget cannot absorb the massive increases forced on it by this Government in the form of high interest rates, expensive health insurance, increased pay-as-you-earn taxation and sales tax on the ordinary necessities of life. On top of this, the wage indexation system has been dismantled causing further deterioration in the financial status of wage and salary earners. This Government has demonstrated that the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975 to reduce the tax burden is a massive deception. The reality of the situation today is that the Fraser Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a contribution to this Budget debate by saying something about the Office of the Auditor-General. The position of Auditor-General has been part of the system in Australia since 1901; one of the early Bills passed after Federation established that position. I think it is generally accepted that the Auditor-General has a role to play as the Government auditor. That was probably the principal role that was envisaged for the Auditor-General when the Bill was passed in 1901. But since that time there has been a significant change in the emphasis on the work carried out by the Auditor-General, such that as we look at that Office in the 1980s we see that he is fairly heavily involved in the role of assisting in the accountability of the bureaucracy to Parliament. It is that second role that interests me.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting facts that emerges when one looks at the Auditor-General, his office and his role, is that there is no input from the Parliament as to what the Auditor-General will look at and the sorts of things that he will examine. The only involvement in the Parliament is after the event when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts looks at the report that he tables in the Parliament. The Public Accounts Committee and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure look at efficiency audit reports.

The relationship between the Auditor-General and the Parliament, I believe, should be the subject of much greater analysis and discussion. Many of the aspects of the relationship I think ought to be considered. One of these would be the fact that the Auditor-General is a public servant. The members of his staff are public servants. There is a transfer into and out of the Audit Office of public servants from other Commonwealth departments. The Auditor-General is subject to the Public Service Board and to policies such as staff ceilings. The Auditor-General is subject also to the budgetary processes in the same way that other departments are. Without being in any way unkind about it, it is true to say that the Auditor-General is a part of the bureaucratic establishment. I just wonder whether that limits in any way the role that some of us who are in parliament may see as being the sort of role the Auditor-General can or should play in relation to that second function, which I indicated in my opening remarks, in assisting the Parliament in playing a part in improving the accountability of departments and authorities to the Parliament.

It is interesting that it is not the case in all similar countries that their auditor-generals are in the same situation as that of the Auditor-General in Australia. I would like to develop this point a little. I probably will not get as far as I would like to tonight but I would like to give some extracts from a seminar which was sponsored by the Public Accounts Committee entitled 'Government Expenditure and Accountability' and which was held in Canberra last year. The following are some quotes from the then Auditor-General, Mr Steele Craik. He said:

. . . although I have been described from time to time as an officer of the Parliament, I regard myself as an officer of the Crown. My situation is summarised neatly in a recent Green Paper on the role of the United Kingdom Comptroller and Auditor-General where it said:

'The Comptroller and Auditor-General is an officer holder under the Crown, subject to removal only on an address from the two Houses of Parliament. Like members of the judiciary, he is not subject to control either by Parliament or by the Executive in the exercise of his functions. His main duty is under the Exchequer and Audit Acts undertaken 'on behalf of the House of Commons'. He is not however a servant of the House although he has been frequently referred to in those terms'.

Mr Steele Craik went on to say that his Office assisted the processes of accountability to the Parliament by the Executive and the public service. He said that his special independence gives the Auditor-General a unique role in the processes of parliamentary scrutiny of the financial and administrative efficiency of the Executive. He further said:

The Parliament exercises its influence over the Executive in a number of ways . . . especially when the annual and additional estimates are being considered and through scrutiny of monies expended against the appropriations approved by the Parliament. The latter is where the Auditor-General comes in. His reports provide a source of independent and impartial information for use by the Parliament in its review function.
He said also:
I stress the pursuit of improvements in the quality of public administration as the aim of my office.

There are some differences and at least one significant difference-between the Australian and United Kingdom positions, that is, that the Comptroller and Auditor-General of the United Kingdom does not make recommendations. This is done by the Public Accounts Committee after consideration of his report. Constitutionally, public audit is seen as an independent function through the Comptroller and Auditor-General as a servant of parliament. Although the Comptroller and Auditor-General is independent of Executive control in most issues, the numbers, pay and conditions of service of his staff are subject to the approval of the Civil Service Department and the Treasury, as is the case in Australia. However, in the event of disagreement he may report to the parliament and have the situation considered by the Public Accounts Committee.

The Canadian Auditor-General reports to the House of Commons and, unlike either his British or Australian counterpart, has express statutory authority for the personal management of his office, including the determination of terms and conditions of employment and the responsibility for employer and employee relations. The Commonwealth Auditor-General, by virtue of section 25 (4) of the Public Service Act 1922, has the powers of a permanent head of a department in relation to the staff under his control. Thus, apart from the control exercised by the Public Service Board over the appointments and staffing levels and the scrutiny of his financial estimates and expenditures pursuant to section 48 (K) of the Audit Act, it may be said that the Auditor-General is independent of Executive control.

The Auditor-General cannot be said to be answerable to Parliament in the sense that a departmental permanent head is answerable to his Minister. Rather, the Auditor-General is answerable to Parliament in a broad sense in that he is under a statutory obligation to report annually and in special circumstances provided by the Act. He can be removed from office only on address from both Houses of Parliament to the Governor-General. In 1980 the British Government produced a Green Paper on the role of the Comptroller and Auditor-General. This Green Paper represented the first stage of the Government's review of the Exchequer and Audit Department Acts. One of the three main questions discussed in the Green Paper was what should be the Comptroller and Auditor-General's status in relation to Parliament and the Executive. At paragraph 56 the Green Paper stated:

The Comptroller and Auditor-General is an officeholder under the Crown subject to removal only on address from the two Houses of Parliament. Like members of the judiciary he is not subject to control either by Parliament or by the Executive in the exercise of his functions. His main duties under the Exchequer and Audit Department Acts are undertaken 'on behalf of the House of Commons'. He is not, however, a servant of the House although he has been frequently referred to in those terms.

Honourable members will recall that that is the same quote as the one that the former Auditor-General in Australia used in relation to his own position. At paragraph 58 the Green Paper said that the Exchequer and Audit Department Acts give the Civil Service Department control over Exchequer and Audit Department staff numbers and gradings. The parliamentary committees of expenditure and procedure considered this an unacceptable degree of Executive influence over the Comptroller and Auditor-General's work. Those committees recommended that the staff should become or be regarded as servants of the House with the Department's costs borne on the vote of the House and that the House of Commons Commission should assume responsibility for the numbers and gradings. The Government rejected the view expressed by the two parliamentary committees and said, in effect, that the present situation should remain and that if matters were not being handled appropriately the Comptroller and Auditor-General, being independent, could report to Parliament. It is interesting that the Green Paper was a Government document. It obviously expressed the views that the Government would like to have expressed on the relationship that the Comptroller and Auditor-General in the United Kingdom should have with the Executive and the Parliament. The committees of the Parliament took a different view which, obviously, did not succeed with the Government. At paragraph 60 the Green Paper stated:

. . . as for the Comptroller and Auditor-General himself, the Government considers that independence in the exercise of his responsibilities and in deciding on the disposition of his staff resources and on audit priorities is of fundamental importance to a national auditor. The nature and balance of his work under the statutes should not be subject to direction from any quarter.

I would not want to argue with that. I think, as I made clear at the beginning of my speech, that the role of the Auditor-General as a national auditor is completely apart from the role he has in relation to the Parliament and his accountability. At paragraph 61 the Green Paper stated:

. . . the Government believe that the Comptroller and Auditor-General's independence would best be safeguarded if he remains an officeholder under the Crown and is not and does not become regarded as a servant of the House.

The Green Paper notes at paragraph 62 that the expenditure and procedure committees suggested that the Comptroller and Auditor-General should undertake inquiries if requested to do so by the House of Commons or any of its select committees. That is the situation in the United States of America. Any such power to direct the Comptroller and Auditor-General, the British Government said, would entail an undesirable limitation of his independence. Among its conclusions the Green Paper contained the following:
(a) the role of the Comptroller and Auditor-General should be:
(i) to provide a basic financial and regularity audit of departmental accounts;
(ii) to undertake an examination of the economy and efficiency with which public funds are spent and
(iii) in appropriate cases to investigate the effectiveness of programs and projects in meeting established policy goals . . .

(g) the independence of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of both the Executive and the Parliament should be reaffirmed and there should be no change in his status as an officeholder under the Crown.

I will now make a few remarks about the General Accounting Office in the United States of America. The Budget and Accounting Act of 1921 established the United States General Accounting Office. The Act provided for the appointment by the President of the Comptroller-General of the US, such appointments to be made with the advice and consent of the Senate. It also provided that the GAO should be under the control and direction of the Comptroller-General and independent of the Executive departments. By providing that the GAO was to be independent of the Executive departments, the Act transferred power from the Executive of the legislative branch and gave Congress new means to guard against lax or improper spending of government funds. The Comptroller-General was given virtually unqualified power in the internal management of the GAO. Such a broad grant of power to the head of a government agency has few precedents in American history.

In 1966 Elmer B. Statts was appointed Comptroller-General for a period of 15 years. It was during his term of office that the GAO developed its current role and its emphasis in auditing activities swung gradually to program evaluation. I now refer to the current function of the GAO. The GAO comprehensive audit manual includes, as part of the accounts function of GAO audits, the following:

(b) to assist the Congress and federal agency officials in carrying out their responsibilities by providing them with objective and primary information on the conduct of government operations together with the conclusions and recommendations.

Some GAO activities, such as financial audits of government corporations, are required by law. Others are responses to requests by chairmen of committees and sub-committees of Congress. Some are requested by individual members of Congress. The majority of reports-about two-thirds of them-are initiated within the GAO on the independent authority of the Comptroller-General. About one-third are initiated by Congress.

It is difficult to equate the role of the GAO to any one organisation of other parliaments. It would appear that its tasks amount to an amalgamation of some of the functions carried out in Australia by the Auditor-General's Office and parliamentary committees, such as the Public Accounts Committee, the Public Works Committee and the various Senate Estimates committees. However, in terms of staffing, management, accountability to the legislature and relationship to the Executive, the only approximate analogy would appear to be that of a super ombudsman whose concern is the nation's welfare as a whole, rather than individual rights. There has also been a reasonably recent report in Canada. The Wilson report on the role of the Auditor-General in 1975 took the view that it would be a great mistake for the Auditor-General to attempt to conduct efficiency and effectiveness studies. It took the view that the danger was that because of the lack of consensus about data and methodologies for the Auditor-General to carry out those studies he would inevitably embroil himself in political controversy so intense as to threaten eventually the office itself. On another occasion I would like to develop some more thoughts about the Canadian situation.

In the time left to me I will make some remarks on the Australian situation, particularly following the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. There is a lot of material in that Royal Commission about the Auditor-General. Following the Commission's report there was an interesting article written by Professor Gordon Reid in the Australian Journal of Public Administration, volume 35, No. 4, December 1976. Professor Reid dealt with two directives to the Royal Commission which were not part of the terms of reference of the Royal Commission but were specifically mentioned in the supplementary schedule of subject matters as matters to which the five Commissioners were to give particular attention. They were:
(c) parliamentary scrutiny and control of administration;
(d) responsibility and accountability of public servants, and their participation in forming policy and making decisions;
Speaking of parliamentary scrutiny and control of administration, Professor Reid said:
It was highly questionable whether a Royal Commission should be charged to inquire into the functions of an elected Parliament.

Instead of having a joint committee of the parliament to inquire into the Public Service, parliamentarians were faced with a royal commission charged with the responsibility to inquire, amongst other things, into the Parliament. Neither House of Parliament nor any official of the Parliament made a submission to the Royal Commission or was examined as a witness. The Royal Commission in chapter 5 'The Administration and Parliament' does not come to grips with the essence of the subject. Professor Reid says that there is no inquiry into what parliamentary scrutiny may mean in modern government, what it could achieve or the several meanings that could be given to parliamentary control.

There is no discussion of the implications of parliamentary financial control for modern budget formulation or what would be an appropriate range of parliamentary committees to facilitate the Public Service's management needs. Reid says that by and large the Commission ignored the implications of this reference in recognition that it had much more to say on the next one, that is, responsibility and accountability of public servants. After dealing with this question of responsibility and accountability of public servants, Reid finishes up by saying that the crucial question remains: What will be the procedures for accountability by which officials may be called upon to report and justify their performance and be rewarded or penalised? Also, who is to be the final judge?

Professor Emy and the Royal Commission agreed that the Auditor-General should be empowered to conduct efficiency audits throughout the Commonwealth Government administration, extending to all agencies which he audits in respect of financial regularity. The Commission recommended that such efficiency audits incorporate some of the provisions currently listed in section 17 of the Public Service Act as applying to the Public Service Board. Reid says that the allocation of authority to conduct the continuing efficiency audit is one thing, but more important is the question of whether that statutory officer-the Auditor-General-will command the authority or status necessary to enable him to bestow awards or to impose penalties and to achieve intended effects.

It is curious that, notwithstanding the alleged dissatisfaction with ministerial responsibility, it is expected that the Auditor-General will use the authority of Parliament to impose his judgments. For example, it is recommended that the outcome of the audits of efficiency should be presented to Parliament and that there should be a specially designed parliamentary committee on administrative and executive efficiency, having a special relationship with the Auditor-General, and that, whilst this committee should have its own parliamentary secretariat, it should be advised on professional matters by the Auditor-General and his staff. Reid argues that, notwithstanding the apparent radicalism of the concept of accountable management, the alleged dissatisfaction with ministerial responsibility and the elevation of the Office of Auditor-General to provide tests of efficiency, the everyday sequence of vesting responsibilities, measuring performance and demanding accountability in government still rests finally upon the authority of the Parliament.

It is obviously not possible for me to continue these remarks at this stage. Time is against me. I would like to open up that debate. I hope that we might be able to carry it further at some later time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the thoughtful contribution of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher). I would like to respond to some of the points which were brought up repeatedly in this House by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) throughout the sittings of this Parliament and the last Parliament and the issues that are before us tonight in this debate. He frequently defended the disastrous economic policies of his Government. I thought of describing this as navel contemplation-I think the medical term for it is omphaloskepsis. That is the sort of attitude he conveys to me when he goes rambling on about what wonderful economic policies the Government has given us. For example, this evening he advised us that the $2 1/2 billion deficit of the Hayden Budget in 1975 meant that we were living beyond our means. That has been well refuted over and over in this place and in other parliaments around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member said that it has taken the present Government six years to pay the Whitlam bills or, to quote other words that he used, to combat the inflationary chaos. He mourned the fact that the Government had been forced to do this unpopular thing without having the luxury or the kudos of being able to return much of its record revenues to those to whom he referred as the people. There are many comfortable fallacies in this argument. It is a fallacy that a Budget deficit means living beyond our means. Any responsible home buyer, farmer or small businessman, unless he is very fortunate and falls into money by receiving a legacy or winning a lottery, or the like, has never succeeded in achieving that independent status without taking some sort of an overdraft or borrowing some money. The Whitlam Government very responsibly undertook in this country development works which are responsibly undertaken by governments at all levels-local governments; state governments, federal governments and, indeed, at times by the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund or whatever-on borrowed money which is paid back over a period by those persons who have the benefit of the facilities that are bought with that capital.

The present Government has pushed two million Australians-a record number in terms of what today's poverty line is -below the poverty line. It has reduced the borrowing capacity of 70 per cent of income earners in Australia over the period that it has been in office. Despite modest gains in productivity, 70 per cent of income earners, after paying tax and after paying health insurance and all the other things that have been required of them by this Goverment's policies, are now worse off in terms of buying power. Of course, they are the people on lower incomes. It is the 30 per cent of people on higher incomes who by and large are better off. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) tonight gave us some vivid examples from her own constituents of the problems this has created for housewives and others in balancing, in particular, the family budget.

This Government has held up its hands in horror at the prospect of undertaking public works such as those contemplated by the Whitlam Government. It has abandoned any profitable investment to the private sector. I refer to undertakings such as the Pipeline Authority, the most imaginative construction of any government since the Snowy Mountains scheme, which in the opening stages was boycotted by Sir Robert Menzies and other conservatives as a horrible example of socialism. The Government has abandoned any kind of extension of the public sector which could be profitable for the taxpayers of Australia and, indeed, has sold it out to private enterprise, to its friends in the private sector.

As the Minister for Health I initiated the buying of the Fawnmac group of companies, which was a highly successful Australian family business with a very broad capacity for producing a wide range of pharmaceuticals, tablets, ampoules and the like and which supplied contracts for multinational drug firms in this country as well as for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. The purchase gave us a window into the drug industry, a means of talking rationally to those drug firms which negotiated the pricing of pharmaceutical benefits with the Department of Health. It allowed us to talk back to them in their own terms about what their costs were when they refused to disclose their cost structures around the world. It gave CSL a greater security in producing vaccines and biological products. Yet this Government sold it out for less than we paid for it while it was still profitable. That is the sort of back-to-front economics that this so-called, business-aware, responsible, economic management government goes on with. It disposes of its profitable enterprises to private industry. If anything is going broke in the private industry then the Government is more likely to look at socialising it as, for instance, Mr Bjelke-Petersen did with some firms in Queensland. His Government bought out shares so that the firms would not go to foreigners.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—It is a good idea; I am a socialist too. It would be nice some time for the honourable member for Maranoa and some of the honourable members of his party to admit that he is indulging in exactly the same thing.
—I am not.

—Now he says he is not although he asked me previously what was wrong with it. Now we have the shortsighted razor gang capers such as confining Telecom Australia to a 10 per cent growth in capital borrowing. Telecom is one of the growth industries. It is one of the most successful industries already profitable under the Australian Telecommunications Commission which the Australian Labor Party set up. Its prices, as the Minister has told us repeatedly in this House, are set by Telecom because he requires it to make the user pay and to make it pay. He gives Telecom independence and says that he will not interfere but he interferes, of course, when it suits him, to make Telecom appear to be inefficient by putting ceilings on its staff, on its borrowings and on its spending, so creating great backlogs in the connection of services, particularly in growth areas like Gladstone where one has to wait for over a year for a telephone for a business, and this is a businessman's government.
—What about Maranoa? We don't have any there.
—Of course, the honourable member for Maranoa objects that he does not have any telephones in Maranoa.
—No, businessmen.

—No businessmen. Well, of course, he should look to the sort of government that there is in the State from which he comes. Perhaps that has something to do with the lack of business in Maranoa. So, Telecom is limited to a 10 per cent growth in its borrowing for the year but it is forced to pay more overtime because of the staff ceilings. what a back-to-front sort of economy that is. This happens in other areas where staff have extra work loads such as in the area of the servicing of unemployment benefits in the Department of Social Security. That Department was forced to lift staff ceilings eventually because of the overtime costs. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), has frequently cited figures which show that there is now consistent correlation between deficit funding, inflation rates, tax levels, economic growth, productivity and employment. For example, the honourable member for Macarthur totally ignored the fact, in his praise of the balanced Budget, that it is purely a domestic balance. It is useless to balance the domestic Budget if the overseas trade budget ends up out of balance to an extent that it has eaten up all the gains that he has claimed are making up what he calls the Whitlam debts. We have just heard that there is a record overseas trade balance for the September quarter and we are $2,000m or $3,000m behind the predictions in the Budget. We thought, of course, that the inflow of foreign capital would be at the same rate as last year. It is down to about half.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the items of the popular mythology espoused by the honourable member for Macarthur was that the world-wide inflation, stagnation and unemployment of the early 1970s was because of the chaos of Whitlamism. The great achievement, it seems, of the Labor Government was to induce this world-wide recession. The right honourable member for Lowe (Sir William McMahon) who is, perhaps, still the most able financial brain on the Government side-I think he was, at least in 1976-in a television interview in 1976 said that half the inflation of the early 1970s had come from capital inflow. Indeed, this was obvious if one looks at the figures for 1972 before the Labor Party came to office. He should know because he was on the Treasury benches and was in charge of that sort of calculation. Then, after the Labor Government came to office, there was an inflow of $4,000m of hot money chasing safe investments following the slump in the Vietnam War boom. Australian real estate and profitable firms that were quite efficient and competent and which were competing without protection on the world market were bought up. Our key resources and industries were bought up often at exorbitant and inflationary prices. Of course, the profits now flow overseas.

The honourable member for Macarthur said that his Government could not hand back revenue to the people. The fact is that it has handed back extra sums in new ways that the Whitlam Government had discontinued or did not introduce to the extent of $10,000m mainly to big business in tax concessions, investment incentives, subsidies, by cuts in the resource taxes, by gratuitous hikes in the Bass Strait oil prices and so on. Not only are Australians required to pay world prices for the new oil finds which was a policy brought in by the Whitlam Government but also the Government is giving Esso-BHP something like a five-fold increase in the prices from their previously known reserves which are still providing most of our petroleum. There has been a massive shift in the wealth of Australians so that 2,000 of the richest own as much as 2 1/2 million of the poorest Australians. That figure is increasing. It proves that the Government is creating two nations, a nation of the haves and a nation of the have-nots and that disparity is increasing. It was, of course, alleged that there would be a trickle down of the riches from the rich to the poor. But, I have already pointed out that after tax, health insurance and the like, 70 per cent of Australians are worse off under this Government despite increasing productivity and there are increasing amounts flowing overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. They work less hours to buy a motor car than they did 10 years ago.

—The honourable member for Maranoa appears to be under the impression that Australians eat motor cars. He says they work less hours to buy a motor car than they did years ago. They also work less hours to fly to England than they did years ago. But 70 per cent of Australians nevertheless have less take-home pay after tax and after paying health insurance than they had in the Whitlam years because of the increasing taxes and because of the decreasing services. As capital inflow slows with the resources recession, hopefully only temporary, increasing profits are going overseas so the overseas balance will get worse. Next to Canada we are the most foreign-owned of all affluent countries. Canada has moved to reverse the trend, not to encourage it as this Government is still doing. This Government knocked back less than 2 per cent of applications for the sell-out of the farm to foreign interests. I refute also the ridiculous claim of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) in this debate this evening. He told us he has to talk to Aboriginals to get their vote and to hold his seat and that is what they want-
—I did not say to hold my seat, I said to get their vote. I would hold my seat without their vote, but I still talk to them. They are friends of mine.
—Some of them are his friends and what they want, he said, is less money.
—I did not say they want less money. I said we are giving them too much.

—He said that we are giving them too much money. Perhaps what he should be doing if he believes that is to reduce Aboriginal benefits even more. We should reduce the funds that are being provided to try to bring Aboriginals up to a decent affluent world standard and not have them live in a third world, deprived, depressed, decrepit and despondent plight. Perhaps we should decrease those funds even further so that more of them will vote for him if that is what they really want.
—I am not looking for their votes. I am looking for some justice for the whites as well as the blacks.

—He says he is just looking for justice. I suggest that deprived people, black or white, are not being adequately catered for while Aboriginal standards of health, education, employment, land ownership and self-respect are of the most depressed Third World standard when measured against the standard of the United Nations or any other authority.
—Utter rot!

—The honourable member calls that utter rot. He made another ridiculous claim that only Aboriginal radicals and interfering whites are asking for freehold land in Queensland. He does not believe in that because all Australians should have equal rights.
—That is right.

—The honourable member confirms that. He did not respond to my question about whether Mr Iwasaki should have freehold land in Queensland, although he plainly heard and responded proudly to the question about whether the Premier was one of his constituents. Mr Iwasaki, not only has a freehold land title but also, unlike the Aborigines of Aurukun shire or the Torres Strait Islands in the Shire of Torres who cannot even own their own homes or building blocks, he has total exemption from shire by-laws.
—Whites in Gove cannot own land either. The Aborigines own it.

—Is that not marvellous! The whites in an Aboriginal reserve and shire are not able to own their own land. There is a special Act of parliament in Queensland which exempts Mr Iwasaki from the Fitzroy shire by-laws under the minority rule of the party, represented by the member for Maranoa. Aboriginals do not want land in order to mine it; they do not want it to block mining like a dog in a manger blocking beasts of burden from their fodder. They want only to be able to determine the pace and style of growth from their old and complex culture which respects the environment in its ancient, mysterious and respected relationship with them in unforced voluntary interaction with the alien, European conqueror's culture imposed on them. More blacks were killed by those conquerors in less than 200 years in what is now Queensland than all the Queenslanders killed in the Boer War, World War I, World War II, the Malaysian confrontation, the Korean war and the Vietnam conflict. Yet we still teach our young people that white settlement was peaceful. The honourable member for Maranoa has the blissfully ignorant arrogance to suggest that black Queenslanders should have to buy their freehold the same way as whites do.
—Why shouldn't they have equality?

—The honourable member confirms that. 'Why shouldn't they', he says. It would be laughable if his State colleagues were not so blatantly racist, so totally opposed to the fine words of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, to deny Aboriginals any group or co-operative ownership of pastoral leases in Queensland-not freehold, just leases. This is worse than the land policies of apartheid in South Africa where at least a share of land is totally given to black citizens for so-called homelands.
—They can take up a lease if they want to. There is nothing to stop them.
—The honourable member says that they can take up a lease if they want to and that there is nothing to stop them-nothing except the Queensland Government still refusing it to them.
—Nonsense!

—The honourable member says that is nonsense. He had better start communicating. The self-rule of Aboriginals in Queensland is a grim farce as any frank discussion with most settlement councils and citizens will quickly disclose. White managers are given blanket devolved powers which they use all too often as superior powers, not unexpectedly as they have the control of communications with the government.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately I do not have very long to speak in this debate. As the last speaker for the Government at the second reading stage of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82, I will attempt to tidy up one or two matters. I have listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham) and to a great range of speakers on this subject. Naturally enough, there has been a fair division of opinion. The Opposition keeps calling for what amounts to a pulling down of people who are successful and who are interested in incentives in order to, in some strange form, build up the country. My view has always been that Australians perform better if they are given incentives, if they are allowed as much as possible to act as individuals and if the competitive environment in which they work can be guaranteed by governments. That is the sort of policy that I have been advocating with this Government and it is the policy that is very strongly emerging in this Budget. It is in stark contradistinction to the socialist policy of the Opposition which believes that somehow there is some incredible wisdom in it and in public servants that is superior to the wisdom of hundreds of thousands of ordinary working Australians. That is a topic in itself. I hope that by the time of the next federal election, the Australian people will get very clearly in their minds the sort of choice they will make.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about Budgets we are talking about the biggest accounting entities in our country in a single year. We are talking about incredibly large amounts of money, in this case some $40,000m in a country where total production is some $130,000m. As a proportion of the total production of Australia it is a very large amount and just standing on its own it is a very large amount. When governments frame budgets the first thing they have to decide on is how much can people afford. They also have to decide whether it is better to have a relatively large government or a relatively small one. Again that question devolves around whether we want as much freedom as possible for individuals or regulation and large government. This year we have come up with a solution which seems fairly reasonable. I have never been one for increasing taxation but I have recognised that if there are public needs that cannot be met by the private sector, if people require transfer payments from relatively well-off people-I am talking about people who require them, not just want them-and if those needs have to be met then an affluent society such as ours ought to be able to afford to spend 25 per cent to 30 per cent of gross national product on them. I am talking about transfer payments and public needs.

This year we are talking about some 28 per cent of gross domestic product going in the form of taxation. Thankfully this year that is the end of the bill. We do not have to raise any more money. We are roughly balancing the books. Again, whether or not we ought to balance the books is another subject that has been covered by many speakers. I support that philosophy and in all discussions that I have had with any Government member prior to the Budget I certainly urged that. Of course, there is no shortage of programs that the Australian people want in every sphere whether it be health, education, roads, what the States want or what the people want by way of pensions the arts and sport. it does not matter what region we look at; people want more programs and more money. But when people sit down and think they usually understand that we cannot have all of those things. We have to raise the tax somewhere but we do not like paying it.

Just look at the reaction to this Budget which in terms of taxation policy is in my view very moderate. Nobody seems to like any of the sales tax increases but everybody wants different tax scales for personal income tax. People want higher tax-free zones and greater eligibility for pensioner benefit cards. They want higher deductions for superannuation and greater incentives to invest in companies. Thankfully, that is something that is being examined. So at every turn nobody wants to pay higher tax. What I am saying is that at the moment the tax take of around 28 per cent of GDP is probably about right. It is certainly high enough and I think as a matter of judgment it is something above which we should not go in the future.

I referred to the size of government. This matter is dear to my heart. I conclude my remarks on the Budget on this point. Too often governments of all persuasions worry too much about companies, groups and unions and do not worry enough about people. That might sound trite or almost self-righteous, but I think this is something that we as Australians ought to think more about. We worry whether a particular company will survive. We do not seem to worry enough whether the consumers who buy the products of that company will benefit from one decision or another. We worry too much about providing monopolistic situations for unions and companies involved in scarce resources. We do not worry about providing guarantees of competition so that people can act as individuals in a freer society. Those are lofty subjects. Those are subjects which unfortunately we have lost track of to some extent in our affluent society.

We have lived through a thankfully relatively short period in our history when we drifted very badly down the road to socialism. When we talk about socialism we are not talking of democratic socialism because there is no such thing. Socialism cannot be democratic. It can be democratic on the day when it is set up. It is not long after that when the sort of people who sit opposite start to tell everybody in the country, through regulation and high taxation, what they ought or ought not to do. When those opposite think about it a little more they will realise that this democratic socialism that we hear so much about is utter rubbish. The two words cannot sit together.

The 1981 Budget puts the country a little more on track. It does not solve all our problems. Not all the problems can be solved at Government level. I believe that what the Government has tried to do this year in total is just about the best solution it could have found. I am looking forward to next year when we cut down a few more of our regulations, when we get out of a few more areas where we are not required and when we can genuinely cut taxes to individual Australians.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Redevelopment of Monaro Mall, Australian Capital Territory-Sales Tax on Publications-Independent Air Fares Committee-Care for the Elderly-McNeill Child Care Centre-Cyprus-Taxation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken already about the problems experienced by small business people in Canberra in their relations with the Lend Lease organisation. The Lend Lease organisation controls all the major shopping centres throughout Canberra with the single exception of the Belconnen Mall, which is now, unfortunately, to be sold to the private sector as a result of the razor gang's decisions. Lend Lease also controls many other buildings and office complexes, as well as the retail centres. This means that Lend Lease has a stranglehold on small traders in Canberra. The smaller retailer has no option but to rent space in a Lend Lease development.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 August, Lend Lease announced that it was planning a major redevelopment for the Monaro Mall. The announcement was made in Sydney. It is very disappointing that a company which controls nearly all of Canberra's retail centres should make this announcement anywhere but in Canberra. It is indicative of Land Lease's whole attitude to Canberra that it did not see fit to present these plans in Canberra. The redevelopment project to update the Monaro Mall is very welcome. The project, worth between $5m and $10m, will assist the local construction industry and will help rejuvenate the Civic area. I am also very pleased with the most recent proposals of Lend Lease to redevelop the Jolimont site. However, the point that I want to make today is really confined specifically to the future of the Monaro Mall.

In the course of making the announcement in Sydney, no guarantee was given that all present tenants would be assured of a place in the new Mall. This is most unfair. Many of these tenants have put their savings and life's work into their businesses. Many have built up excellent reputations over more than 15 years of operation of the Monaro Mall. These tenants should be given a place in the new development. They should also be given reasonable leases for at least two to three years so that they can continue to plan and develop their businesses on a rational basis. Many of these tenants have been told by Lend Lease that they can have only one-month leases. This is an impossible situation for a business to be in. Lend Lease apparently has no concern for these local people who have paid rent for years and years. What these local people really want to know is what the plans are for the Monaro Mall so that they can work out where their businesses fit in and what they are planning for.

I believe that it is not good enough just to continue with the situation of not giving them a guarantee of where they are going or outlining the plans for future development, especially at a time when Lend Lease has just released its plans for the Jolimont site. I believe that it is necessary to look at the whole of Civic as a totality in an attempt to regenerate the whole area, but what we need to do is give some guarantee to the small retail traders that they will have some sort of security in the new Monaro Mall development. There is no doubt that the Monaro Mall needs updating and revamping in order to help to re-establish Civic as the retail centre of Canberra. The way in which Lend Lease has introduced its proposals has led to a serious loss of confidence amongst small traders. Many are uncertain about their future. They are, understandably, unwilling to invest in larger stock inventories whilst they have no security of tenure. Lend Lease should immediately consult with all tenants on this project and give them the first option on a place in the new Monaro Mall. This will ensure that all existing tenants are treated fairly and will enable them to make sound investment decisions. Monaro Mall should be the focus of the central Canberra retail district and should be planned in conjunction with the local people. Lend Lease has a very special responsibility in Canberra, because of its monopolistic market position, to ensure that all small business people are treated fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to voice my and my electors' concern about the Government's introduction of sales tax on a wide range of items-in particular, the sales tax on books. I am not alone in my opposition to the introduction and extension of such an iniquitous tax as sales tax. Nor are all who oppose sales tax on this side of the House. The extent of this opposition prevented the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) from attending President Sadat's funeral, as his presence here was required to quell the discontent of his back bench. He was defending the imposition of sales tax with hints of future tax cuts. He was explaining to his party that the underlying significance of the new sales tax is in its future over-riding importance. In other words, he was giving a clumsy hint of promise to his unhappy followers of future personal income tax cuts, a promise given by him repeatedly since 1975 but never kept. The Prime Minister's credibility on this issue is so low that one has to be a card-carrying member of the Liberal Party of Australia or a fool to believe him. Whilst he may have extinguished some burning cinders on his own back bench, the Prime Minister certainly did not allay the fears of people connected with retailing of books. Small booksellers in my electorate expressed to me their dismay at the introduction of a sales tax on books.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a natural abhorrence of the Government's idea to tax books and publications; that is, to tax the basic medium for the flow of information. Besides the argument that the tax is a tax on information, there are many objections to such a tax on other grounds also. The pricing structure of books is such that the introduction of sales tax will result in increases of up to 12 1/2 per cent, not 2 1/2 per cent. The public will bear the brunt of the publishers' manipulation of the new scheme. Already publishers are talking about the possibility of increasing the price of some titles by $1, where the product is very attractive, and not adding any sales tax to other selected titles. The prices of books imported into Australia are converted at rates of between three and five times the imported prices. The public already objects to some dubious practices in this area and it does arouse confusion and suspicion of the retailer. With the sales tax mathematics added, breaches of conversion will be extremely hard to detect, especially for the public. Publishers will be able more easily to pull the wool over the eyes of the book buying public.

Books are sold to retail outlets on a sale or return basis; that is, books not sold by retailers are returnable to publishers for full credit. Later it is common for them to be resold at greatly reduced prices, a practice known in the trade as 'remaindering'. So the occasion might arise when a second amount of sales tax may have to be paid on the same books. Whether the retailer pays twice or not, the public's confidence as to whether the prices charged are justified will be undermined.

Small booksellers or suburban bookshops may lose their school and library accounts, often a large proportion of their turnover. Library suppliers will be exempt and will therefore be able to undercut small retailers. This situation is a grave threat to individual retail booksellers. The retail book trade is already in a crisis situation owing to the high prices charged by importers and the public's resistance to paying such high prices. Moreover, this tax will completely eliminate small bookshops. Taxing books means taxing knowledge and information. Therefore, I would argue that the proposed tax is not only impractical but also unjust and dangerous. To tax knowledge and information is to strike at the basic principles of democracy. I urge the Government to withdraw the tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage-the first opportunity available to me in the Parliament-I want to make a few comments on the long awaited but welcome statement by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in announcing the composition of the soon to be established Independent Air Fares Committee. Last Friday, 9 October, the Minister issued a Press release naming Mr Kenneth F. Wraith of Melbourne as chairman of the Committee, the two other members of the Committee to be Dr Dolph Zink from Perth and the Hon. Kevin Cairns from Brisbane. Mr Wraith recently retired as senior executive of Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd. He has held directorships in a number of companies and has extensive financial and management experience in Australian business. Dr Zink was deputy chairman of the Western Australian Post Secondary Education Commission and holds a number of company directorships. He also was Dean of the School of Business and Administration at the Western Australian Institute of Technology in my electorate for a number of years. I think his appointment is particularly pleasing in the fact that Dr Zink is a Western Australian and he certainly will be well placed to be mindful of the air fare disadvantages long suffered by long haul domestic passengers.

SPEECH.PARA: The third member of the committee is Mr Cairns who was the Federal member for Lilley and a former Minister for Housing. He is president of the Queensland Branch of the Economic Society of Australia and New Zealand and has undertaken economic consultancy tasks for various organisations. I welcome the appointment of these three individuals to the Committee. As mentioned by the Minister, the Government decided upon their appointments on the basis of their individual qualifications and ability to carry out the tasks in an impartial and professional manner. I express my appreciation of their acceptance of what in my view will be an extremely difficult job.

Members and other people outside this place who are interested in domestic aviation matters will recall that the Independent Air Fares Committee which is soon to be set up in accordance with the Independent Air Fares Committee Act will be responsible for undertaking various tasks, including updating the domestic fare setting formula, adjudicating on fare increase applications by the airlines and conducting periodic cost allocation reviews which in turn are the basis for the air fare formula. My position on this matter, I think, is fairly clear in that I belong to the school of opinion that believes that proper fare setting can take place only within a true competitive environment. With the extension of the two-airline policy for at least the next five to eight years I do not believe we have such an environment, but we must be content with a regulated system and a regulatory authority which will attempt to determine fares on the basis of cost, thereby ensuring the viability of the airlines and, I hope, and in my view more importantly, in the public interest. I could not help but pass a wry smile at the headline in the Australian Financial Review of today. When reporting on this matter it stated:
A new bite at Holcroft cherry.
In fact Dr Zink was quoted in that article as saying that he expected the Committee's first task would be to determine a formula for setting air fares. He said:
The Holcroft Report got a fair way down the track but the whistle was blown on them a little early in the game . . .

In fact we have had two bites at the cherry. Holcroft in fact put forward an air fare setting formula and air fare adjustments were made partially on the basis of that forumla, and of course Price Waterhouse in turn reported. The question I wish to ask the Committee, on the basis of those two air fare formulas, is: What is the right formula? I put forward to the Air Fares Committee, in its initial deliberations, that there is no right formula. When we have a nationally consistent formula based on a flag fall and distance component it is obvious in the cost allocation procedure that as we weight the flag fall we favour long haul routes. Secondly, if we weight the distance component we favour the short haul routes. The Committee will have to come to grips with this insoluble problem. The second problem as, Price Waterhouse pointed out, is that the fares are set to keep the least efficient operator viable. In this case the least efficient operator happens to be Trans Australia Airlines, and in setting fares on this basis, Ansett Airlines of Australia makes a profit. I think it will be pointed out that the system is rotten and should be thrown out.
