SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention tonight to the Government's policies of care for the elderly which simply are policies of encouraging institutionalisation, policies which are against all trends in modern research which clearly support the view that, wherever possible, people in need of care, support and general nursing, as distinct from acute medical cases, benefit far more from community care and continuing to live in their own homes. In my own electorate this Government's attitude means that many elderly residents are forced at this time in their lives to leave the beautiful environment where they have lived all their lives and move into nursing homes far from the Dandenongs.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year a report written by Ms Jan Carter, the first Australian analysis of Federal and State government policies of care of old people, was published. This report stated that thousands of Australia's elderly people are unnecessarily being kept in institutions because of powerful medical interests and government disregard. Such people could be cared for more cheaply in the community if doctors and the Government were prepared to take some initiatives. Another recent study of private nursing homes in Brisbane found that half the patients were capable of living outside a nursing home. A large body of recent research in fact has shown conclusively that between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of people in nursing homes should not be in them and that home help services, community care and rehabilitation or local hostels would be cheaper and more desirable for the elderly. I have heard of cases of people who have no alternative but to place their elderly relatives in private nursing homes and institutions. In a majority of cases these people do not need acute medical care or institutionalisation. They simply need consistent care and on tap nursing services. Once placed in these institutions, often far from their own communities, friends and relations, these people often decline in motivation and in health. As has been documented by research, those who are not sick can be placed with acutely sick and disabled people and, lacking company, lose their own independence and spirit. The only benefit the Government effectively makes available for a person requiring care in his or her own home is the domiciliary care benefit of $3 per day payable to a relative or eligible person caring for someone full time. It is infinitely cheaper for most elderly people to stay in hospital than to return home and use home nursing services. District nursing services offer home visits on a limited basis. This service operates from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. only, and works on a priority basis.

The Government's new federalism policies, which are starving local municipalities of funds for community services such as Meals on Wheels, welfare and social work, are strained to the limit and are unable to extend any care for the elderly. Priority in service must be given to the sick or those recently home from hospital. The elderly have no guarantee of a regular secure service from their community, no matter how well meaning and overworked council employees are. In my electorate there are no community health centres or services to help out. Home care schemes are not readily available. There are relatively few special services, such as day care or temporary care, to prevent elderly people being permanently institutionalised. Lack of government support for families generally means that they have little choice but to pass off such care to hospitals and nursing homes. The situation is made much worse in Victoria where care in many nursing homes is inadequate due to overworked staff. The ratio of patient/nurse in Victoria is 10 to one, a figure which has not changed since 1939, when nursing authorities state that it ought to be no higher than six to one in this field.

I suggest that quite clearly many thousands of our elderly citizens could cope with their growing age and dependency in the secure and familiar surroundings of their own homes if they could have the security of community back-up systems and could afford the cost of having a nurse call on them, even on an hourly basis if necessary. Home nursing will never take the place of a hospital for a person requiring specialised nursing care, but it could shorten a person's stay in hospital following surgery or an acute illness. For many more, it could prevent their institutionalisation altogether. the Gvernment is ever ready to talk of individual rights and freedoms. I contend that in fact our elderly people, with the exception of the wealthy minority, are treated as second class citizens. For them life is not as normal or as full as it could be simply because of government organisation of the community. By ignoring community health and rehabilitation schemes, by cutting back funds for those organisations within the community which would be responsible for community care and by directing the vast majority of funds to institutional care only, the Government is forcing thousands of our elderly citizens to live out their final years in unnecessary isolation from their friends and neighbours.

Extension of grants to the States for the provision of domiciliary services to local government and voluntary organisations could lead to an extensive development of services. At present, for example, neither home help nor Meals on Wheels is available seven days a week throughout the year. Such bodies as the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Motor Accident Board have realised the benefit of taking the nurse to the patient and not the patient to the nurse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the House's attention the case of a child care project which urgently needs and is not receiving Commonwealth assistance if it is to carry on providing very necessary services to parents and children in my electorate, in the Waverley municipality. The McNeill Child Care Centre, the problems of which have received Press publicity-most recently on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald-is in Bondi Junction and was opened in 1978 by the then Minister for Social Security. The Centre, which is sponsored by the Uniting Church in Australia, aims to provide day care for the children of local working parents.

SPEECH.PARA: I should add that Waverley is the most densely populated municipality in Australia, with over 71 persons to the hectare. That population includes over 2,000 children in need of day care. In that area there are over 1,000 children from single parent families and upwards of 700 single parents dependent on the supporting parents benefit. However, in the whole municipality of Waverley there is only one place for each 23 children needing day care.

Up to now the McNeill Child Care Centre has provided day care for 41 children for up to 50 hours a week, providing each child with lunch as well as morning and afternoon tea. The ages of the children range from 2 1/2 to five years. The McNeill Child Care Committee, which in close consultation with the parents concerned conducts the Centre, is concerned to meet the special needs of many of the children receiving day care for stimulating companionship and educative play, as well as providing kindergarten facilities; so it has employed at the centre two trained teachers and three mothercraft nurses, also fully trained. The Committee has sought also to meet the needs of very young children of single parents. There are about 200 such children in the area who often have special needs for companionship and creative play and the Committee wished also to give priority to the needs of low income single parent families.

With those aims in mind, a neighbouring property to the Centre, itself a former Presbyterian church renovated largely by voluntary effort, has been purchased and named McNeill House. McNeill House will cater for 12 children under the age of four years from single parent families, with priority going to low income families. Once again, the object is not just to provide child care but also to give the children stimulating companionship and play, something which the children may well be deprived of. To carry out those aims, the McNeill Child Care Committee hoped to employ at McNeill House two specially trained staff to help the children attending the Centre at this essential phase of their development.

I strongly maintain that that most necessary project deserves Commonwealth support, yet I find that it has not received any. The original Centre, the McNeill Child Care Centre, since 1977 has received over $64,000 in recurrent capital grants and in 1980-81 recurrent funding was over $51,000. However, the Committee, after several applications, has been informed that no Commonwealth assistance will be provided for the new McNeill House. The reason for that refusal is that the 1981-82 allocations for the Children's Services Program will be largely absorbed in maintaining existing projects and that such funds that remain for extensions to existing services, such as McNeill House, will go to projects having a higher priority than McNeill House. The result of that decision is that McNeill House is unable to commence operations, especially as it cannot hope to cater for low income families without Commonwealth assistance. I am advised, moreover, that the McNeill Centre itself has had to lay off staff, despite the continuation of some Commonwealth assistance.

I urge strongly that the priorities be reassessed. I put it to the House and to those concerned that McNeill House is a priority project that will fulfil several urgent needs. I remind the House that more than the bare provision of child care services is at stake here, for the aim of McNeill House is to provide essential help to children to help them overcome very possible deprivation in their personal development at a most formative time in their lives, perhaps the most formative time in their lives. Nor can we afford to overlook the very real burdens borne by low income single parents seeking to do their best for their children. Nor can we afford to close our eyes to the situation of well trained staff who will lost their present and prospective employment due to the lack of Commonwealth assistance to the McNeill project.

I can only repeat my very strong concern that this highly necessary project catering to vital needs in a densely populated area should receive its just due. Surely we can afford the investment for the future that we must put into providing the best nurture for our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I was able to visit the Republic of Cyprus and saw for myself the plight of many of the refugees in that country who, unfortunately, have been separated from their place of abode and some of them from their loved ones by the partition of that country. Prior to my leaving Australia I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 21 July, asking that Australia take more interest in the plight of the Cypriot refugees. On 5 August I received a reply from the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), who was the Acting Prime Minister at the time, saying that I would receive a full reply as soon as possible. Unfortunately, that has not yet occurred. However, Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have copies of those two letters incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FIRST FLOOR 132 BEAMISH STREET CAMPSIE, N.S.W. 2194 TEL. 787 1372-3 21 July 1981 LEO McLEAY, M.P.
MEMBER FOR GRAYNDLER
My Dear Prime Minister
I am writing to you to express my concern at the lack of support given to the Cypriot people by the Australian Government.

Both Turkish and Greek Cypriots have shown in the past the ability to live together in peace. The present dislocation of the lives of nearly 1/4 million Cypriots (200,000 Greeks and 40,000 Turks) is due to the initial interference of the Greek Junta in the affairs of Cyprus and subsequent reaction of the Turkish Government to that interference.

I understand that the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in 1975 set up a committee on Cyprus and that Australia was a member of that committee. I would be pleased to be advised what action that committee has taken since 1975 to achieve the withdrawal of Turkish troops occupying Cyprus and whether Australia is still a member of that committee.

As Vice-President of the Justice for Cyprus Co-ordinating Committee of New South Wales and on behalf of the 21,630 Cyprus-born people living in Australia I would ask you, on behalf of Australia, to raise this matter at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Conference in Melbourne this year and support the United Nations' resolution on Cyprus if it is raised in the General Assembly this year rather than abstain as Australia did in 1979.
The cause of freedom for the people of Cyprus is a just cause and should be supported by the Australian Government and all Australians.
Yours sincerely LEO McLEAY MP for Grayndler The Rt Hon. J. M. Fraser, C.H., MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In Cyprus there are approximately a quarter of a million refugees-approximately 200,000 Greeks and 40,000 Turks. For some years now they have been separated from the area in which they lived and the area in which many of them had lived for generations. I think it was unfortunate on all counts that the problems of Cyprus were caused in the past by the interference of larger regional powers. The Cypriot people had been able to live in relative harmony for a considerable period without any of the great intercommunal strife that has occurred since 1974. In Australia at present there are over 21,000 people who have come to this country from Cyprus and who take a keen interest in what has occurred in their recent homeland. Of those 21,000 people many are Turkish Cypriots as well as Greek Cypriots. I think they all would join with me in asking the Australian Parliament and the Australian Government to play a more active role in endeavouring to resolve the Cyprus problem in international forums.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was in Cyprus I had discussions with people from both communities and the communities seemed to share a fair amount of agreement on a number of issues. They both seemed to feel that there was a need for some of the larger regional powers-indeed, some of the super-powers-to involve themselves in finding a solution to the problem. I was struck particularly by the unanimity among the political parties in Cyprus concerning a resolution of the problem. I think that the offer by the Greek community, if there should be reunification of the island, to disarm both the National Guard and the Cyprus Army is quite a significant offer to the Turkish community, which obviously was quite worried between 1972 and 1974 about the activities of the mainly Greek officered Cyprus National Guard. I think that a demilitarised island of Cyprus would be a great tourist attraction and would assist the economy of Cyprus. It would also be a great example to other areas in that part of the Mediterranean and the Middle East.

I hope that the Australian Government will start to play a larger role in the resolution of that island's problem. In recent weeks we have seen activities by the Australian Government in an attempt to defuse problems in other parts of the world. I would think that, with 21,000 people in Australia with a particular interest in their recent homeland, our Government should turn its eye towards doing something about the problem in Cyprus. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to place on record the Australian Labor Party's policy on Cyprus. I seek leave of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) to have the Labor Party's policy on Cyprus incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Cyprus

Conference reaffirms Labor's solidarity with the Government and people of the Republic of Cyprus, and its deep concern over the failure to implement successive United Nations resolutions and Commonwealth decisions on Cyprus.
In accordance with the General Assembly and Security Council resolutions in 1974 and the Commonwealth decision and the Security Council resolution of 1975 and the Commonwealth decision of 1977
Labor calls for-
(a) the immediate withdrawal of all foreign troops from the Republic;
(b) the immediate return of all displaced persons to their homes in safety; and
(c) the urgent continuation of substantive inter-communal talks with a view to reaching a just and lasting solution within the framework of the resolutions of the United Nations.
A Labor Government will make every effort to achieve the implementation of these resolutions and decisions on Cyprus.

TALK.START.PARA: —In finalising my remarks, I would like to say that the problem of the people of Cyprus is one to which we should all be willing to join in seeking a resolution. It would be a great thing for Australia if we were to play a greater part in world affairs, both at the United Nations and in the Commonwealth, in attempting to resolve that very important problem that affects a number of people in Australia. It would also show a great way to resolve problems in areas of conflict in the world, namely, by consensus rather than by armed struggle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which I have shown to the Government Deputy Whip. The table denies most of the nonsense we have heard in this House in recent times about changes in taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that in this table indirect tax is shown to have increased by only 3.7 per cent in the current Budget, which is the lowest rate for four years and about half the rate of two of the Hayden Budgets. I point out that total tax revenue will increase by 5.3 per cent this financial year, which is the lowest rate for three years and compares with a 13.1 per cent rise in real terms-all these figures are in real terms-in the 1973-74 Labor Budget, for example. Of course, it is a lower rate of increase than those in two out of the three Labor Budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: Those figures are the essential figures on which debate in this place should take place. How regrettable it is that the Australian Labor Party appears to be incapable of either reading those figures or understanding them. I hope that the incorporation of those figures in Hansard will give Labor Party members at least a solid base on which in future to maintain a sensible discussion, if possible, on tax in Australia. That table shows clearly that most of the nonsense being spoken in this House by Opposition members simply cannot be sustained in fact and that the present Government's record in tax, whilst it is not good enough yet, is certainly far better than that of the Opposition. the Opposition's attacks are quite appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may be extended until 10.40 p.m.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not detain the House. I give the usual assurance that I give to all honourable members who speak on the adjournment debate when I am the Minister on duty in the chamber. I will draw to the attention of the appropriate Ministers the Hansard extracts, when they come to hand, of the matters raised by each honourable member. All of the speakers bar one spoke on matters outside my portfolio responsibilities. I wish to comment very briefly only on the remarks of the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). I have heard what she said. I simply say in response that I encourage the honourable member and colleagues opposite to adopt a more enthusiastic and, if I might say so, encouraging approach to the future of Canberra. We cannot tolerate any longer the negativeness which is so clearly demonstrated in doctrinaire socialism. I ask the Opposition to join with the Minister and the Government in making the city of Canberra the finest national capital in the world.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what proportion of shares in the companies, (a) BHP, (b) Peko-Wallsend, (c) Western Mining Corporation, (d) North Broken Hill, (e) Pancontinental Mining, (f) CSR, (g) MIM Holdings, is held by bank or other nominee companies.
(2) Is he also able to say what proportion of the nominee shareholding in each of these companies is in turn foreign-owned; if not, what is the reason.
(3) Has nominee shareholding of major Australian mining companies increased steadily over the last few years.
(4) If so, is he and the Foreign Investment Review Board concerned by this development.
(5) Does he possess powers under sub-section 36 (1) of the Foreign Takeovers Act to require disclosure of the persons or corporations on whose behalf the interest is held by nominee companies.
(6) If so, has he used these powers to discover what foreign interests are involved in nominee companies which have significant shares in the mining companies referred to in part (1).
(7) If he has not used these powers (a) what is the reason and (b) will he do so urgently.
(8) Will the Government allow Australian equity in the companies referred to in part (1) to continue to decline, or will it take action to limit foreign ownership through nominee companies.
(9) What proportion of shares in the (a) ANZ, (b) Bank of NSW, (c) National and (d) CBC banks is held by that bank's own nominee companies.
(10) What is the rank, in terms of the number of shares held, that each nominee has in its parent bank.

(11) Is it a fact that where a bank nominee company holds shares in its holding company, even if this is on behalf of a third party, the bank is enabled to act in the same fashion as if it were dealing in its own shares, by virtue of the power granted by the beneficial owner.

(12) If so, will he discuss with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs the need to include appropriate provisions in the proposed national companies securities legislation to rectify this gap.
(13) If he will not do this, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Stock Exchange data provide information on shareholdings by bank and other nominee companies. These data are as follows:
Proportion of shares
held by nominees*
Company
As at Per cent

BHP 4.8.1980 17.0 Peko-Wallsend 31.8.1980 *24.1 Western Mining Corporation 29.9.1980 28.9 North Broken Hill 27.8.1980 20.6 Pancontinental Mining 26.9.1980 62.1 CSR 23.5.1980 16.7 MIM Holdings 5.9.1980 *7.3

* These data represent the proportions of total issued capital of the companies that are held by the nominees included amongst the 20 largest shareholdings in each company. (Data on other nominee shareholders are not available.) As such, these figures may under-estimate the actual proportions of shares held by nominees. The extent of the under-estimate may not, however, be significant as the 20 largest shareholders in these companies account for large proportions (in most cases, around half) of the companies' equities.
* Based on issued capital (excluding preference shares) as at 13.10.80.
* Based on issued capital as at 28.10.80.

It has been estimated that in 1979, 21 per cent of shares in BHP were held by nominee companies (P. H. Davies, 'Equity Finance and the Ownership of Shares', Australian Financial System Inquiry, Technical Paper No. 22, 1981).

(2) Without requiring nominee companies to disclose whether their shareholdings are beneficially owned by Australian or foreign residents, the extent of foreign ownership of nominee shareholdings cannot be determined. In those cases where the size of shareholdings of nominee companies is of potential significance for the purposes of the consideration of a foreign investment proposal against the requirements of the Government's foreign investment policy, it is the practice to seek from the participants in the proposal information as to the ownership of the nominee shareholdings, indicating whether they are beneficially owned by Australian or by foreign interests. The Paper referred to in (1) estimated that the level of non-resident shareholdings in BHP in 1979 was 21.8 per cent.
(3) Studies cited in the Davies paper indicate that the extent of nominee holdings in Australian companies has increased in recent years.

(4) The Government and the Foreign Investment Review Board will continue to monitor carefully nominee holdings in Australian companies where these are of significance for purposes of consideration of a foreign investment proposal.

(5) to (7) Under section 36 of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975, the Treasurer may require information where 'he has reason to believe that a person is capable of giving information or producing documents relating to matters that are relevant to the exercise by the Treasurer of his powers under this Act'. This power may be used in relation to foreign investment proposals that are subject to the Foreign Takeovers Act. In other cases, there is reliance upon the co-operation of the parties to the proposal in seeking any required information. As noted in the answer to (2), information as to the beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings is sought in those cases where such information is required for consideration of a foreign investment proposal.

(8) The Government's foreign investment policy places particular emphasis on Australian equity participation in the ownership and control of the country's natural resources and industries. The Australian equity participation guidelines in the policy provide encouragement to Australian ownership and control of natural resource projects and the naturalisation provisions provide an incentive for companies that are predominantly foreign-owned to introduce higher Australian ownership and Australian control. The available data would appear to indicate that the level of foreign ownership in the economy has been relatively stable for several years, with the proportion of company income, after payment of tax, that is payable abroad, being around one-third. It should also be noted that the Australian equity participation guidelines are applied on a project rather than a company basis. As such, the guidelines are not primarily concerned with levels of Australian equity in particular companies, but are directed towards ensuring that appropriate levels of Australian ownership and control of natural resource projects are achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the forthcoming national census, is there a proposal to ascertain 2 tabulations of population based on (a) where citizens will be actually situated on the evening of 30 June 1981 and (b) the actual place of permanent residence of each citizen.
(2) If so, does this represent a departure from past practice.

(3) Which tabulation will the Government employ (a) in ascertaining State entitlements of the number of Federal electoral divisions, which are related to Statistician-supplied population figures and (b) in calculation of Federal funding to the various States where population has any part of such calculation.

(4) As Queensland traditionally has a very large number of temporary residents, particularly in the winter months, can he say whether adoption of the alternative population assessment would (a) threaten any reduction in the present number of Federal electoral divisions in Queensland, (b) delay entitlement to an additional Federal electoral division in Queensland, despite the continuing population increase in that State and (c) in any way prejudice either the level of funds or the formula used in ascertaining Commonwealth funds provided to Queensland.

(5) If there is to be an alteration in the manner of ascertaining or tabulating the population of the various States and Territories, will this be to the detriment and disadvantage of (a) Queensland, (b) Western Australia and (c) the Northern Territory.

(6) Will the Government give an assurance that if there are to be 2 tabulations of population, in electoral and funding considerations, there will be no departure from the basis used in previous census, and that the figures will be based on the actual situation of persons on the evening the census is taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(3) (a) The Australian Electoral Office and the Australian Bureau of Statistics have provided the following answer.

Under the Representation Act 1905, the Chief Australian Electoral Officer is required, in the twelfth month of the life of every Parliament, to make a determination of the number of Members of the House of Representatives to be elected from each State. The determination is based on the latest official population statistics of the Commonwealth and the States supplied at the time by the Australian Statistician.

As the 32nd Parliament was opened on 25 November 1980, the Chief Australian Electoral Officer must make his next determination in the month ending 24 November 1981. This will be made on the official population statistics provided by the Australian Statistician.

Following the June 1981 Census the official population statistics will be based on the 'usual residence' information derived from that census. However, as the 1981 Census figures will not be available in time for the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to make his determination, the population statistics on which this determination is made will be those based on the 1976 Census 'place of enumeration' data. The present projections of the future populations of the States prepared on this basis do not indicate any change in the present representational entitlement of any State in November 1981. It is difficult to foresee what effect population statistics prepared on the basis of residence would have on the representation entitlement of different States.

(b) The size of population is one factor determining the distribution between States of the tax sharing grants payable under the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981. Under Section 10 of that Act the Australian Statistician determines the estimated population at 31 December each year for purposes of calculating the tax sharing grants and, from 1981-82, the population figures to be used in making that determination will be based on 'usual residence' figures derived from the June 1981 Census. This is a change from previous practice under which estimates have been based on the 1976 Census 'place of enumeration' information.
(4) (a) and (b) See 3 (a) above.

(4) (c) and (5) Preliminary projections of population figures for December 1981 based on 'usual residence' have indicated that some States will receive in 1981-82 a lower growth in their tax sharing grants than if previous arrangements had continued. In the light of the relatively large effect on the estimated tax sharing grant payable to Queensland in 1981-82 the Commonwealth agreed, at the 20 June 1981 Premiers Conference, to supplement the tax sharing grant otherwise payable to that State in 1981-82 by $9m. In addition, in accordance with an undertaking given to the Northern Territory that the Territory's grant for 1981-82 should reflect the population element contained in the Memorandum of Understanding, the Commonwealth has agreed that the Northern Territory's tax sharing entitlement in 1981-82 not be determined by reference to 'usual residence' population figures for December 1981 but will be a fixed amount of $315.1m.
(6) See (3) (a) and (b).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the continued failure of Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Sri Lanka and Thailand to ratify International Labour Organisation Convention No 87-Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948, is due to their objections to the Convention's Article 5 which gives workers' organisations the right to affiliate with international organisations of workers.
(2) Has Australia discussed this convention with any of these States; if so, on what occasions and with what response.

(3) Has Australia raised this convention for discussion at meetings of (a) Commonwealth Heads of Government (b) ASEAN Ministers or (c) the International Labour Organisations; if so, at which meetings and with what results.
(4) Have 93 States ratified this convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am having the record checked in relation to the matter raised in this part of the honourable member's question and I shall inform him appropriately in due course.
(2) Australia has not raised with the countries mentioned by the honourable member the question of the ratifying Convention No 87 because it is primarily for their internal decision.

(3) (a) No. (b) Australia could not raise any matter at a meeting of ASEAN Ministers. (c) Australia has taken part in discussions touching Convention 87 in meetings of Asian and Pacific Labour Ministers (which include Ministers from ASEAN countries) and in a variety of meetings associated with the International Labour Organisation. Australia's general attitude in such discussions has been that it favours ratification of the Convention, which it has itself ratified, because of its fundamental significance to the role of the ILO. For example, the Ninth ILO Asian Regional Conference (Manila, December 1980) included an agenda item on Freedom of Association, Labour Relations and Development in Asia. The conclusions adopted by the Conference include a statement of general principle that governments should give serious consideration to the ratification and effective implementation of ILO Conventions on Freedom of Association.
(4) As at 1 January 1981, 93 Member States of the ILO had ratified Convention No 87.

(3) Has Australia discussed these conventions with any of these States; if so, on what occasions and with what response.

(4) Has Australia raised the issue of these conventions in discussions with (a) Commonwealth Heads of Government, (b) ASEAN Ministers or (c) the International Labour Organisation; if so, on what occasions and with what response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The denunciation by Singapore of ILO Convention No 105-Abolition of Forced Labour, 1957, was registered on 19 April 1980, with effect from that date. The application of that Convention by Singapore had given rise to problems which had been the subject of observation by the ILO Committee of Experts on the application of Conventions and Recommendations.

(2) (a) and (b) I understand that the Government of Singapore had been considering denunciation of ILO Convention No 98 but that discussions about the matter have ensued between a representative of the Director-General of the ILO and the Singapore Government. I am not aware whether there is a likelihood of Malaysia denouncing ILO Convention No 98 or of Sri Lanka denouncing ILO Convention No 89.
(4) (a) and (b) No.
(4) (c) No. Australia, which has ratified Conventions No 98 and 105 has of course participated in meetings at which these Conventions have been discussed at the ILO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that the Superannuation Fund investment requirement provisions under Section 23F of the Income Tax Assessment Act offer no clear guidelines with respect to (a) the definition of a commercial rate of interest and (b) when an investment ceases to be an investment and becomes a trading situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 23F of the Income Tax Assessment Act does not refer specifically to commercial rates of interest or to the distinction between investment and trading.

It is necessary, however, for the Commissioner to pay attention to these factors in administering section 23F which exempts from tax the income of a superannuation fund which, amongst other things, is established and maintained by an employer solely for the purpose of providing superannuation benefits for employees and their dependants.

The High Court has suggested that when moneys placed in a fund are returned to the employer by way of loan the proper conclusion may be that the fund is not entitled to exemption under section 23F because it is not established and maintained solely for the purpose of providing superannuation benefits for employees and their dependants. This would be particularly so where the moneys are lent free of interest or at non-commercial rates. Where the trustees of a fund use the trust moneys to engage in trading activities instead of investing them appropriately, a similar conclusion may be drawn.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that the Victorian Government has considered making it compulsory for junior cricketers to wear protective helmets; if so, why have these helmets not been placed in the same category as pony club helmets which are regarded as items of apparel and are therefore exempt from sales tax.
(3) Will he now consider exempting safety helmets worn by cricketers from sales tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Item 120 (1) in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act provides a general exemption for clothing but an exclusion from that item has had the effect of denying exemption for protective cricket helmets and similar equipment.

In the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1981, introduced into the House on 18 August 1981, the Government proposes the removal of the exclusion, see clause 32 of Part 1 of the Schedule to the Bill. The effect of this proposal will be that protective cricket helmets become exempt. However, under the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981 they will, along with clothing generally, become taxable at 2 1/2 per cent from 1 January 1982.

I might add that the Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that the sales tax content in the price of a cricket helmet selling retail for $70 should not exceed $8 at the rate of tax (15 per cent) applying on 18 August 1981. It will be considerably less after 1 January 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Bureau of Statistics Quarterly Table

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it feasible for the Australian Bureau of Statistics to redesign the Quarterly Table which currently calculates average weekly earnings in terms of male units, so that particulars of wages and salaries are shown separately for males and for females; if not, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Quarterly Average Weekly Earnings series are currently derived from information on payroll rax returns, direct returns from some government bodies and estimates of wages and salaries for employees not covered by these sources. These sources of information do not provide separate figures for wages and salaries paid to males and females. Accordingly, an estimate of the ratio of female to male average earnings is made from results of an annual survey of earnings and applied to the information obtained from the sources given above. Estimates of aggregate wages and salaries are divided by the number of male units to derive an average earnings estimate in terms of male units.

The present payroll tax based series for average weekly earnings per male unit has become increasingly unsatisfactory and from the September quarter 1981 onwards, estimates of average weekly earnings will be based on the results of a new quarterly survey of employers. The new collection will allow the production of separate estimates for male and female average earnings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that money spent on home insulation is an authorised tax deduction.
(2) If so, from what date is the expenditure an allowable deduction.
(3) Has the Government given consideration to permitting a deduction for individual expenditure on insulation prior to that date; if so, what were the reasons for not permitting the deduction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) A deduction is allowed for amounts paid by a resident taxpayer for thermal insulation materials, and for the cost of their installation in a dwelling, if the dwelling is the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia. A further condition is that the taxpayer or, in the case of married couples, the taxpayer or his or her spouse, has not previously owned another dwelling in Australia that he or she used as a home. For these purposes, a married couple includes persons living as husband and wife on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married. The deduction is allowable for the cost of insulating a dwelling that was purchased by the taxpayer on or after 1 October 1980 or, if constructed by the taxpayer, where construction started on or after that date. Amounts paid for the insulation of extensions to dwellings qualify for the deduction under corresponding conditions.
(3) Yes, but having regard to other demands on the Budget it was decided not to depart in this respect from the announcement made by the Prime Minister in his Policy Speech for the 1977 election.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Importation of Skins of Baby Seals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictions presently apply in relation to the importation of skins of baby seals.
(2) Will he ensure that products containing baby seal ingredients or elements are prohibited from being imported into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no restrictions on the importation of skins of baby seals.
(2) Policy advice relating to the import of products containing baby seal ingredients or elements is the province of my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.

I am informed that the species of seal on which the main commercial seal hunt is based is the harp seal. That species is estimated to be the second most abundant species of seal in the world and is not considered endangered by current levels of exploitation although there are differences of opinion on the confidence which may be placed on the estimates of population size.

So far as is known, there is very little commercial importation of seal fur and skin products into Australia. Should evidence be forthcoming that any seal species from which such products are likely to be derived is endangered by commercial hunting, the Australian Government would review its position on importation of seal products

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many organisations and individuals received sales tax exemption for sporting equipment during each of the last 2 years.
(2) What criteria are used for providing these exemptions.
(3) Will he consider providing exemption from sales tax on sporting equipment for amateur sporting organisations.
(4) Would the provision of this exemption be a valuable stimulus for preventative health measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no provisions in the sales tax law which specifically exempt sporting equipment for use by particular organisations or individuals. However, organisations that are eligible for exemption in respect of goods for their own use, and not for sale, may obtain sporting equipment free of tax. Examples are government departments, non-profit schools and universities, bodies that promote the interests of such schools and universities or promote competitive sport among their students and public benevolent institutions. These exemptions have existed for many years. There are no equivalent exemptions for individuals.

(2) The criteria for exemption for each kind of body varies. As a general statement the exemption from sales tax is granted to these bodies in recognition of their activities in the fields of government, education, help to the underprivileged, et cetera.

(3) This matter was one of the many that were examined in the course of the recent Budget deliberations. Because of the need to reduce the overall Budget deficit by almost $1,000m as part of the Budget strategy to contain and reduce inflation, all sales tax rates were increased by 2.5 per cent. In this climate it was not considered appropriate to grant a general exemption for sporting equipment.

(4) To the extent that participation in sporting activity provides some health benefits, it may well be that any increase in such activity that would result from the sales tax exemption sought would benefit the health of the community. However, it is considered that any increase as a result of sales tax exemption would be marginal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state in his Budget Speech that the prospect for the labour market in 1981-82 was for a slowing in employment growth (Hansard, 18 August 1981, page 62); if so, did he mean that unemployment can be expected to increase.
(2) Does the Budget propose that unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years of age will remain at $36 per week.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the prediction by the Victorian Liberal Minister for Youth, Mr Dixon, of increasing rates of youth crime and a growing incidence of youth homelessness unless unemployment benefits were increased and the means test raised in the 1981-82 Federal Budget.

(4) If so, what is the reason for the Government's decision to abandon the Community Youth Support Scheme which will lead to thousands of young people presently assisted through the Scheme becoming unemployed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Statement No. 2 indicates that total employment is forecast to increase by about 2 per cent in 1981-82 which, while still a relatively strong rate, would be below the 2.6 per cent recorded in 1980-81 and the 2.4 per cent recorded in 1979-80. This forecast easing in the rate of employment growth, together with an assumed labour force participation rate similar to that evident in 1980-81, implies some rise in the level of unemployment over the course of 1981-82, although the average level for the year as a whole would be much the same as in 1980-81.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) Since its introduction in 1976 the Community Youth Support Scheme has provided financial support to representative community committees and local government authorities to undertake projects involving unemployed young people in a range of employment-orientated programs, and recreational and community service activities.

More recently, and in response to changing economic and social conditions, the Commonwealth has taken several initiatives to increase the opportunities for young people to train as apprentices and to gain other practical training and work experience to help them to gain employment. These latter programs pay particular attention to those who have been out of work and away from education for a long period. Total expenditure on programs designed to expand the supply of skilled labour sought by industry and to assist young people in their search for employment is estimated to increase by 22 per cent in 1981-82, to $203m.

In the light of the increases in these programs, which the Government considers to be more attuned to present labour market conditions and requirements, it has been decided to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme on 31 October 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many helicopter accidents have there been in the Gladstone area, Queensland, since operations commenced at Clinton Airport.
(2) In which years did each of the accidents occur.
(3) What were the findings of the inquiries into each accident.
(4) How many helicopter accidents have there been in Queensland during the same period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Gladstone (Clinton) Aerodrome commenced operations as a licensed aerodrome on 27 October 1956. My Department has records of three helicopter accidents in the Gladstone area since that time.
(2) These accidents occurred in the years 1968, 1969 and 1981.
(3) The circumstances of each accident were as follows:

29 June 1981-A Sikorsky S58 entered ground resonance when it sank back onto the runway during an engine power check after lift-off. The under-carriage collapsed, but there were no injuries to the five occupants.

31 October 1969-Soon after lift-off the engine of a Sikorsky S58 lost power. The aircraft entered ground resonance when it touched down again. The undercarriage collapsed and the aircraft caught fire. One of the thirteen occupants sustained serious injury.

17 June 1981-While taxi-ing an Aerospatiale SA319 apparently entered ground resonance and was substantially damaged. One of the seven occupants sustained minor injury. The accident is still under investigation.
(4) During the same period there have been 71 helicopter accidents in Queensland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network evaluation team indicate in their evaluation that the UNIVAC switching system on which the Collins International Service Co. tender was based had been rejected by other tenderers because they felt its availability was doubtful.

(2) If not, and other tenderers excluded from their proposals the UNIVAC switching system on this basis, why was this fact overlooked or ignored in the preparation of the evaluation team's recommendations and will he indicate why a comprehensive evaluation did not take place.

(3) Was CISCO the lowest tenderer, if not, was it selected on a technical rather than cost basis on the assumed use of the UNIVAC switch; if so, was the final tender accepted on the basis of an inadequate evaluation of a tender which the tenderer has not been able to comply with.

(4) Will he, in the interests of the integrity of the public tendering system, have the tenders re-evaluated or re-opened in order that those tenderers whose submissions were based on a real and proven system can obtain a fair evaluation, in competition against actual systems being offered rather than against tenders whose technical basis is inadequate.

(5) Did the successful tenderer, CISCO, during tender evaluation or in their tender documents (a) indicate that the Sperry UNIVAC switching system had been researched and (b) guarantee its availability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The swiching system offered in the CISCO tender was a combined development and as such was not available for consideration in that form by other tenderers. The DISCON evaluation team was aware that one tenderer claimed it had rejected a specific UNIVAC switching system.

(2) The DISCON tender evaluation was comprehensive. The evaluation took into account detailed information obtained from (a) the tenders, (b) clarifying discussions with the tenderers, (c) inspections and discussions held at the overseas facilities of the tenderers and their major sub-contractors, and (d) inspection of demonstration switching, control and security systems. In considering this information, the advice of a large number of specialists in the Departments of Defence and Administrative Services was obtained regarding the financial, contractural, technical and security implications of the tenders offered. As indicated in answer No. (1) other tenderers could not have excluded from their tenders the switching system offered in the CISCO tender as it would not have been available to other tenderers for consideration.

(3) It would be contrary to established procedures for specific cost details of any tender to be disclosed. However, the comprehensive evaluation of the DISCON tenders included the assessment of price, technical capabilities, operating and maintenance costs, AIP, supply and support and technical risk of implementation. Based on a lengthy and comprehensive overall evaluation assessment as outlined in my answer to Question (2), the CISCO tender was selected as the preferred tenderer subject to successful negotiation of contractural arrangements.
(4) New tenders are to be invited for the DISCON as announced in my statement in the House on 10 September 1981.

(5) It would be contrary to established procedures for the specific details of costs of any tender to be disclosed. However, all tenderers were required to provide statements of compliance with the DISCON technical specification of requirements and provide details of the development status for the systems and equipment offered for DISCON.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that meat processed for pet food in any State must be dyed with a vegetable extract but that meat being transported interstate for any purpose need not be dyed.
(2) Have reports been drawn to his attention regarding unmarked kangaroo meat in Brisbane cold rooms awaiting transportation south.

(3) Is it a fact that there is no docket system or inspection system aimed at ensuring that meat sent interstate as pet food actually gets used as pet food; if so, will he take action on these matters beyond waiting for reports by the Royal Commission and independent consultants recently announced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The control of pet meat produced in other than registered export meat establishments is the responsibility of individual States. Some States require pet meat to be identified by means of coloured dyes, whereas other do not. Undyed pet meat may be transferred interstate under these circumstances.

Pet meat produced on export establishments may only be produced and transported in a frozen or heat-treated state to an approved pet food processing establishment, under strictly controlled conditions.
(2) Yes.

(3) Frozen or heat-treated pet meat produced on licensed local abattoirs and registered export abattoirs may only be moved to approved pet food processing establishments and controls over this movement appear satisfactory.
The control of pet meat produced on other than registered export establishments is the responsibility of the State authorities.

However, recognising the present inadequacies of control of production and movement of fresh pet meat from non-licensed establishments the States are currently working through the Standing Committee on Agriculture to develop a uniform legislative framework to rectify this situation.

In any case the honourable member's question is among those to be examined by the Royal Commission inquiring into the Australian meat industry. It is better therefore that I make no further statement in regard to the question so as not to prejudice the findings of the Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

(2) Did he state in the House that the Bureau of Animal Health received its first advice from the U.S.A. Department of Agriculture on 11 August 1981.
(3) Were other sections of this Department aware of the discovery before 11 August 1981.
(4) If not, what is the explanation for the 3 week time delay between the discovery and USDA notification of the Australian authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sand Mining: Fraser and Moreton Islands

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the chairman of Mining Houses of Australia, Mr Eric Alexander, that sand mining companies should forget about Fraser and Moreton Island sand deposits and concentrate on environmentally less sensitive areas.
(2) Did Mr Alexander also accuse sand miners generally of pushing their views too strongly and ignoring that of the environmental lobby.

(3) Did Mr Alexander (a) advocate discussions between sand miners and environmentalists to resolve their differences, and (b) recommend that Murphyores Ltd should resolve its compensation claim with the Commonwealth Government over Fraser Island, and withdraw completely from Fraser Island.
(4) Has he communicated his support for these statements to Mr Alexander; if not, will he do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Mr Alexander made a number of statements in relation to the environmental aspects of sand mining. The Government supports communication between mining and environmental interests on matters of common concern. The development of the National Conservation Strategy will provide one avenue for such communication. The Commonwealth position with regard to Fraser Island is well known. With respect to Moreton Island, I understand that there have been no approaches made to the Commonwealth for export approvals in relation to sand mining activities. The Government will consider its position on Moreton Island if and when, specific requests for Commonwealth approval are received.
(3) and (4) See above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement by the Chairman of Mining Houses of Australia in the Courier Mail of 16 September 1981 to the effect that sand miners should withdraw from environmentally sensitive areas like Moreton Island.

(2) Given the combined effects upon Moreton Island beaches and environment of the dredging of 18 million cubic metres of sand from Middle Banks in Moreton Bay and the go-ahead of sand mining operations, will he urgently require an environmental impact statement to be carried out into such effects upon Moreton Island.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I understand that there have been no approaches made to the Commonwealth for export approvals in relation to proposed sand mining activities on Moreton Island. Under these circumstances, there are no grounds for the application of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Environmental Impact Statements (EIS's) prepared by voluntary conservation groups have been reviewed by the Commonwealth Government in each year since 1975.
(2) Can he state what the average cost of preparing an EIS by such groups was in 1974-75 as opposed to the average cost in 1980-81 (in real terms).

(3) Is it a fact that, in real terms, Commonwealth funding for such voluntary conservation groups, declined by 60 per cent from $440,000 in 1974-75 to $350,000 in 1980-81; if so, has this reduction occurred when the costs of preparation of EIS's by voluntary groups have risen in real terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) None. The administrative procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act require that an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), directed on a proposed action in accordance with those procedures, be prepared by the proponent of the proposed action. Following preparation of a draft EIS, it is released for public review and during this stage, voluntary conservation groups may, if they wish, provide comment on the draft EIS. All such comment must be taken into account by the proponent in preparation of a final EIS which is then submitted to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment for assessment.
(2) Not applicable.

(3) Commonwealth funding of voluntary environmental groups was $400,000 in 1974-75 and $350,000 in 1980-81. The purpose of the grants is to assist voluntary conservation groups with administrative expenses.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vietnam: Use of Herbicides and Pesticides

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the statements of Government officials, in the report entitled 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study', that (a) Australian personnel were exposed to various chemicals in Vietnam, (b) potential risks associated with chemicals may arise from acute or chronic poisoning and (c) that possibility of undue individual susceptibility must also be considered; if so, will he now ensure that full repatriation benefits are paid to all Vietnam veterans making claims on the basis of chemical exposure.
(2) What consideration has the Government given to making ex gratia payments to spouses and offspring of Vietnam veterans making claims on the basis of chemical exposure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to the named report which contains a section outlining the potential toxicity of various chemicals. The report clearly indicates how some Australian personnel used certain of these chemicals in Vietnam, mainly to reduce unwanted vegetation on base perimeters. The report does not speculate on the actual extent to which Australian personnel were exposed to chemicals as a result of these procedures or from United States defoliation operations.

It is one of the objectives of the scientific studies now in progress to examine all available information relating to exposure to chemicals in Vietnam, including the records of U.S. herbicide spraying missions and material on medical conditions of personnel exposed. Manifestations of toxicity which could indicate undue individual susceptibility will be taken into account in this work.

Where there is evidence of a causal relationship between a veteran's disabilities and exposure to chemicals in Vietnam, the veteran is entitled to the benefits granted to others with service-related disabilities.

(2) Although the repatriation legislation does not cover dependants in this context, the Government has stated that it will consider appropriate action in respect of dependants if scientific investigation reveals a causal link between chemical exposure in Vietnam and birth defects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

(2) What requirement do the providers of this service have to meet for the provision of special meals for diabetics.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970 does not specify the type of meals to be provided by participating organisations. It is expected, however, that a 'meal' should consist of meat or fish and vegetables or salad.
Meals on Wheels Services are encouraged to supply a Vitamin 'C' supplement with meals by payment of additional subsidy by the Commonwealth.

Organisations which provide a delivered meals service are supplied with a booklet prepared by the Nutrition Section of the Commonwealth Department of Health which provides information on the nutrient needs of elderly people and on the planning and portioning of meals.
(2) There are no requirements for provision of special meals for diabetics. Meals on Wheels Services do, however, provide special meals for diabetics wherever possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would the pension means test for (a) single pensioners and (b) married pensioners be if the means test had been increased in line with consumer price index increases for each year since it was last raised.
(2) Will the Minister increase the pension means test; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The means test on pensions was converted to a test on income alone in 1976. In broad terms, the income test provides for the maximum rate of pension to be reduced by one-half of the amount by which non-pension income exceeds prescribed limits-$20 a week in the case of a single person and $17.25 a week for a married person. A married person is regarded for income test purposes as having one-half of the combined income of the couple. These limits or ''free areas'' are equivalent to the maximum amounts of means as assessed which a pensioner could have under the former means test while retaining entitlement to the maximum rate of pension.

Legislation authorising these limits came into operation on 27 September 1972. If the present income limits were increased by the movement in the consumer price index (CPI) from the September quarter 1972 to the June quarter 1981 (the latest CPI figure available), they would become (rounded to the nearest five cents)-
(a) $51.45 a week for a single person;
(b) $44.40 a week for a married person.
(2) I refer the honourable member to the answer provided by me to Question No. 2771, which contains an indication of the costs involved in increasing the pension free areas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Council on the Ageing: Funding Arrangements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current funding arrangements between the Federal Government, the Australian Council on the Ageing and State branches of the Australian Council on the Ageing.
(2) When were the funding arrangements last changed.
(3) Before the change, what sum did each State branch of the Australian Council on the Ageing receive from the Federal Government through their national council.
(4) What does each State branch currently receive in financial assistance from the Federal Government.
(5) Are branches of the Australian Council on the Ageing experiencing financial problems, particularly in Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania.
(6) Will the Minister review funding arrangements with the Australian Council on the Ageing to help overcome these problems; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Council on the Ageing (ACOTA) will receive grant-in-aid funding of $160 000 in 1981-82 from the Commonwealth Government. The Commonwealth does not provide separate funding to State Councils on the Ageing.
(2) ACOTA ceased its practise of transferring a substantial part of its annual grant-in-aid to State Councils from 30 June 1980.
(3) In 1979-80, the last year in which ACOTA transferred a part of its grant-in-aid directly to State Councils, $100 000 was transferred. The following allocations were made by ACOTA:

New South Wales 28,551.50 Victoria 19,470.50 South Australia 14,270.50 Queensland 11,132.00 Western Australia 9,559.50 Tasmania 6,180.00 Australian Capital Territory 5,034.00 Northern Territory 5,802.00

(4) Although State Councils on the Ageing receive no regular grant-in-aid assistance from the Commonwealth Government, my department currently provides funds through the State Grants (Home Care) program for the employment of welfare officers by State Councils on the Ageing in New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia. There is approval also for the subsidy to be paid to State Councils in Queensland and the Northern Territory. No subsidies are paid to State Councils in Victoria, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory. Recent payments have been as follows:
QLD-Approved May 1981-nil expenditure
NT-Approved December 1980-nil expenditure.
(5) I am aware of the current situation of State Councils as reported in recent newspaper reports, particularly in the August edition of the Australian Pensioner.
(6) I do not intend to review funding arrangements with ACOTA. The Government's policy is that grants-in-aid are made to organisations operating at national and territorial levels only.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a resolution of the Queensland State Liberal Party's conference that pensioners be permitted to earn up to $30 a week without loss of benefits; if so, what action has the Minister taken in respect of this resolution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that a resolution was put to the Queensland State Liberal Party's conference concerning the amount of non pension income pensioners may have before loss of pension entitlement.

In general, under current arrangements, the first $20 of non pension income in the case of a single pensioner and $17.50 for a married pensioner, is disregarded in assessing pension entitlement. Above these 'free areas', maximum pension entitlement is reduced by fifty cents for each one dollar of non pension income. In providing and withdrawing assistance on this basis, the Government is concerned to achieve a balance between concentrating assistance on those in greatest need and providing reasonable rewards for self-help and thrift.

While the Government recognises that there is a case for increasing the pension 'free areas' to encourage self-provision, it must also recognise that such action would provide no benefit for pensioners who are entirely, or substantially, dependent on their pension, while all part rate pensioners, including those with quite high incomes, would gain.

The cost of increasing the 'free areas' to $30 a week for single pensioners, with a corresponding increase for married couples would be significant-$80m in a full year. Such expenditure must be considered in the context of other social welfare priorities which compete for the limited resources available to the Government. One such important, and costly, priority is the twice yearly automatic indexation of pensions. For example, for estimated cost of the November 1981 and May 1982 pension and benefit increase that will arise from the indexation provisions of the Social Services Act is some $280m in 1981-82 and some $715m in a full year.
The Government keeps the appropriateness of the pensioner income test under constant review and will continue to have regard to the views of the community as part of this process.
Any changes in this area will be considered in the total Budget context.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telidon Television and Telephone Video Data System

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What broadcasting regulations will apply in the proposed Telidon television and telephone video data system operations to be introduced by Myer Emporium Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department is aware of studies undertaken by Myer Emporium Ltd into the possibility of establishing a data transmission service based on the Canadian Telidon system.

Honourable members will be aware that data transmission may be undertaken in a non-broadcast or a radiated form. The non-broadcast form involves the transmission of digital data over telephone lines onto modified television receivers, which is understood to be the application proposed by Myer. The Telidon system is also capable of distributing signals employing the electromagnetic spectrum as a data broadcasting service.

In relation to broadcasting applications of data transmission services, the Government's particular interest at this time is to ensure that all such systems are thoroughly demonstrated to be satisfactory during an adequate period of technical assessment, and that they comply with technical and operating standards specified by the Minister under the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942.

Honourable members will also be aware that Telecom presently administers standards for attachments to the telephone network under Sections 13 and 94 of the Telecommunications Act although responsibility for these standards is under review. These standards are designed to ensure the safety and reliability of our telephone service.

If Myer Emporium Ltd proceeds with its plans to provide a videotex service using the telephone network, it will be required to meet the same standards as all other users who attach equipment to the network.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: ABC Frequency Modulation Station, Port Pirie, South Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: When will the establishment of an Australian Broadcasting Commission frequency modulation station near Port Pirie, South Australia, to service the northern Spencer Gulf area, in line with the promises made earlier on the establishment of this facility, be finalised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As you may be aware, the 1974 Independent Inquiry into Frequency Modulation Broadcasting (the MacLean Report) recommended that FM broadcasting occupy the frequency band 88-108 MHz. This frequency band, however, also accommodates television channels 3, 4 and 5. Consequently, it is not possible to establish an FM service either within or adjacent to those areas which receive television coverage from channels 3, 4 and 5, until such time as particular television services can be reallocated to alternative channels. As the Port Lincoln television services utilise channels 3 and 5, Port Pirie, which uses channel 4, is one of those areas where the introduction of FM services is dependent upon reallocation of an existing television service.

Although guidelines for the reallocation of television services which occupy channels 3, 4 or 5 are currently being developed, it is not possible at this stage to indicate when they will be introduced. You may be assured, however, that when a suitable frequency does become available, establishment of a national (ABC) FM broadcasting service in the area will certainly be considered.

(2) (f) Protests were not lodged with the Soviet authorities. Experience suggests that the Soviet authorities are most unlikely to be responsive to such action. Moreover, in the absence of a direct Australian interest such as a consular interest, in people brought before Soviet courts in human rights trials, the formal grounds for protest are not strong. The fact of our joining with other Western Embassy representatives in making a conspicuous attempt to attend such trials is in itself a significant expression of Australia's concern.

(2) (g) Yes. It is not Soviet practice to give advance warning of such trials, nor is there any domestic press coverage. Apart from the problems of advance warning, the difficulty about attending trials outside the Moscow area is that Embassy officers need to obtain official approval to travel and must do so 24 hours in advance. In practice this generally means that the trial is likely to have finished before an officer can get to the city in which it is being held. Despite these very real practical difficulties, the Embassy has not relaxed its efforts to learn about trials in time to seek admission. The Embassy is making and will continue to make every effort to have officers attend trials.

(3) The Government has no recent information on the health of Dr Orlov or Mr Shcharansky other than that made available by organisations such as Amnesty International. The Government has supported, and will continue to support international initiatives aimed at securing the release of both men whenever appropriate opportunities arise.

(4) The Government's view of Recommendation No. 65 of the Report of the JCFAD on Human Rights in the Soviet Union remains the same as those outlined to the House of Representatives by my predecessor on 18 September 1980. Our attitude is not a function of the incidence of violations, however distressing these may be, but stems from important general questions concerning the conduct of our foreign policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Individuals and organisations wishing to bring new varieties into Australia are not required to advise my Department and, accordingly, I am not in a position to provide the information requested. However, a Working Party set up by the Australian Agricultural Council in 1977 was informed of specific cases in which overseas breeders were known to have refused to release new varieties to organisations in Australia because of the absence of a local scheme to protect their rights to those varieties.
