The Industries Assistance Commission recommended in 1975 that the introduction of legislation for plant breeders rights be expedited. Subsequently the Australian Agricultural Council recommended that the Commonwealth draft legislation to introduce a PVR Scheme. Numerous rural industry organisations have since indicated support, including the National Farmers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that on 28 August 1981 Mexico and France presented the President of the United Nations Security Council with a joint declaration which recognises the Salvadorian guerilla organisation, the F.M.L.N. and its political wing F.D.R. as representative political forces in El Salvador.

(2) Does the Australian Government propose to be one of the few governments in the West which continues to give unqualified support to the views of the United States of America Secretary of State Haig, who described the F.M.L.N. as being purely and simply terrorist.
(3) Has there been any further modification of the Australian Government's position on El Salvador since the statements made by the Prime Minister and himself to this Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Australian Government has never given unqualified support to United States views on El Salvador, nor has the Australian Government expressed any opinion about the F.M.L.N. or about the United States attitude to that organisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a Press statement in the Courier-Mail of 24 August 1981 entitled 'Airport Work Will Destroy Bay Fish Areas'.

(2) If so, and in the light of the fact that the official environmental study produced by the Department of Transport is dated March 1974, is there a need for a new and independent environmental impact study.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The 1974 Brisbane Airport Environmental Study prepared by the Commonwealth and State Governments provided valuable information on the existing environment of the airport site and its surrounding area.

Much of this information was used subsequently in an environmental impact statement (EIS) on the expansion of Brisbane airport prepared by the Department of Transport in accordance with the Administrative Procedures under the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The EIS was released for public review in December 1978.

Following assessment of the EIS, the then Minister for Science and the Environment advised the Minister for Transport that the environmental effects of the proposal had been appropriately examined. He recommended:

'that the Joint Government Co-ordinating Committee and its Working Groups remain in being throughout the planning and design stages, to facilitate joint consideration of the various detailed issues that will have to be resolved before work commences.'

The Joint Committee and its Working Groups have remained in being and are currently involved in the planning and implementation of the airport project. Environmental factors are taken into account in the work of the Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the Wheat Industry Finance Fund levy and the wheat tax collected from growers at the same time, and is the assessment of the amount due from individual growers based on the same harvest; if not, what are the mechanics for collecting each payment and when does the collection take place.

(2) For the 1981 wheat season (a) over what period will the wheat levy be collected from growers, (b) when is it expected that it will be completed, and (c) when will payment be made by the Australian Wheat Board to the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Wheat Tax Acts 1957 and 1979 and the Wheat Levy Acts (No. 1 and No. 2) 1979 the tax and levy are imposed on wheat delivered to the Australian Wheat Board and directly to a buyer with the authority of the Board. The payment received from the Board by the grower on the delivery of his wheat is net of the tax and levy. The wheat tax is paid by the Board to the Commonwealth within fourteen days of the first day of January, April, July and October in respect of wheat delivered in the preceding three months. The wheat levy applying to deliveries in a season (1 October to 30 September) is paid by the Board to the Commonwealth on 31 March of the year following the end of that season.
(2) (a) and (b) Each grower's delivery payment by the Board is net of an amount equivalent to the amount of levy payable in respect of that grower's wheat delivered to the Board.
(c) The amount due to the Commonwealth from the Board from gross realisations in discharge of its levy obligations on 1980-81 deliveries becomes due and payable on 31 March 1982.

(2) If a fee is imposed has consideration been given to the imposition of a similar charge on inspection of animals exported from Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there a considerable number of cot deaths occurring in Australia.
(2) Is the incidence of cot deaths causing great concern to many families.
(3) What action can the Government take to assist in research into the elimination of this dreadful waste of Australian life.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(3) The most recent figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate that in 1979 there were 397 deaths as a result of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. This incidence rate, and the uneven geographic distribution of cases, is obviously of concern to the community.

The Government places great importance on the continued funding of high quality medical research in Australia into the causes and prevention of disease. For this reason the appropriation to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) has been steadily increased each year by the Government. In 1981 the NH & MRC is supporting ten research projects relating to Sudden Infant Death Syndrome with funding totalling in excess of $280,000.
The NH & MRC will continue to recommend funding for any research projects in this area which reach a sufficiently high level of scientific merit to warrant support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government consult with any industry in general, before deciding to withdraw its offer of assistance for the proposed Sydney-Melbourne railway electrification program (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1850); if not, why not.

(2) What independent advice did the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions seek as to the likely long-run transport costs imposed on industry by the deferral or abandonment of the rail electrification scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government had indicated that it would support investigation of the project in co-operation with the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria. The States accorded low priority to this project and because of this the Commonwealth did not proceed with its offer.

(2) Adequate independent advice was available to the Government in the form of a consultant's report to the Department of Transport and another report by the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many jobs will be lost in Australia over the next 3 years as a result of the decision to adopt the recommendation of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions to break the Commonwealth Government's promise to provide funds towards the electrification of the Sydney-Melbourne rail line (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1850).

(2) Did the Government investigate the likely impact on industry and employment in the towns serviced by, and themselves servicing, the Sydney-Melbourne railway line before deciding to implement the recommendations on rail electrification of the Committee of Review; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This Government decided to withdraw its offer to proceed with this project only after the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria indicated to the Commonwealth that they accorded low priority to the project. The electrification work was not planned for the early stages of the project during which the upgrading of the line would have been given priority. It is open to the two State governments to initiate this upgrading over the next three years. The honourable member could direct the employment aspects of his question to those governments.
(2) Yes. The consultant's report to the Department of Transport addressed itself adequately to the regional implications of the electrification of the Sydney-Melbourne rail line.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Communications between Brisbane and Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many complaints have been received concerning congestion on telephone lines between Brisbane and Canberra for each of the last 3 years.
(2) How many cables connect the capital cities referred to in part (1) and has there been any increase to the number of cables in the last 3 years.

(3) Can he say whether the Member for Kooyong made a statement to the House on 28 April 1981, the effect of which led to an increased usage of telephone communications throughout Australia: if so, were complaints about congestion and overload on the telephone lines between Brisbane and Canberra received on that day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by Telecom that no specific records of the number of complaints relating to congestion are kept. Congestion in a telephone system can occur at various points, for example, within an exchange or in gaining access to a particular route consequently it is difficult to identify from customer trouble reports precisely where any congestion may have occurred. In general, however, complaints of congestion are relatively few compared to the level of traffic being handled. Nevertheless, Telecom recognises from overall measurements of its major trunk switching centres that levels of congestion are higher than desirable on a number of routes particularly during peak traffic periods and measures are in hand to alleviate the problem.

(2) There are a number of broadband systems which connect Brisbane to Sydney and Sydney to Canberra. Currently, 57 direct circuits are provided over these systems (27 Brisbane to Canberra and 30 Canberra to Brisbane). The circuits provided over the last three years were:
* temporary reduction in direct circuits compensated by adequate provision of alternative routing facilities.

When telephone traffic is greater than can be handled over the direct circuits the calls are automatically routed over alternative circuits. In 1979-80, 142 alternative circuits were available to traffic between Canberra and Brisbane. In 1980-81 the number of alternative circuits available was increased to 182.

(3) There is no record of any complaints relating to congestion between Brisbane and Canberra on 28 April although between 26 April and 28 April 1981 a co-axial cable at Grafton was damaged which would have affected telecommunications traffic between Brisbane and Canberra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that at the last World Health Organisation (WHO) annual assembly, Australia voted in favour of a world-wide advertising ban on the marketing of infant formulas currently being used as a breast milk substitute in Third World countries.
(2) If so, does the position taken by Australia in this connection extend to placing a ban on powdered milk and emergency food aid to Third World countries.

(3) Is he able to say whether Infant Formula Action Coalition (INFACT) claimed that polluted water in Third World countries is contributing to the misuse of imported baby formulas; if so, will he commit a special percentage of Australian foreign aid funding specifically to benefit water supply projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While Australia voted in support of the International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes, the code-which was adopted by the World Health Assembly as a recommendation only-includes the statement that 'there should be no advertising or other form of promotion to the general public of products within the scope of the code'.

The code does not recommend that information about breastmilk substitutes, i.e. infant formulas, be unavailable to health care providers who may need this information for situations where breast feeding is not possible.
(2) No. Exportation of products incorrectly labelled as breastmilk substitutes is, however, prohibited under export controls.

(3) INFACT, along with many other organisations concerned with the health of infants in less developed countries, has correctly claimed that polluted water supplies have contributed to gastro-intestinal disease among infants fed formulas requiring the addition of water. The World Health Organisation is presently engaged in a ten-year water and sanitation program. The Australian Development Assistance Bureau is already actively participating in this program and is providing assistance to clean water development projects in Asia, the South West Pacific and Africa.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the average cost of providing a domestic telephone service to new (a) urban, (b) rural, and (c) remote areas subscribers.
(2) What charges are levied on each type of subscriber for the service.
(3) If the costs exceed the charges, how are the costs covered.
(4) Is there any way to cover the costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by Telecom that although its costing system is not geared to provide data in the form sought by the honourable member, the latest results of its studies show that the average investment necessary to add each new telephone service to the network in 1979-80 was:
Metropolitan-$2,151;
Country-$3,010;
National-$2,530

Studies also showed that in country areas, for a service 20km radially from an exchange, the capital investment, on average, was of the order of $15,000 increasing to $21,000 at a radial distance of 30km.
(2) The standard charges for the provision of a non-business (domestic) telephone service in both metropolitan and country areas are:
Service Connection Fee-$150;
Yearly Rental-$95.

The standard charges are applied where an applicant resides within 16km of an automatic exchange. Where an applicant resides more than 16km from an automatic exchange he is called upon to pay a once-only contribution of $160 for each 1/2km in excess of 16km (measured radially from the exchange) or alternatively he may elect to pay a higher rental of $500 yearly.

(3) and (4) The standard rental and connection fee go only part of the way towards covering the total cost of providing and maintaining telephone services, the remainder of the costs being covered by fees charged for local and trunk telephone calls.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that a person who meets the Income Test guidelines necessary to qualify for a disadvantaged health care card on 11 out of 12 months of a year, may be denied a health card for a 6 month period, if on the 12th month that person fails to pass the Income Test; if so, would a more equitable arrangement be to issue the health care card monthly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. There is no six months period of exclusion for purposes of eligibility for a health care card following the refusal of an application or the loss of entitlement. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government be issuing a medal, to be known as the Rhodesia medal, to Australian soldiers who served with the Commonwealth force in Zimbabwe last year.

(3) Will he change the name of the medal to the Zimbabwe medal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
